column9: A short spiky acanthus for growing in a spot that is warm and dry. Full sun will bring the best flowering when the highly unusual short spikes of hooded flowers can best be appreciated. Flowers pale to deeper pink covered by pink veined hoods. 40cm

Leaves are barely toothed rather than the deeply cut form of the subspecies. peringii being long and narrow with slightly hairy texture. In flower they are again similar but with more of an emphasis on pink rather than pinky purple. For a warm sunny site.

A choice dwarf species of Acanthus from Turkey. The leaves are long narrow and deeply divided forming dense clumps. The flowering spikes are densely hairy and carry soft yellow flowers  hooded with hairy green bracts. Best grown in full sun in a well drai

Handsome and stately with dense clumps of deeply lobed leaves and stiff spikes densely packed with four rows of purple shrouded pale pink flowers. Well drained soil in full sun; Height between 90 & 150cm

beautiful bold broad shining golden foliage particularly in Spring and Autumn but also goldy in Summer if grown in the shade. Typical white slipper shaped flowers with strong purple hoods grow on 90cm tall stems persisting for a long time

Handsome and stately with dense clumps of deeply lobed leaves and stiff spikes densely packed with four rows of purple shrouded white flowers. Denser and squatter than the type. The leaves are broader in their lobes making the lobes ovelap and creating v

Bold architectural leaves are variously splashed and edged in white a colouring that fades through the season. Flower spikes are white colouring pink as they mature. A little neater and hardier than acanthus 'Whitewater'

Handsome and stately with dense clumps of deeply lobed leaves and stiff spikes densely packed with four rows of purple shrouded pale pink flowers. Well drained soil in full sun; Height between 90 & 150cm

Handsome plants with large shining ornamental foliage which appears cream and yellow in the Spring. In this species the leaves are deeply divided. Spires of foxglove-like flowers. Height 4-5 feet (colouring appears in older plants only)

The spiniest prickliest form of Acanthus spinosus. The leaves are so finely cut that they are reduced to a veinal framework with every part of the leaf a handsome silver spike. It thrives in hot dry conditions although it flowers less precociously than the type. 75cm
Handsome plants with large shining ornamental foliage. In this species the leaves are deeply divided. Spires of foxglove-like flowers. Height 4-5 feet

The leaves of this most striking variety are variably edged and splashed in white. The flower spikes are also a ghostly cream with contracting red stems. Altogether a variety which is sure to attract attention
A useful for brightening any scheme with open airy flat heads of bright white flowers; each with a dark eye. Easily grown and non-invasive. 60cm
Tall stems topped with dense flat heads of rich yellow flowers. A good long- lasting flower for the border which dries extremely well also. 120cm.
Short and stocky form with very broad heads of flowers. Flowers open deep pink and fade in the sun giving a lovely two-toned effect. Dense ground cover. 60cm. Full sun. Any soil
Short and stocky Achillea with deep cherry red flowers packed in tight flat heads. Easy to grow adaptable perennial which forms Dense ground cover. 60cm. Full sun. Any soil
Dense clumps of feathery leaves extending right up the stems to the heads of lavender flowers. An easily pleased & rewarding perennial Full sun. Succeeds well on poor soils. 75cm
Short and stocky Achillea with deep cherry red flowers packed in tight flat heads. Easy to grow adaptable perennial which forms Dense ground cover. 60cm. Full sun. Any soil

Tiny flowers crowded in dense flat heads in a selection of colours are a magnet to bees and other insects. Dense foliage clumps spread well to cover the ground. Excellent easily grown perennial for any soil in full sun. 75cm. Re blooms over long period if
A haze of pure white button flowers carried on stout branching stems. Equally beautiful when adding 'froth' to either mixed planting or a vase of cut flowers. 60cm - spreading

An excellent achillea with broad heads of flowers and sea-green foliage. Flower colour fades as the flowers age from a rich scarlet to a faded old-rose giving a pretty two-toned effect. Plants have a compact habit and good ability to stay upright. 50cm. S
Dense clumps of feathery leaves extending right up the stems to the heads of Pale lemon flowers. An easily pleased & rewarding perennial Full sun. Succeeds well on poor soils. 75cm
Domed saucers consisting of hundreds of small deep red flowers are borne in a long succession from june to September above evergreen ferny foliage. To 60cm when in flower
Broad flat heads containing a myriad of tiny flowers open scarlet and fade through burnt orange to tawny gold. Flowers July to September. For a sunny spot.
Flat heads of salmon pink flowers are displayed over a long period above ferny foliage from June to September. A good cut flower. For a sunny  adequately drained position. Height in flower 90cm
Broad flat heads containing a myriad of tiny flowers open dark terracotta orange and fade through burnt orange to tawny gold and finally cream. Flowers July to September. Very easy in a sunny spot.
An excellent hybrid form with flat heads of soft lemon flowers freely produced over a mound of feathery grey shaded foliage. 60cm. Full sun. Ideal for poorer soils

An excellent strong-pink achillea with broad heads of flowers and fine dark green foliage. Flower colour strengthens as the flowers age giving a pretty two-toned effect. Plants have a compact habit and good ability to stay upright. 50cm. Summer. Repeat fl
Flat heads of salmon pink flowers are displayed over a long period above ferny foliage from June to September. A good cut flower. For a sunny  adequately drained position. Height in flower 90cm
Intense dark cerise flowers crowded in dense flat heads. Dense foliage clumps spread well to cover the ground. Excellent easily grown perennial for any soil in full sun. 75cm
Broad flat heads containing a myriad of tiny flowers open dark terracotta orange and fade through burnt orange to tawny gold and finally cream. Flowers July to September. Very easy in a sunny spot.

Easy to grow adaptable perennial. The colour combination of sage like grey green foliage and flattened heads of burnt orange flowers is as subtle as it is beautiful. Flowers over a long period. 60cm. Full sun. Any soil

One of the mid-season Aconites. Stiff upright stems from finely divided foliage Branching heads of flowers in June and July. The flowers are typical ‘policeman’s helmet’. The colour is anything but typical being white stained violet blue towards the edg

A short bushy aconite which doesn't need staking. The elegant white hooded flowers  have broad purple blue edges giving a sensational two-tone effect. Handsome dark glossy foliage. Moisture retentive soil in  cool position. POSIONOUS IF EATEN
column16: A\Aconitum napellus subsp. napellus Anglicum closer.jpg

column9: A rare flowering treat in September is this magnificent monkshood with its dense heads of deep blue flowers on 5ft stems. (Sun or shade) CAUTION - ALL PARTS OF THIS PLANT ARE POISONOUS

Deeply incised foliage ruby-pink on emergence turning through pale green with cream and pink margins before turning fully green. Well branched heads of typical rich blue Monkshood flowers from September to November. Shorti at 60cm. For Sun or partial shade.

Beautiful upright spikes of deep clear blue hooded flowers are born in early Autumn on a short plant 60cm. This variety works hard for the garden providing rich red glossy divided foliage early in teh year from February onwards. CAUTION- POISONOUS

Beautiful large pale cobalt-blue flowers in good sized heads. Belongs to the Wilsonii group which lends it handsome glossy foliage and well spaced flowers in elegant pyramidal heads with plenty of side shoots for a great display.  CAUTION - ALL PARTS OF THIS PLANT ARE POISONOUS
WOLFSBANE. Tall stems with dense pyramids of narrow hooded flowers shaded ivory and green. A real treasure for part shade. 5ft CAUTION - ALL PARTS OF THIS PLANT ARE POISONOUS

Densely clumped slender spikes of hooded blue flowers rise 1m over pale deeply fingered foliage in early summer. A charming native plant for lightly shaded spot. CAUTION - ALL PARTS OF THIS PLANT ARE POISONOUS
column13: A\Aconitum napellus subsp. napellus Anglicum closer.jpg

column9: A superb aconite with wide branching heads of sinister hooded deep violet-blue flowers in late summer. An good soil in sun or part shade. 1.5m CAUTION - ALL PARTS OF THIS PLANT ARE POISONOUS

Bugbane. An easily grown plant for cool moist shade rewarding you with some of the last blooms of the year. The  clean white bottle-brush flower spikes are borne in late autumn on tall slender stems over ferny pale foliage. Needs no staking and resists s

Handsome mounds of  dissected glaucous foliage are topped in Spring by spikes of somewhat fluffy white flowers. Remarkable pure white berries with a  black dot at the apex on bright cherry red pedicels. For the woodland garden.  CAUTION - ALL PARTS OF THIS PLANT ARE TOXIC

Snakeroot. Whilst the chief attraction of this  delicate plant is the autumn show of pure white plump berries; the pale foliage is a delight all season.  Ideal for woodland or waterside planting. 75 to 100cm

Red Baneberry. Whilst the chief attraction of this  delicate plant is the autumn show of jewel like  red berries; the pale foliage is a delight all season.  Ideal for woodland or waterside planting. 75cm

Handsome plant of great distinction with its deeply divided rich purple black leaves and tall waving wand of pink budded white flowers produced as late as Oct. Dark colour becomes more apparent on older plants. Best with moist soil. No need to stake. Immu

Autumn Snakeroot. Possibly the best selected black leaved form of an already extremely handsome plant. The  rich purple black leaves and tall waving wand of pink budded white flowers  are very distinguished. Leaves fade to a dark brownish green by Autumn.

Autumn Snakeroot. One of the best of the selected black leaved forms of this already extremely handsome plant. A shade less dark in the leaf than ‘Hillside Black Beauty’ but still very fine..  Best with moist soil. No need to stake. Immune to slugs

This variety comes with exquisite black leaves and cylindrical flower heads that have a pink tinge owing to the pink colour of the stamens.  The deeply divided black leaves and tall waving wands of pink budded white flowers produced as late as Oct are ver
column13: C\Cimicifuga simplex var simplex Pink Spike #3.JPG

column9: Hardy Maidenhair fern. A delicate gem with branching croziers of pale overlapping pinnules creating a rich lacy tapestry on wiry black stems. 15-50cm. Best in a moist soil in partial  but bright shade. Prefers good air flow.

Hardy Maidenhair fern. A delicate little gem with erect fronds of soft golden green creating a rich feathery tapestry. 30-40cm. Best in a moist soil in partial  but bright shade. Prefers good air flow.

Hardy Maidenhair fern. A delicate little gem with erect fronds with soft pinnules making a rich lacy tapestry on wiry black stems. 20-40cm. Best in a moist soil in partial  but bright shade. Prefers good air flow.

Hardy Maidenhair fern. A delicate little gem with fine branching croziers making a rich lacy tapestry on wiry black stems. 10-15cm. Best in a moist soil in partial  but bright shade. Prefers good air flow.

Ccreeping rootstock and will slowly colonise to form mats of the most delicate foliage which persist throughout most of the year. New fronds in Spring emerge in shades of ruby and ochre gradually darkening  to the mid-green of maturity. Cool leafy root run and some shad. 30cm tall
Large spherical heads of dark blue; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture May need a deep winter mulch in the garden

The flowers of the inapertus Agapanthus are all long and tubular rather than the usual flared trumpets and hang downwards. Fully hardy provided that the bulbs receive a good mulching in the Autumn once the leaves have all withered. 150cm in flower. Flowers are a rich blue

The flowers of the inapertus Agapanthus are all long and tubular rather than the more usual flared trumpets and hang downwards. They are fully hardy provided that the bulbs receive a good mulching in the Autumn once the leaves have all withered. 150cm. Flowers are a good sky blue

A superb new hybrid Agapanthus with a unique colour. Large  umbels of deep purple flowers open from exquisite black purple buds. Flower stems are 1-2m high and are borne from July to September. Hardy in a sunny well drained position
Abundant heads of beautiful pure white trumpets. Flowering from July to October. 60cm. For a sunny position in well drained but moisture retentive soil. Or ideal for pot culture.

A Medium sized agapanthus distinguished by its dark flower colour enhanced by near black stems. Flowering from July to October. 60cm. For a sunny position in well drained but moisture retentive soil. Or ideal for pot culture.

A Medium-Small sized agapanthus distinguished by its dark flower colour enhanced by near black stems. Flowering from July to October. 60cm. For a sunny position in well drained but moisture retentive soil. Or ideal for pot culture.

Good sized spherical heads of dark blue lily-like flowers carried on dark coloured stems. A most striking bold cultivar. 60cm. July-September. Agapanthus enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture

Add a Mediterranean touch to the garden with large spherical heads of dark blue; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture May need a deep winter mulch in the garden. 120cm
One of the best hardy hybrid Agapanthus. Large spherical heads of pale blue; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture. 100cm

Add a Mediterranean touch to the garden with large spherical heads of dark blue; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture May need a deep winter mulch in the garden. 140cm
An excellent race of hardy hybrid Agapanthus. Large spherical heads of rich blue; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture

The first bicolour agapanthus to be bred in the UK by Ken Rigney. Neither blue nor white but a beautiful combination of both. Lots of trumpet shaped flowers are borne by reddish bronze pedicels and from white buds become more and more stained at the bases

Very large open heads up to 20cm across carry flowers with lobes cut most of the way down the flower tube each one washed blue with darker royal blue stripes down the veins and edges. Each flower has at least 4 tubes nested one inside the other. A relatively short variety 45-60cm
Abundant heads of beautiful pure white trumpets. Flowering from July to October. 60cm. For a sunny position in well drained but moisture retentive soil. Or ideal for pot culture.
A collection of the best hardy hybrid Agapanthus. Large spherical heads of rich blue; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture
A collection of the best hardy hybrid Agapanthus. Large spherical heads of pure white  lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture
A new strong growing hybrid producing deep purple blue flowers in profusion over a long period from july to oct. Grows tall to 1.5m . A real beauty. Hardy. Enjoys full sun with access to moisture

A strong growing selection taken from seed from the Kalmthout Arboretum. Produces large rounded heads of lily like flowers predominantly in shades of blue with some whites. Enjoys full sun with access to moisture
Large spherical heads of dark blue; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture May need a deep winter mulch in the garden

A new compact Agapanthus with a dwarf habit. Makes a good clump of leaves to 30cm and in July to September sends up many stems with umbels of mid blue flowers each petal enhanced by a darker blue stripe. Hardy in a sunny well drained position

A new compact Agapanthus with a dwarf habit. Makes a good clump of leaves to 30cm and in July to September sends up many stems with umbels of mid blue flowers each petal enhanced by a darker blue stripe. Hardy in a sunny well drained position

This bi-coloured Agapanthus packs a punch with its huge heads crowded with white lily flowers each with a strong violet blue flush to the outside of the buds and the trumpets. It has large evergreen leaves making impressive mounds and strong stemmed flower spikes soaring up to 1m.

Very refined looking variety with more than a nod towards A.'Windsor Grey'. It is fairly short at around 45cm with well shaped flower heads each carrying flowers of a pale powder blue wash striped in a diffuse cobalt.

A short growing Agapanthus with dense heads of double white flowers which sit above the fresh green foliage like pom-poms. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture. 50cm
A fine hardy Agapanthus with large spherical heads of pure white  lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture. 50cm
One of the best hardy hybrid Agapanthus. Large spherical heads of pale blue; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture. 100cm

Add a Mediterranean touch to the garden with large spherical heads of pure white; lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture May need a deep winter mulch in the garden. 140cm

Agapanthus ‘Windsor Grey’. A subtle and very beautiful cultivar which is very easy to grow. Flower heads are large and dense with distinctly trumpet shaped flowers that point down at an angle. The colour is softest lilac fading to pink as the flower ages
Large spherical heads of mid-blue lily-like flowers. They enjoy a hot position & thrive on the crowded conditions of pot culture May need a deep winter mulch in the garden. A medium height variety

Lovely warm rose-pink elongated (really quite long) tubular flowers in a long spike clearly defined into distinct whorls which makes it reminiscent of a betony. Calyces are also a deep pink.Smallish but distinctly upright bush to 2 feet high.

An absolute magnet for bees and butterflies. Conical spikes of purple blue flowers which are produced in profusion from mid Summer until the cold weather. The flowers emerge from dark violet purple buds and pale a little in the sun giving a soft pastel ef

This showy white Agastache produces long erect green pokers studded with white nepeta -like flowers over a long season. Nice bright green nettle-like foliage yields a liquorice fragrance when brushed against. It reaches 3 feet in height with strong stiff straight stems.

Purpley-blue tubular flowers emerge from narrow 3 inch spikes of darker buds and calyces surrounded by a haze of exerted anthers. The glossy lanceolate leaves are deep bronzy-purple on wiry purple stems and very minty fragrant. mid Summer into the Autumn.

Fat plumptious spikes crowded with lavender-blue tubular flowers surrounded by a pretty haze of exerted anthers all erupting from dark purple buds and calyces. Favourite of bees and butterflie.s  3 feet with fresh green minty leaves and stems.
A new variety from the United States with exceptionally large flower heads carried over an extended period. An absolute bee magnet

A lovely compact neat Agastache with wonderfully aromatic foliage. From evet axil of the stems erupt clusters of warm yellow tubular flowers which come from pink calyces. Flowers from May to September loved by bees. 60cm

A lovely compact neat Agastache with wonderfully aromatic foliage. From evet axil of the stems erupt clusters of warm orange tubular flowers which fade to orangey pink. Flowers from May to September loved by bees. 60cm

A useful plant in many respects growing in a wide range of soils providing there is moisture. Richly coloured leaves are an attraction throughout the season whilst the fluffy white flowers produced late in the summer are a magnet for bees and butterfl

Not a big blousy primadonna but nevertheless  a useful plant full of its own charms. Useful as it is late flowering with compact heads of small white snowballs which are just full of nectar. The leaves are fresh apple green with stems that will colour up
An loose upright non-spreading grass. Pale sky blue leaves have pendant tips. Makes a good foil for flowering perennials 18 inches high

Quite unlike the familiar ground-hugging bugle this Ajuga has upright stems with deeply toothed leaves boldy marked with a white edge. Flowers are blue in loose terminal spkes. Enjoys a cool moist root run away from direct sun. 30cm spreading.
Metallic bronze leaves and tight spikes of blue flowers. Excellent vigorous ground cover for wide ranging conditions. 15cm tall
A larger and more robust form of bugle with metallic bronze leaves and tight spikes of blue flowers. Excellent vigorous ground cover for wide ranging conditions. 15cm tall

If you want something a bit brighter than the native bugle then this is the plant for you. Not only are the flowers a good clean white but the foliage is a nice fresh green as well. Has the same ground-covering ability as all of its kin.
In all ways just like the standard bugle except for the fact that the flowers are a silvery pink. Excellent vigorous ground cover for wide ranging conditions. 10cm tall
Bugle. Lovely ground cover for a shady spot where the green leaves will make a dense carpet above which will stand dense short spikes of pink flowers in the spring.

Tall mallow / hollyhock cross resulting in a wonderful robust looking hollyhock but to 1.5-2m high in flower and way beyond hollyhock season. Soft creamy flowers with ruffled curly centres and burgundy anthers. As a sterile hybrid for Sun. Excellent (but not total) resistance.

Tall mallow / hollyhock cross resulting in a wonderful robust looking hollyhock but to 1.5-2m high in flower and way beyond hollyhock season. Bluey-pink flowers veined in a richer pink with ruffled curly centres. Sterile hybrid for Sun. Excellent (but not total) rust resistance.

A very neat refined version of Ladies’ Mantle with small neat foliage shaped like a rounded seven point star. The leaf edges are picked out in silvery hairs. Sprays of pale green flowers. Smaller and less rambunctious than Alchemilla mollis

A smaller form of the otherwise similar Alchemilla mollis with beautiful scalloped serrated edged foliage which often takes on a blueish-grey hue. Typical chartreuse sprays of flowers are produced in Summer on purpley stems and act as a lovely foil to other blooms.

Scalloped hairy leaves form a dense clump and are a delight when bejewelled with dew or raindrops. The flower heads are like a dense limey green gypsophila. A fantastic tough and rewarding plant that will grow happily in all but soggy sites thriving in d

Quite a different little allium with tall stems topped with tight heads only 4cm across but crammed with up to 40 individual flowers in a subtle shade of blue. Likes a dryish sunny spot. 50cm. Frost Hardy.Â Foliage starts into growth in early Autum
Very distinctive in the way that all of the flowers hang down like a bunch of rosy pink bells. 30cm

Each head can be 25cm across consisting of up to 100 narrow petalled 6 pointed stars. The colour is a shiny pale lavender set off by a green button centre. Once flowering is over the head drys to a pale straw colour equally as pretty as the head in full

One of the earlier large Alliums with a particularly rich purple flower heads. The globe shaped flower heads are produced on 70-90cm stems in May and June. They are excellent to create a bold statement in the border as a prelude to the full flowering of t

Huge heads up to 12cm across domed with a relatively flat base and flowers of white with a dark green eye. For a sunny spot where it can have a warm summer rest. This onion with its very broad leaves has been known in gardens since 1762.

Pear-shaped heads densely packed with flowers begin green and gradually turn a deep pinky-purple the colour spreading from the top until the whole head is coloured. All the time the heads maintain their dense drumstick form swaying on impossibly thin stems.  July. 60cm.

We don’t really know which variety this Allium is. It came form Dawn’s Mum. What we do know is what a stonkingly good variety it is in our clay soil where it multiplies freely and produces huge heads of lilac flowers which just get bigger and bigger as th

Each flower begins its life with a rosy pink flush which quickly fades out to pure white with a defined pink line down the middle of each petal. At the centre of the starry flowers is the round dark ovary.  sun or part shade. Heads 4-5cm across. 30cm June to July

One of the best giant Alliums with huge heads tightly packed with flowers that are a good shade of lilac. It is slightly larger than A. 'Globemaster' and quite fast to clump up in the ground. Particularly good with grey leaved Hosta. 120-150cm June. AGM
PERUVIAN LILY. A vigorous clone forming dense colonies of 90cm tall stems capped in summer in vivid orange flowers. Excellent cut flower.

PERUVIAN LILY. A new compact variety of Alstomeria with heads of rich yellow and rose lily-like flowers with a bold central flare.  Good garden plant for a sunny well drained spot and an excellent cut flower. 60cm

PERUVIAN LILY. A new compact variety of Alstomeria with heads of rich yellow lily-like flowers with a bold central flare.  Good garden plant for a sunny well drained spot and an excellent cut flower. 60cm
PERUVIAN LILY. plants range in colours through carmine; orange; yellow and pink all veined in deep red. Good garden plant and excellent cut flower. 90cm

PERUVIAN LILY. A new compact variety of Alstomeria with heads of bright scalet lily-like flowers with a yellow centre.  Good garden plant for a sunny well drained spot and an excellent cut flower. 60cm

Warm coral-pink outer petals kissed by just a hint of lipstick pink giving a warm rosy glow. The innermost 3 petals have all the vibrancy of a tropical fish being golden yellow with flecks of deepest beetroot guiding the bees to its rosy throat. Compact  60-70cm. June to October

Sugary pink darker eyed mallow flowers dance on tall stiff willowy stems in late Summer until the frosts. Strong growing clump from a hardy perennial rootstock. Wiry stems to 1.8m high. Full sun and good drainage but not too dry a soil. Superb in the Autumn border
Very pretty annual umbellifer. Excellent as a compliment in herbaceous plantings and good as a cut flower

Long-lived sun-lover. A Mass of willlowy stems which are sheathed in narrow fresh green leathery leaves topped off in June and July with a fountain of pale steel-blue 5-petalled stars. Good for Butterflies and fairly Deer proof.

Compact form growing just 35-40cm high with the deepest lavender-blue flowers of any Amsonia. It pays its way all year with neat shiny green leaves on a compact easy care plant topped with flowers in June to July
Prostrate grower for full sun and sharp drainage Finely divided grey hairy leaves from which come all summer white daisies with contrasting deep red reverses
A large perennial prized for its abundance of flowers of a bright gentian blue which seems to intensify in Summer's evening light. Full sun; drought tolerant

During June and July this glorious perennial produces tall branching stems heavily laden with the most intensely deep blue flowers like a giant for-get-me-not. achieving 1.2m (4') and happiest in a sunny well drained spot.

During June and July this glorious perennial produces tall branching stems heavily laden with the most intensely deep blue flowers like a giant for-get-me-not. achieving 1m (3') and happiest in a sunny well drained spot.
A large perennial prized for its abundance of flowers of a bright gentian blue which seems to intensify in Summer's evening light. Full sun; drought tolerant
A very distinctive grass notable for the range of colour in the foliage which is striped in shades of orange and brown.
Short growing single anemone in a lovely rich cerise pink

Rich rosy magenta with the two sepals being darker towards cerise. The petals tend to fade towards the edges which can create a pale halo which makes them really stand out against a darker background. 90cm.
Cupped flowers are a rich dusky pinky-red with numerous narrow petals intensifying the yellow of the anthers at the centre
A really short variety which punches well above its weight. The cupped flowers are a rich dusky pinky-red with numerous narrow petals intensifying the yellow of teh anthers at the centre
Pure white saucer flowers with golden centres on strong tall stems make this a gem for early Autumn. Grows in a wide range of soils; flowering best in sun. 150cm. Apt to spread
Pure white saucer flowers with golden centres on strong tall stems make this a gem for early Autumn. Grows in a wide range of soils; flowering best in sun. 150cm. Apt to spread

Almost white suffused with soft rose-pink becoming stronger flushed and edged on the reverse. Each flower has 12 individual petals which are arranged with great fineness as they arch a bit like a waterlily. Tall and robust

A short and delicate Anemone with bright rich pink very double flowers which are slightly cupped with richer colour on the outside and in the centre. In form the flower is rounder in outline and in its component parts than the similar A.'Prinz Heinreich'.

The large semi-double flowers are open saucers of glowing sugar pink fading paler towards the central ring of rich chrome yellow athers. Easily grown in soil that is not too dry. A lovely last fling before Winter. 90cm August-September
A treat in late Summer with abundant pale silvery pink flowers swaying on tall strong stems. Successful in a wide range of soils; flowering best in sun. 120cm. Vigorous coloniser

This variety has a kinship with A. 'Honorine Jobert' and A. 'Andrea Atkinson' but instead of the flower being composed of a few broad petals each flower is made up of up to 25 narrower overlapping petals. Despite being semi-double the rich golden yello

A picture of refined elegance; resembling most a dark eyed; pure white buttercup. The 4cm flowers borne on stalks radiating from a 60cm tall stem; emphasised by a lovely ruff of leaves at the junction. Moist soil in sun
A short robust anemone for the rockery with stems to 20cm carrying two or three pale cream-yellow flowers followed by 'cotton wool' seedheads. Spring flowering
A short robust anemone for the rockery carrying numerous vivid cerise-red upward facing blooms that always get it noticed. 20cm. Attractive 'cotton wool' seedheads. Spring flowering

This lovely form of our native wood anemone is one of the earliest strains to flower. It opens pale pink almost white from darker buds and gradually gains a deeper shade as it smiles up at the sun. It has a dark pink reverse.

A picture of refined elegance; resembling most a dark eyed; pure white buttercup. The 3cm flowers are borne on stalks radiating from a 60cm tall stem; emphasised by a lovely ruff of leaves at the junction. Moist soil in sun
SNOWDROP ANEMONE. Nodding fragrant white flowers produced in spring and then sporadically into autumn. A fine and easily grown perennial Sun or shade. Fluffy seed heads. 45cm
A treat in late Summer with abundant pale silvery pink flowers swaying on tall strong stems. Successful in a wide range of soils; flowering best in sun. 120cm. Vigorous coloniser

Pure white cupped flowers with a contrasting purple-blue reverse to the petals held on branched stems well above lush spreading foliage.  Voted best new plant at The Chelsea Flower Show 2011.  A.Wild Swan’ is in flower at a time when other large Anemone

An exquisite beauty from Japan with waxy lilac-pink nodding saucers with purple tips to the pale central tube. The flowers are held aloft in long stalked nodding racemes from late June through July. Slow to establish but it is long lived. 60cm
Imposing structure perennial and an excellent foil for the flowers of others. Impressive fresh green leaves and 6ft stems bearing large round heads of pale green flowers
Imposing structure perennial and an excellent foil for the flowers of others. Impressive fresh green leaves and 6ft stems bearing large round heads of pale green flowers
Imposing structure perennial with handsome deeply cut foliage. The stems; inflated leaf stalks and 1ft spherical flower heads all a rich maroon. Ht 4-5ft. moist soil

Starting remarkably early in  the year this plant pushes up fascinating glossy purple foliage soon becoming an imposing architectural feature topped with a dense spherical head of pink flowers. Not dissimilar to a more sturdy cow parsley but with less a
Imposing structure perennial and an excellent foil for the flowers of others. Impressive fresh green leaves and 6ft stems bearing large round heads of pale green flowers
Excellent edging plant that is rarely out of flower from late spring onwards. delicate silver foliage and yellow eyed pure white daisies. Sunny well drained spot.
Late summer sees this perennial smothered in pale yellow daisies with darker centres. Attractive evergreen ferny foliage Plant in sun. Cut back after flowering
Late summer sees this perennial smothered in pale yellow daisies with darker centres. Attractive evergreen ferny foliage Plant in sun. Cut back after flowering
A compact form of this ever popular daisy which is smothered during the summer in pale yellow daisies with darker centres. Attractive evergreen ferny foliage Plant in sun. Cut back after flowering
Late summer sees this perennial smothered in pale cream daisies with rich yellow centres Attractive evergreen ferny foliage Plant in sun. Cut back after flowering
A cross between tinctoria and cupaniana giving a bush with cream flowers over silver foliage
A charming delicate plant with open branched heads of small white flowers set with bright yellow stamens. Height 50 cm. Plant in full sun.
Near black foliage in a dense ferny mound rising to dainty umbels of tiny white flowers. A striking form of Queen Anne's Lace with great poise and grace. 100cm. Any soil
Near black foliage in a dense ferny mound rising to dainty umbels of tiny white flowers. A striking form of Queen Anne's Lace with great poise and grace. 100cm. Any soil

KIDNEY VETCH. Bright yellow pea flowers cluster in woolly heads and are a rich nectar source for bees and butterflies making this both valuable and cheerful. Good for naturalising. 50cm. short lived perennial. Grows best on chalky soils.
Pretty nodding lilac-blue spurred flowers blend perfectly into any cottage garden scheme; looking particularly well with shrub roses. 15 to 60cm tall. part shade
An old cottage garden favourite and a good cut flower. Abundant display in late spring of long spurred lemon yellow flowers in over fine blue-green foliage. 60cm. Full sun
A very dwarf aquilega for the rockery or raised bed Short erect stems carry one or two relatively large flowers; each blue with a white trumpet A charming little plant of easy cultivation
A delightful dwarf aquilega covered in late Spring with a mass of nodding spurred flowers. A mixed colour series coming in a wide pastel range. 15cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN

Pretty nodding blue flowers spurred with a white tipped corolla tube dance over distinctly blue grey leaves. A short variety with large flowers best suited to a rock garden or front of a bed. 40cm tall. part shade

A diminutive Aquilegia with most unusual green flowers with a chocolate coloured corolla and delicate foliage. 40cm high in flower and needing the protection of the rock garden to ensure it is not squeezed out by stronger neighbours but an interesting variety. Fragrant. May to July

An old cottage garden classic which will freely seed about any well drained soil and cheer any planting in late spring with its wonderful informal blooms. A selected rich pink form. Any soil that is not too wet. full sun. 60cm
large pure-white gracefully nodding bonnets each 4cm wide are borne on leafy stems 80cm high in great profusion. Often tipped with green on ageing the spurs are short and slightly curled.
An all yellow leaved sport of 'Woodside' Excellent in light shade where it brightens up any planting scheme. Flowers usually white or nearly so.       HARMFUL IF EATEN
A recent introduction with striking flowers in bicolour white and deep purple (near black). Would look good in a mixed cottagey border Best in light shade.    HARMFUL IF EATEN
Beautifully marbled foliage with its bright yellow splashing makes this a feature all through the season. Flowers generally a clear pale pink.     HARMFUL IF EATEN

An old cottage garden classic which will freely seed about any well drained soil and cheer any planting in late spring with its wonderful array of pastel blooms. Mixed colour range. Any soil that is not too wet. full sun. 60cm
A most distinctive form of columbine bearing double pom-pom flowers in pink and lime green; fading white. Grows best in dappled shade. 80-100cm
A most distinctive form of columbine bearing double pom-pom flowers in darkest plum purple. Grows best in dappled shade. 60-80cm

One of the spur-less Barlow series based around the plant originally found in the garden of Nora Barlow. This form has flowers that are a violet-blue. Would look good in a mixed cottagey border hanging above paler mounds of flowers. Best in light shade. HARMFUL IF
A charmingly subtle variation of an old cottage garden favourite. Double flowers start off pale apples green opening to a clean fesh white.WIll seed about once established. 60cm
A most distinctive form of columbine bearing double pom-pom flowers in rich deep maroon. Grows best in dappled shade. 60-80cm

One of the spur-less Barlow series. This form has flowers that are a fully double white with green tips. Would look good in a mixed cottagey border hanging above paler mounds of flowers. 80cm. May-July. Best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN

A  variation on and old cottage garden classic with unspurred flowers that are splayed flat resemblong a clematis. Will freely seed about in any well drained soil and cheer any planting in late spring with its wonderful array of pastel flesh pink blooms.
Long spurred short growing variety in a  good colour range. A cottage garden favorite & an excellent and unusual cut flower. May to June. 45cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN
A long spurred aquilega whose flowers are a violet blue with contrasting white corolla.  A cottage garden favorite & an excellent and unusual cut flower. May to June. 85cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN
An old cottage garden favourite and a good cut flower. Abundant display in late spring of long spurred red and yellow flowers in over fine blue-green foliage. 60cm. Full sun
Long spurred flowers in contrasting pastels A cottage garden favorite & an excellent and unusual cut flower. May to June. 85cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN
Long spurred flowers in contrasting pastels A cottage garden favorite & an excellent and unusual cut flower. May to June. 85cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN

A really tightly double flower with more than a passing resemblance to a pair of vintage frilly tennis knickers. The colouring shades from a rich cerise at the spurs to a clean white at the face of the flower. 60cm tall.
A long spurred aquilega with Rose-pink flowers with contrasting white corolla.  A cottage garden favorite & an excellent and unusual cut flower. May to June. 85cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN
A long spurred aquilega with Rose-pink flowers with contrasting white corolla.  A cottage garden favorite & an excellent and unusual cut flower. May to June. 85cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN
A long spurred aquilega with pure white flowers.  A cottage garden favorite & an excellent and unusual cut flower. May to June. 85cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN
A long spurred aquilega with pure white flowers.  A cottage garden favorite & an excellent and unusual cut flower. May to June. 85cm. Sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN
An old cottage garden favourite and a good cut flower. Abundant display in late spring of long spurred lemon yellow flowers in over fine blue-green foliage. 60cm. Full sun
Beautiful arum for a moist cool spot in leafy soil. Candy striped pink and white arum spathes spring from the ground in spring followed by the large 3 lobed leaves.

A charming if curious little plant for a moist shady position where it will produce dense mats of arrow shaped foliage. In late spring 'mouse tails' appear through the foliage which turn out to be the tips of the strange brown and yellow flowers huddled b

Small evergreen sub-shrub to 2'6" (75cm) creating a ball of shimmery silver ferny foliage topped off with long branched spikes of tiny grey flowers in high summer. An excellent foil for other plants and a delicate and attractive addition to the border. Be
Beautiful filigree silver-grey foliage especially suited to  complimenting pastel planting schemes. Happiest in a hot dry spot; but reputed to be a more hardy selection than others. 90cm

A tall strong perennial of stout constitution with purple stained leaves providing a lovely foil for the sheaves of creamy white flowers. A good backdrop to shorter perennials. Sun or part shade. 1.8m

A tall strong perennial of stout constitution with purple stained leaves providing a lovely foil for the sheaves of creamy white flowers. A good backdrop to shorter perennials. Sun or part shade. 1.8m
Creeping rootstock with upright stems of finely divided silver foliage and matching silver flowers. Beautiful compliment to pastel planting schemes. 2ft
Creeping rootstock with upright stems of broad silver foliage and matching silver flowers. Beautiful compliment to pastel planting schemes. 2ft

This ground hugging artemisia spreads to about 60cm wide; giving an attractive carpet of silver-white felted leaves. The flowers are small on felty stems that blend in perfectly with the foliage. Cut back each year in Spring. Dry spot.
Beautiful filigree silver-grey foliage especially suited to  complimenting pastel planting schemes. Happiest in a hot dry spot; but reputed to be a more hardy selection than others. 90cm

Beautiful in two respects. Firstly the arrow shaped leaves with stark white veins are a delight throughout the winter and cut well for flower arrangements. Secondly the bright orange berries clustered on short stalks are a colourful harbinger of Autu

This Arum is in many ways similar to our native Cuckoo Pint but instead of having spotted leaves the leaves are marbled in a mixture of whitened greens. A lovely plant to settle into shaded areas taking a fair degree of drought but growing better with
A dwarf version of the larger Goat's Beard Decorative mounds of filigree foliage and delightful plumes of creamy white flowers enhanced by their red stems. 50cm. moist soil
Goat's Beard. A grand handsome plant for most soils in most situations. A large 120cm mound of ferny foliage and masses of creamy  feathery plumes to 2m. Like a giant Astilbe

With foliage cut down to threads and a dainty feathery plume of tiny cream flowers this is a plant of delicate charms. Place in a moist lightly shaded spot to show its filigree charms to the best. 100cm

A fine hybrid Goat's Beard raised by  Ernst Pagels. He deliberately crossed the dwarf A. aethusifolius with the larger A. dioicus creating a mid height variety with the best of both parents. The foliage is fine close and well divided colouring brilliant

Spreader for shade. The kidney shaped leaves are a fresh apple green and covered in minute hairs giving the surface a silky sheen. One of the most adaptable and tolerant of the Asarum tolerating drought moist sites and alkalinity with equal ease. Deciduous and very hardy.

The leaves are a long tapered heart deep green with all of the veins picked out in a pale sage green. The growth is tight with the leaf arrangement chaotic as if all of the leaves are scrabbling to crowd out of a doorway at once.

Asarabacca. Shining evergreen foliage interest for moist shade where creeping rooting stems form loose groundcover. Curious slug pollinated flowers appear in spring. CAUTION. All parts of this plant are poisonous.

Attractive foliage for moist shade with heart shaped  leaves prettily veined in silver. Stems run and root  along at ground level which is also where the curious flowers appear in spring. CAUTION. All parts are toxic
Slender spikes of pale lemon flowers produced late in summer. A lesser known relative of A.lutea more delicate in appearance. Sun and good drainage. 100cm. Summer
KINGS SPEAR. Blue grassy foliage and spikes set up the length with bright yellow spidery fls. Interesting seed heads like strings of beachballs Sun and good drainage. 100cm. Early Summer

A selected form of our native Hart's tongue fern with attractive bright green fronds with an crinkled undulating margin. 45cm 18'' . A lovely foil for other plants or as a contract to other ferns. Will take dry sites once established if shaded.

Adaptable British native with  broad bright green fronds; crested in this form.  An excellent evergreen foil for other plants.  Best in semi shade. Will take dry sites once established if shaded. 45cm

Great form of Hart's Tongue fern that is little seen. It is a fine member of the Crispum Group with deeply ruffled edges to the leaves that are worthy enough on their own. However given sufficient light the leaves are a rich yellow for most of the Sprin
Harts Tongue Fern. Adaptable British native with broad bright green fronds that make an excellent foil for other plants. Grows best in semi shade. Doesn't tolerate drought. 45cm
Clear lavender blue flowers borne on stout freely branching stems from July-October Valuable for its showing in the Autumn garden. Height 3 feet

A short stocky aster whosr freely branching stems are a riot of late colour with their soft warm pink flowers lit up by the bright yellow centre. Not just valuable for their colour the blooms are a useful and much used late food source for bees. 60cm.
Violet mauve flowers borne on stout freely branching stems from July-October forming a loose low mound. Valuable for its showing in the Autumn garden. Height 3 feet

Very simple starry flowers with widely spaced petals surrounding a yellow disc are artfully arranged along graceful thin black stems. Each time the stem divaricates (= splits in two hence the name) a simple green leaf marks the break giving a simple eleg

A very dainty small flowered michaelmas daisy which is short (2' 60cm) and requires no staking. Its twiggy form makes an excellent foil during the summer while its myriad of pale blue flowers cheer up the autumn days and last a long time into even dec
One of the finest hybrids ever raised. Clear lavender blue flowers borne on stout freely branching stems from July-October Height 3 feet

Large and dramatic with tall stiff shiny jet black stems to nearly 5 feet high. Dark green leaves are also heavily flushed black by flowering time in late September. Clouds and clouds of quite large mauvey-blue flowers at a time when the rest of the garden is fading.

Lovely dark stems of the species which beautifully accent the pale pink flowers which open from darker buds and gradually fade towards white. The centre conversely starts yellow and ages dark ruby red. Greener in the leaf than the speciesand a little smaller growing to 1.5m.

Very strong growing tall (1.5-2m) beauty with strong stiff stems which support huge sprays of gorgeous cool clean white daisies. Freshly opened flowers have green eyes which adds to the immaculate effect. Flowering late in the year it is at its best in October

The pale lavender flowers set against black stems and dark leaves give this aster an elegant charm. It is tall and open creating a substantial but delicate show in October. Full sun. 200cm. disease free

Arching swags of pure white daisies with yellow eyes are borne on stiffly upright stems with gently arching laterals. But it just gets better and better until the centres transform into miniature Robin's Pincushions. Petals reflex with age and take on a hint of silver pink. 1m
The branches of this 60cm shrubby aster arch out to give a tiered effect. Each in autumn is absolutely smothered in small white flowers with a large violet boss of stamens.

The branches of this 60cm shrubby aster arch out to give a lovely tiered effect. Each branch in autumn is absolutely smothered in small white flowers with a large violet boss of stamens. Folaige is dark and smoky all season.
A glory in September to October when it is a huge  mound of pale sugary pink flowers covered in bees  and butterflies. A large showy michelmas daisy  which is largely mildew resistant. 200cm

A shaggy collar of narrow purple tinted bracts from which uncurl a myriad of narrow petals in a deep rich royal purple. The flowers begin with a reasonable regularity and become more unruly as the flower ages. 90-100cm. Reckoned to be the best purple
Selected by Julie Ritchie of Hoo House Nursery and named for her son. The colour is a good rich cerise not so strident as 'Alma Potschke' being a little darket in tone. The height is a good 4ft.

Falls somewhere in the middle in the colour stakes. The narrow petals are a rich but not strident cerise on their inner surface and a silvery pink on the reverse. With a dark ruff of narrow bracts and rose tinted stems it was certainly well named. 130-175cm

Michaelmas Daisy - compact plants to 50cm 2' become mounds of fringed daisy flowers in late summer and autumn. This variety has violet purple flowers. A wonderful plant for the autumn garden - no staking required!

A glory in September to October when it is a large  mound of rich; yellow centred ruby pink flowers covered in bees  and butterflies. A large showy michelmas daisy  which is largely mildew resistant. 200cm

Possibly the very last of all the Asters to be in flower. Typical shaggy novae-angliae daisies. The colour is a rich magenta with a dark central boss - it makes me think of Vernonia 'MammuthOne of the best good and late and not one of those awful blue-pinks. to just under 2m
A striking autumn flowering Aster with branching heads producing a mass of very bright cerise scarlet daisies warm enough to cheer the dullest day. Very easy to grow. Height 1.3m (4ft)
column13: A\Aster novae-angliae Andenken an Alma Potschke #1.jpg

column9: One of the first to bloom. These Aster blooms open as perfectly domed sugar pink powder puffs. As they mature the petals reflex to reveal a golden eye surrounded by a frilly tutu of sugary pink with silver highlights - A real girly delight ! Flowers 3.5cm wide. Height 90cm.

30cm. The short twiggy bush is literally smothered with beautiful semi-double lilac-blue daisies 3cm wide with yellow button eyes. Although technically semi-double the flowers open flat and appear as well formed singles. Mid September-October
MICHAELMAS DAISY. A shorter growing Aster with semi-double dark purple-red flowers on 70cm high plants. Will thrive in sun or part shade. September-October

The benefits of this hybrid Michaelmas daisy are a short compact habit combined with an abundance of clear blue flowers that  completely cover the plant. Blends beautifully with the rich tones of Autumn 40cm
An intermediate height neat Aster with a rich profusion of pale lavender-blue flowers with appealing pale creamy yellow eyes. Only 50cm high and flowering from late September into October.
MICHAELMAS DAISY. A shorter growing Aster with semi-double pale lavender flowers on 50cm high plants. Will thrive in sun or part shade. September-October

50cm. Rosy pink buds gradually unfurl lots of sugar pink petals to give a generous display of double pink daisies. At 50cm or below this is a cute little Aster. mid Sept into Oct. And it needs no staking ! Bred in the 1960's by Bakers Nrs and named after the breeders granddaughter !

This Aster opens a myriad of small (2cm) single lilac-pink daisies on a short twiggy bush. Although classified as a novi-belgii hybrid it leans quite heavily in both flower shape and branching habit towards the style of a lateriflorus. 80cm October. Some mildew resistance.

The michaelmas daisies are such a welcome flourish at the end of the year with their glowing profusion of rich tones. This variety is a strong deep crimson semi-double with a bright golden button. 90cm

At the National Collection of Aster this small flowered (2cm wide) mid pink semi-double Aster with dark eyes had me dribbling. A lovely colour and such a mass of blooms. A beauty that had to go home with me ! 90cm September to October.
A richly coloured violet blue semi-double aster with a broad robust feel. With its bright yellow button centre; it's makes a lovely complimentary accent amongst wilder pink michaelmas daisies. 90cm

Many petalled flowers are a dreamy candy-pink double with a fresh limey -green eye on newly opened flowers. As they age they seem to become fuller still as the petals curl and twist to form tutu of pink loveliness. excellent reputation for health and vigour. August-October. 75cm

Another of George Chiswell's Asters. Geurney Slade has beautifully shaped double flowers in a rich deep blue. Flowers are produced in September to October at about 1m high. Part of a series of Asters based on the Ballard strains named after the mining villages of Somerset.

A fully double deep violet Aster with good weatherproof blooms 4cm across. An excellent deep colour to contrast with the more typical mauvey blues. It stands tall at 100cm high and is a late season flowerer extending the season well into October. More purple than blue !

A richly coloured violet blue semi-double aster  with the advantage of a dwarf habit. With its bright  yellow centre; it's makes a lovely complimentary accent amongst wilder pink michaelmas daisies. 60cm

Intermediate between the very dwarf and tall border Asters. A stocky plant is smothered in smallish lialc-blue daisies and is ideal for the edge or near front of the border to give a dash of late colour. An excellent late nectar source. Late September 50cm. Flowers 3cm.
MICHAELMAS DAISY. A medium growing Aster with semi-double lilac flowers on 90cm high plants. Will thrive in sun or part shade. September-October
A lovely crisp white michaelmas daisy; particularly beautiful as it shines out amongst the rich tones of autumn. Flowers are semi-double with a broad yellow centre. 90cm
MICHAELMAS DAISY. A medium growing Aster with semi-double bright clear pink flowers on 90cm high plants. Will thrive in sun or part shade. September-October

Enormous 6cm double blooms of deep violety-blue with silvery highlights. When open a yellow eye is surrounded by a ruff of blue-violet petals a few of which remain partially quilled revealing the paler reverse. 90cm. Mid September. Bred in 1958 by R.Lindsey at Gayborder Nursery.

A lovely Aster with a really full skirt of petals which are a pale blush-pink flecked darker on some of the tips. Bred by George Chiswell. Worked for Aster breeder Percy Picton then started his own nursery at Midsommer Norton - Priory Nursery. Did a lot of his own Aster breeding
45cm compact. Sprays of large 4cm semi-double lilac blue daisies adorn this lovely compact mid-height Aster about 50cm tall.

30cm. Shell-pink fully double with creamy centres crowd this compact little dome. Petals have a little notch giving a slightly frilly effect. Bred by Ernest Ballard it is highly prized as one of the few dwarf novi-belgii asters to have fully double flowers. Mid Sept-Oct.
An exceptionally short michaelmas daisy which makes up for its size by the punch of its clear pink flowers produced in great abundance in September. 20cm. Any good soil in full sun
MICHAELMAS DAISY. A medium growing Aster with semi-double lilac pink flowers on 90cm high plants. Will thrive in sun or part shade. September-October

The benefits of this hybrid Michaelmas daisy are a short compact habit combined with an abundance of rich pink flowers that  completely cover the plant. Blends beautifully with the rich tones of Autumn 40cm

A very distinctively coloured michaelmas daisy with single medium sized (4cm) purple flowers with a burgundy sheen becoming even darker on maturity. Golden yellow eyes become tawny with age. Late September onwards. 150cm

One of the short series of Aster raised by the late George Chiswell Timsbury has semi-double soft rose pink flowers and flowers in October at around 1m high. part of the series of Asters based on the Ballard strains named after the mining villages of Somerset.
The michaelmas daisies are such a welcome flourish at the end of the year with their glowing profusion of rich tones. This variety is a rich carmine-red semi-double with a bright golden button. 90cm
Makes a 2ft high shrubby cloud of fine foliage surmounted by hundreds of tiny white stars. Lovely to lift a scheme amongst the rich tones of Autumn. Prefers not t o be too wet through the winter.

Excellent in dry shade where it will produce a gracefully arching mound covered in late Summer with 3.5cm white daisies with reflexed petals. The leaves are large serrated and stay fresh. 1-1.5m across. In many ways like a more beefy (some would say coarser) version of Aster divaricatus.

A really rich purple flower on branching upright stems forms a rounded bush. Flowers produced really late in mid October and on into November. Healthy green foliage makes good ground cover even in quite dry shade. Flowers nearly 3cm
Rich lavender blue daisies with a bright orange eye are held 20cm above a neat cushion of deep green foliage. Unusual in being summer flowering. A colourful and neat front of border plant
One of the prettiest autumn flowering  Asters. Dark wiry stems carry a myriad of bluish mauve flowers in delicate airy sprays. For a sunny situation. Height 1m (3 feet)

A very dainty small flowered michaelmas daisy which is short (2' 60cm) and requires no staking. Its twiggy form makes an excellent foil during the summer while its myriad of sugar pink flowers cheer up the autumn days and last a long time into even dec

Forms a generous frothy cloud of small pale blue flowers on a bush 1m plus tall. It forms a lovely foil to compliment more strikingly coloured hybrids A hybrid of Aster cordifolius produced before 1920 by Ernest Ballard this variety can be slow to establish.
A lovely tall aster with a very long flowering season. Masses of mid purple starry flowers in the style of Aster 'Little Carlow' and Aster laevis. 180cm

With millions of beautiful small 2.5cm single daisies in the most delightful shade of lilac which just keep coming and coming. Forming a goblet shaped bush which takes on a handsome burgundy tint in Autumn which is echoed in the tint the flower’s central
Distinguished by being particularly early to flower with its arching feathery heads of white flowers. Succeeds best in a moist to wet soil in full sun. 30cm tall
A dwarf selection; growing just 20cm tall. The pink flowers are shown off to perfection by the glossy closely knit deep green leaves. Any moist soil; sun or part shade. good for pots
A rich dark form of masterwort Tight clusters of tiny pink-maroon flowers backed by a dark collar. An interesting & beautiful plant Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage
Beautiful perennial with attractive collared flowers which dry excellently. Flowers deep maroon on 75cm stems. Dark stained foliage. Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage. Good on chalk
A rich dark pink form of masterwort Tight clusters of tiny pink-maroon flowers backed by a dark collar. An interesting & beautiful plant Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage

A rich pink form of masterwort with flowers that are fairly flat and open Tight clusters of tiny pink-maroon flowers backed by a darker collar. An interesting & beautiful plant Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage
Beautiful perennial with attractive collared flowers which dry excellently. Flowers age from white to pink in this variety. 75cm Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage. Good ground cover
Beautiful perennial with attractive collared flowers which dry excellently. Flowers tinted pink in this variety. 75cm Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage
Beautiful perennial with attractive collared flowers; tinted claret; which dry excellently.  50cm. Attractive pale green lobed leaves Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage
Another excellent addition to the red Astrantias. Not so dark as some but a good strong ruby red with fine dark stems and a good flat starry shape. 30cm

Seedlings that have come form a fabulous cultivar that came to us unamed from Mrs Davey. Beautiful perennial with attractive collared flowers which dry excellently. Flowers white tinted green with pink on the outside. 75cm Happy in sun or part shade with
Pretty yellow variegated leaf form of Masterwort. Collared flowers which dry excellently are white tinted green with a slight hint of pink. 75cm Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage

A recently selected large flowered dark burgundy-red masterwort. Tight clusters of burgundy flowers are surrounded by beautiful ray florets.  An interesting & beautiful plant happy in sun or part shade with some drainage. 60cm
Beautiful perennial with attractive collared flowers which dry excellently. Flowers white tinted green with a slight hint of pink. 75cm Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage

The flowers of this particular variety are notable for being large and pure white tinted green on the edge of each ray floret. The display created is both striking and long lasting. Easily grown in sun or semi shade height 60cm

Cheerful woodland perennial with flowers that comprise  a pin cushion centre surrounded with a neat ruff of  triangular petals all in a soft sugar pink. Spreading habit Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage
Beautiful perennial with attractive collared flowers which dry excellently. Flowers tinted pink in this variety. 75cm Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage
Seedling forms of this selected dark masterwort Tight clusters of tiny maroon flowers backed by a dark collar. An interesting & beautiful plant Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage

A recently selected large flowered dark red masterwort. Tight clusters of maroon flowers are surrounded by beautiful ray florets.  An interesting & beautiful plant happy in sun or part shade with some drainage
A rich dark pink form of masterwort Tight clusters of tiny pink-maroon flowers backed by a dark collar. An interesting & beautiful plant Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage. 70cm

A rich pink form of masterwort with flowers that are very flat and open Tight clusters of tiny pink-maroon flowers backed by a darker collar. An interesting & beautiful plant Happy in sun or part shade with some drainage
Pure white flowers with green tips to the bracts. Said to be an improvement on Shaggy

A really distinctive fern with a beautiful and unique silvery grey sheen; further enhanced by the maroon flush on the central fronds. A lovely fern worthy of a little care and a moist shady spot. 45cm
A red stemmed form of our native female fern. Forms a dense 'shuttle-cock' of delicate lacy fronds. Especially beautiful as the croziers unfurl. Height 45cm. Best in damp semi-shade
Tatting fern. In this fascinating variant of our native lady fern the pinnae are reduced to balls all along the length of the frond. Height 10-20cm. Best in damp semi-shade.
A form of our native female fern with fronds attractively crested. Forms dense clumps of typical fern 'shuttle-cocks'. To a height of 45cm. Best in damp semi-shade.
A really unusual form of our native female fern where the individual frond elements alternate forwards and backwards in a cross formation. Height 45cm. Best in damp semi-shade
Our native female fern. Forms a dense 'shuttle-cock' of delicate lacy fronds. Especially beautiful as the croziers unfurl. Height 45cm. Best in damp semi-shade
This variety is like var. pictum but wiith a much redder central section to the lovely silver-grey fronds. A lovely fern worthy of a little care and a moist shady spot. 45cm

A very choice fern with striking coloration. Young fronds are a pale ochre/green with maroon veining contrasting well with the blue green they assume with age A lovely fern to brighten a moist dark corner. 60cm
A tall elegant fern whose dainty fronds; which are darkened when immature; develop dark stems and veins as they age. A choice fern for a moist shady spot where it will grow to 60cm
Classic edging plant; ideal for tumbling over walls and rockeries. Flowers a good rich purple. Plant in well drained soil (neutral to alkaline) in full sun. Prune after flowering
A very refined perennial with  neat clumps of 3ft high waving stems of blue green leaves topped in June with a thin spike of deep ultramarine pea flowers. Plant in deep soil in full sun. Lime free

A little known Chinese member of the Ranunculaceae which is rarely offered. It has beautiful dark green shining orbicular leaves on long thin but stiff petioles. The leaves have substantial texture and an overlay of drak peaty-brown staining which varies

Leaves of this choice species are large- up to 30cm acrosswell rounded and covered in tiny hairs. It makes a large clump but considerably less dense than most bergenias. The flowers are pink held erect and slightly fragrant. Leaves colour red in Autumn.  Cool moist shade.

Adaptable evergreen ground cover that will cope with any reasonable position including dry sites. Large lush green leaves are apple green in summer and richly tinted in winter.  Heads of pink flowers are produced freely in spring. 30cm spreading

A large leaves species with foliage that is pale apple green rather longer than wide and lax in habit. The flowering stems are large tall and well branched arching and carrying relatively large slightly spidery drooping flowers in white

Distinctive upright leaves with a fringed edge are a apple green in summer and turn a fiery orange red in winter Mildly fragrant pure white flowers are borne in tight clusters on short stems in March. 45cm spreading.
A lovely low growing form with broad crinkley- edged leaves which colour well in winter. Flowers are semi-double in glowing claret. Spring flowering Easily grown good ground cover for any good soil
Excellent compact growing form making good evergreen ground cover in wide ranging conditions. Clear pale pink flowers in dense spikes lvs 15cm colouring well in winter. flws 30cm

Lovely neat and glossy foliage red flushed and bronze in Winter. From March to May huge densely packed heads of palest pink flowers which mature white dramatically offset by the red calyxes and stems. The flowering heads are particularly full and well

Adaptable evergreen ground cover that will cope with any reasonable position including dry sites. Large lush green leaves are apple green in summer and richly tinted in winter.  The flowers white blushed pink produced freely in spring. 30cm spreading

A good flower arrangers variety as the large leaves with their crinkly edges turn a rich purple in winter. Umbels of flowers in deep coral-pink are produced from early to late spring. 45cm. Will even tolerate dry shade under trees when established

Adaptable evergreen ground cover that will cope with any reasonable position including dry sites. Large lush green leaves are apple green in summer and richly tinted in winter.  The flowers white blushed pink produced freely in spring. 30cm spreading
A good all round Bergenia with fine stems of large flowers in a bright cherry pink. Flowers first in Feb-March and then once again in June. Any soil sun or shade. 45cm

Handsome evergreen glossy green leaves are overlaid with shades of red and copper and can turn bright scarlet on exposed sun drenched leaves. Umbels of flowers in brightest magenta are produced from early to late spring. 30cm. Will even tolerate dry shade

An early flowering hybrid between B.ciliata and B.emiensis nice narrow glossy green leaves flushed red beneath and on the serrated margins. Like B.emiensis it has beautifully poised shapely branched trusses of flowers bell shaped at first becoming fl
Excellent vigorous new cultivar whose stems and leaf margins colour a bright red all winter. The arching flower sprays come in early Spring. Any soil sun or shade.

Adaptable evergreen ground cover that will cope with any reasonable position including dry sites. Large lush green leaves are apple green in summer and richly tinted in winter.  Heads of pink flowers are produced freely in spring. 30cm spreading

The flowers on this medium sized 'elephants ears' are a real spring delight. Held in tight clusters on 30cm stems they glow a bright rich pink accentuated by the red stems and calyces and set off by the shining leaves. Easily grown good ground cover for
Handsome large leaves that turn a rich deep burgundy in Winter setting off perfectly the large heads of pure white flowers in Spring Easily grown in sun or part shade. Ht 45cm
('Winter Fairy Tale') Relatively small leaves; pointed with a slight twist; which colour well in winter especially on the reverse. Flowers dark rose. 40cm. Excellent new variety

Relatively large spiky daisies are borne in a long succession in late summer borne on thick upright stems. Requires a warm spot with adequate drainage and protection in cold winters. In some ways a very thistley daisy; Interesting rather than stunning
HARD FERN. A choice british native for moist or dry conditions where the even dark green fronds are  a constant attractive feature. Spore producing fronds  are curiously taller and more divided. 45cm
Charming dwarf borage with its summer long display of nodding sky blue bells. Especially nice scrambling through other perennials Happy in full sun where it will self seed mildly
A woodland plant of some charm from N.America. The cut leaves are always a fresh green; enhanced in summer by heads of white flowers. 30-60cm. Moist shaded spot

Wiry stems carry a wide branched head of hanging papery flowers that sway and quake in the slightest breeze. A very pretty if undestated little grass that is best siuated where the sun can catch the flowers. The only perennial quaking grass.

Pretty quaking grass with soft glaucous leaves with white edges and striping. In Summer dainty wands of little dancing lockets which sway in the breeze. Green-white at first and often tinged with pink. Not a very long lived plant but careful division can extend its life

Beautiful leaf form with large heart shaped leaves boldly bordered in white. A delicate cloud of pale blue forget-me-not flowers brings the whole plant to life in spring. Grows best in light shade. 60cm
Handsome heart-shaped leaves with a bold cream edging especially beautiful in spring with its delicate cloud of pale blue forget-me-not flowers. Grows best in light shade 45cm

Beautiful new leaf form with the handsome heart-shaped foliage completely silvered with a netting of darkened veins. A delicate cloud of pale blue forget-me-not flowers brings the whole plant to life in spring. Grows best in light shade. 60cm
Handsome deep green; heart-shaped foliage; with a ring of silver spots; lightened in spring  with a delicate cloud of pale blue forget-me-not  flowers. Grows best in light shade

Entirely silvered leaves make this new introduction a plant of great beauty and class. A delicate cloud of pale blue forget-me-not flowers brings the whole plant to life in spring. Grows best in light shade. 60cm

Handsome heart-shaped foliage completely silvered with a netting of darkened veins. A delicate cloud of pure white forget-me-not flowers brings the whole plant to life in spring. Grows best in light shade. 60cm

Very similar to ‘Jack Frost’ ebut a little whiter and has an elongated pointed tip to the leaf. Leaved are a lovely silvered with the veins picked out in green forming a dense mound in any situation that is out of direct sun
Handsome deep green; heart-shaped foliage; lightened in spring with a delicate cloud of pale blue forget-me-not flowers. Grows best in light shade
An upright column of variegated foliage topped with dense feathery plumes
A charming neat little plant which never seems to be out of flower. Much loved by bees and butterflies for the rich nectar it provides. For a sunny spot
MARSH MARIGOLD. Dark leaved form of a bright and cheery British native that thrives in any moist soil; especially at the waters edge where its stout foliage and bright buttercups look most at home.

L than the species and perhaps a little more upright with leaves that are of a fresher paler green held on pink stained petioles. The flowers which are also large are of a bright lemon yellow rather than the more chrome yellows of most varieties.  45cm. April.

MARSH MARIGOLD. A bright and cheery spring flowering kingcup that thrives in any moist soil; especially at the waters edge where its glossy foliage and bright fully double buttercups look most at home.
MARSH MARIGOLD. A bright and cheery British native that thrives in any moist soil; especially at the waters edge where its stout foliage and bright buttercups look most at home.
MARSH MARIGOLD. A bright and cheery British native that thrives in any moist soil; especially at the waters edge where its stout foliage and yellow eyed white buttercups look most at home. 12"

This is a larger form of our native Marsh Marigold bigger in all its parts and growing up to a 2ft across. Branching stems of shining golden yellow buttercups. which usually carry extra petals. Suitable for any permanently wet site including with its feet in water.
Elegant and refined with tall spires hung generously with creamy white bells enhanced by the darker calyces. A beautiful bellflower for sun or part shade so long as not too dry. 70cm

An exciting new variety of clustered bellflower carrying dense heads of tightly crowded flowers that are rich lilac-pink fading to white in the throat. A strong grower with distinctive pale olivey green foliage
One of the earliest Campanulas to flower; its stems weighed down by the weight of the dense heads of deep violet-blue flowers. Excellent for the front of border. Adaptable

The flowers of this campanula are tightly clustered in dense heads and are of the purest glistening white.. Excellent for the front of border. Adaptable and one of the earliest Campanulas to flower. 30-45cm spreading
Deep violet bells clustered around 75cm tall stems An easily grown perennial providing stout reliable clumps and a good splash of colour in early summer. Any soil including chalk
Talking point for the front of the border. Sreading stems; like a prostrate octopus; Smothered the 2nd year by 7cm; pale lilac; upward facing; inflated bells. Biennial. 45cm
Beautiful pale pink form of the milky bellflower. 5ft stems with large branching heads of flowers. Equally good in the border or naturalised in grass. Cuts well for the house
A strong coloured short growing milky bellflower. 50cm stems with large branching heads of flowers. Equally good in the border or naturalised in grass. Cuts well for the house
Tall floriferous perennials for the back of the border. 100cm stems carrying large branching heads of mauve-violet flowers in mid  to late summer

A selection of our native Giant Bellflower with flowers that are narrower than the species and of a much richer lavender-blue. As well as this they are held more horizontally on the stem rather than all hanging down. Altogether it is a little more refined
Stately perennial; for the back of the border From handsome foliage clumps rise 90cm stems hung with 6cm long tubular bells of a  rich violet blue. Good for naturalising.
The beautiful pure white form of the giant bellflower. Stout foliage clumps with tall 90cm high stems generously hung with long narrow pure white bells. naturalises well
Light green evergreen foliage forms spreading mats from which rise 3ft stems of outward facing glistening white flowers. Excellent to brighten a shady spot
3ft high stems; crowded with outward facing open cups; coloured pale pink-lilac. Evergreen foliage. Grows well on alkaline soils; sun or shade

Elegant and refined with tall spires hung generously with creamy white bells subtly striped pink and further enhanced by the darker calyces. A beautiful bellflower for sun or part shade so long as not too dry. 70cm
CANTERBURY BELL. A dwarf strain of this cottage garden favorite. 45cm Cup and saucer flowers in a good mix of colours - white; blue lilac and pink
Like a large version of a harebell Dense clumps of foliage and a succession  of sky blue bells. Height 80cm Excellent cut flower. Good on chalk
Like a large version of a harebell Dense clumps of foliage and a succession  of glistening white bells. Height 80cm Excellent cut flower. Good on chalk

A blooming good variety with large more saucer shaped flowers than the type. They are a good deep blue and have a extra set of petals giving a hose in hose effect.. Evergreen foliage. Good on chalky soils
The glistening white flowers are fully double; often tinted with green on the reverse. Lovely to lighten up a shaded spot or against darker shrubs. evergreen
A beautiful new variety Large creamy white flowers with a lilac 'picotee' edge. good on chalk Evergreen foliage. Good cut flower
A beautiful new variety Large creamy white flowers with a lilac 'picotee' edge. good on chalk Evergreen foliage. Good cut flower
A floriferous 'cup-and-saucer' form with pure white flowers; stained green at the tips Narrow evergreen foliage. Any soil; thriving particularly on chalky soils
Like a large version of a harebell Dense clumps of foliage and a succession  of sky blue bells. Height 80cm Excellent cut flower. Good on chalk
Dense clumps of foliage and a succession  of double; cup shaped flowers in mauve blue. Height 80cm Excellent cut flower. Good on chalk
This variety is distinguised by especially large flowers in a rich violet-blue Its habit is reminiscent of a large harebell Evergreen foliage. Good on chalky soils
Like a large version of a harebell Dense clumps of foliage and a succession  of sky blue bells. Height 80cm Excellent cut flower. Good on chalk

a new addition to this form of Campanula with flowers that are a hose-in-hose double. Each bell colours from a spotty lilac-pink at the base to cream at the tips so that the inner bell pokes out of the outer like petticoat. The doubling has created a sho
A dwarf hybrid with short upright candelabras; 30cm; dense with 7.5cm long inflated cream bells; heavily marked inside with maroon spots. Forms a low creeping mat of foliage.
From a low spreading foliage mat rise 45cm high candelabras hung with 7.5cm inflated bells; maroon spotted over a pink base. Best in well drained soil. good on chalk

This is the whitest of the punctata forms with broad bells in a creamy ivory white double with one bell within the other. The flowers have a covering inside of fine red spots. Spreading clumps of broad hairy heart shaped foliage
Short upright candelabras; 30-60cm; dense with 7.5cm long inflated cream bells; heavily marked inside with maroon spots. Forms a low creeping mat of foliage.
From a low spreading foliage mat rise 45cm high candelabras hung with 7.5cm inflated bells; maroon spotted over a rich pink base. Best in well drained soil. good on chalk
