From a low spreading foliage mat rise 45cm high candelabras hung with 7.5cm inflated bells; maroon spotted over a pink base. Best in well drained soil. good on chalk
Chimney Bellflower. Tall spires of tightly packed cup-shaped pure white flowers. A well grown specimen can top 5 feet tall. Was once rown to fill fireplaces in summer
Chimney Bellflower. Tall spires of tightly packed cupped flowers in either blue or white A well grown specimen can top 5 feet tall. Was grown to fill fireplaces in summer
Both leaves and flowers of this beautiful perennial bellflower are softly hairy. The flowers are large; hung on 45 cm stems the leaves a soft grey-green. Sunny spot
A form of takesimana possibly a cross with Michauxia that has pure white flowers with bells reduced to narrow spidery threads.
Recently introduced gem from Korea Spreading clumps of bronzed foliage;  surmounted in late summer by large candelabras  hung with spotted cream bells. 60cm
Handsome clumps of foliage give rise to richly clothed stems which carry a succession of  wide pure white bells all up the stems to 3' (60cm)
Handsome clumps of foliage give rise to richly clothed stems which carry a succession of  very neat and fully double deep purple bells all the way up the stems to  2' (60cm).

Double pure white form of our native nettle-leaved bellflower. Shorter than C.trachelium producing a a multi-stemmed clump 18" high. The points of the petals are curled outwards like an elf's hat. Happy in sun with moisture or semi-shade in dryer sites. Summer
Handsome clumps of foliage give rise to richly clothed stems which carry a succession of  wide blue bells all up the stems to 3' (60cm)
From a mat of heart shaped spreading foliage rise 45cm high candelabras hung with large deep rich purple inflated bells. Best in well drained soil. Even good on chalk
Possibly the darkest of the large belled C.punctata derived crosses. Deep purple bells from even richer buds over spreading folige mats. C.punctata x C.trachelium

A delightful cross between C.latifolia and C.puntata showing characteristics of both parents. The many short flowering stems  hang with long mauve bells opening from darker elongated buds. Will rebloom if cut back. 30cm spreading

Coral Root. An attractive if colonising species with 4 petalled pinky-purplish flowers. It spreads by underground tubers and by the bulbils which sit in the axils on the flowering stem. A rare British native growing in calcareous woodlands

A quite similar species to C.pentaphyllos. Flowers of this species are a satiny lilac white rather than pink and the tendency is for it to spread more.  Larger and bolder than C.quinquefolia. For a cool position in leafy soil in shade. 20-30cm

Flore Pleno is a double form with fully double lilac coloured roses. This form sets no seed but can spread by vegetative means in sufficiently moist conditions.The double form has been recorded since the 1650’s. Shorter than the species.

This is the most pristine pure white form both lovely en-masse in a meadow or as Spring companions in the border. Lovely interplanted with Lathyrus vernus or Omphalodes. Thrives in unimproved wet ground around

This one is the strongest mauve we could find bearing many spikes 15 inches (38cm) tall of bright four-petalled blossoms from April until June. Lovely interplanted with Lathyrus vernus or Omphalodes. Thrives in unimproved wet ground around

Large heads of pinky-mauve 4 petalled flowers are held well above the 5 -lobed attractive foliage from late February. Earlier than most other species. Moist humus rich soil in partial shade.Summer dormant. 20cm.
Only 12 inches high with fine bronze-brown foliage softly flowing from a low funnel shape. Benefits from combing periodically Prefers a moist soil
Long arching leaves flow out from an upright clump Their mix of green; orange and bronze tones add  evergreen interest all year. Height 18 inches Best in a moist soil or out of full sun
A very low grass forming small evergreen clumps. The bright green and gold banding brighten up shady corners; where the plant is most at home
The white form of CUPID'S DART. In summer come sheaves of thin stems; each ending in a papery white flower with a dark purple eye. The flower surrounds dry well. 2ft. sun
An easy to grow spreading cornflower with handsome deeply lobed leaves; white on the reverse and long stems topped with a bright carmine cornflower that cuts well. 60-90cm
A very refined cornflower with large lilac- pink blooms set above spreading clumps of  sea green leaves with white reverses. Place at the front of the border in full sun. 45cm
This is the knapweed found commonly in rich moist meadows. Loved by butterflies

William Robinson described this as 'A border flower of the highest Merit.' A low rosette of dark green divided foliage from which rise stiff sparsely branched stems topped by large creamy yellow shaggy pom-poms. 120cm. Reasonable adaptable but dislikes wet feet in winter
Found most commonly on calcareous soils and naturalised along railway embankments. Loved by butterflies
Giant Yellow Scabious. A lovely plant to add scale to a border without weight. Pale creamy pincushion flowers on long stalks throughout the summer. Smaller than Cephalaria gigantea
Giant Yellow Scabious. A magnificent sight in early summer with its large mound of deeply cut foliage and 6ft branching stems generously furnished with 3in pale lemon flowers
Sun loving twiggy perennial whose glory comes in September and October when the short stems; now clothed in maroon leaves; terminate in heads of royal blue flowers. 30cm
A diminutive relative of the snapdragon. Will produce a low cushion of foliage covered over a long period by a mass of blue shaded flowers. 10cm. sun and drainage

A stout Umbellifer with a distinctive colouring. The leaves are soft and hairy apple green in colour. The flowers are sugary pink in close umbels tighter than a Cow Parsley. If happy it can make a substantial clump 2ft or more in leaf alone. Best with
Very delicate looking fern for growing in dry conditions. Fronds are minutely covered in hairs giving a distinctive grey green colour to the fronds. 30cm
A lovely grass a bit like a shorter Stipa gigantea but with braoder foliage. Flowers dry extremely well for Winter decoration
Stems carpet an area 3ft round; which in Sept becomes absolutely covered in large pure white daisies that age pink. Dark glossy foliage sets off flowers well  MAY CAUSE SKIN ALLERGY
In late Oct this tight 2-3ft mound is smothered in 1in pom-poms; shaded apricot to maroon. Very welcome so late in the year. Any soil in sun. Cut to ground in winter.
Deeply quilled petals that are rich burnt-orange inside and yellow on the reverse

This Chrysanthemum puts up with wind rain and even the first frosts without becoming scruffy. It puts on a show of its single pink blooms from October until as late as December in a good year. About 60cm high and with the usual lovely Chrysanthemum scent. reliable and long-lived.
Very free flowering and hardy chrysanth. with 3in clear sugar pink flowers produced profusely from August to October. Cut to ground in Winter. Any soil. 60cm.  MAY CAUSE SKIN ALLERGY
Single but full flowers which shade from an apricot edge to a burnt orange centre. Lovely scent

Intensely magenta pink single blooms with a distinctly pale ring surrounding the bright yellow central boss. Reminiscent of a dark red Pyrethrum but flowering in October-November. About 60-70cm tall. Lovely Chrysanthemum scent.
Deep ruby-red semi-double blooms reveal a bright yellow eye attracting late flying insects. October to November. A really good intense colour
A very old; beautiful and distinctive cultivar. After the first frosts; before the flowers open in september the leaves colour a rich ruby red setting off the silvery pink quilled double flws.
Full petalled single flowers which are white with a flush of pink
Very free flowering and hardy chrysanth. with 3in soft apricot flowers produced profusely from August to October. Cut to ground in Winter. Any soil. 60cm.  MAY CAUSE SKIN ALLERGY
Very welcome in late Oct this tight 2-3ft mound is smothered in 1in pom-poms; shaded light to dark pink. Any soil in sun. Cut to ground in winter. MAY CAUSE SKIN ALLERGY

column6: 'Nantyderry Sunshine' - Early Flowering Outdoor Pompon : semi-pompon
column9: Sunshine yellow buttons at the end of the season are the mark of this variety. It flowers early in the Chrysanthemum season and forms a low 60cm bush that is absolutely covered in bright yellow fully double buttons that deepen in colour from the edge to the centre.

column6: 'Paul Boissier' - Early Flowering Outdoor Type : rubellum
column9: Paul Boissier is an Early Flowering Outdoor Type  of the rubellum type. The flowers are double in a rich shaded burnt orange

Intensely ruby-red frilly double flowers are produced in profusion from September to October. Highly rated by our friend Angela Whinfield a noted plantswoman as her absolute favourite. Nice compact and bushy habit growing about 50cm high. For sun. 60cm wide

Elegant tall stems sway in late summer with broadly branched heads of narrow creamy white bottle-brush flowers. Slug & deer proof ! Rarely needs stak Adaptable; but best with shade and a little moisture. 180cm

Beautiful stately perennial with fresh green much divided  leaves and a well branched head of creamy white  bottlebrush flowers. Slug & deer proof ! Rarely needs staking Adaptable; but best with a little shade and moisture. 180cm

Extremely handsome plant of great distinction with its deeply divided rich purple black leaves and tall waving wand of pink budded white flowers produced as late as Oct. Best with moist soil. No need to stake. Immune to slugs

Tall branching flower spikes up to 2m plus topped with generous thistle-knobs at the top. If you have the space its a great statement plant and great too for the wildlife providing nectar for insects seeds for the finches and a food plant for Painted Ladies. For a moist soil.

Broader leaves a more spreading habit and larger flower s than its cousin Cirsium rivulare. Later in the year to flower as well. In shade this plant will grow well but flower poorly. Give it plenty of moisture and sun to see it at its best.

Attractive  thistle with stout erect flowering stems generously topped with rich  red-purple thistle knobs. Easy and rewarding plant with strong architectural character. Grows best with moisture. 1m. June

A useful new addition to the range of colours available in a thistle. If you want that thistle accent in a pale scheme then the creamy white flowers of 'Frosted Magic' are just what you need. Plant with a dark leaved shrub behind to get the flowers to really stand out

A new variety that compliments its similar cousin C.rivulare 'Atropurpureum'. Whilst being superficially similar it has flowers that are bluer in hue and are carried on stems that are purple stained over white pubescence. A little stiffer and more vigorou
Choice & unusual fully herbaceous clematis with nodding deep blue bells produced generously in summer followed by very attractive silky white seed heads. Trails to approx. 60-100cm

Sophisticated herbaceous clematis whose 120 cm stems of purple foliage provide the perfect foil for the loose terminal panicles of starry white flowers. forms a small densely  packed matt. Best supported by a few twigs.

A rather special perennial which forms a good clump in well drained soil. The nodding pale china blue flowers are quite charming and if you lift the bells to peep inside the orange markings are a further delight. 2' in a sheltered spot ideally with a litt

A rather special perennial which forms a good clump in well drained soil. The nodding pale china blue flowers are quite charming and if you lift the bells to peep inside the orange markings are a further delight. 2' in a sheltered spot ideally with a litt
Charming twining climber generously hung with broad bells coloured a delightful creamy lime green. Best placed where the blooms can be upended to view the interior. 2m
A real charmer for a moist peaty soil in sun to part shade. Scrambling and twining to 2m and hung in August with creamy green bells delicately veined and netted maroon inside

Pure white flowers to 10cm tall are borne in profusion in September. Best in deep fertile warm soils that are free-draining but moist. Ideal for banks and rockeries but can be naturalized in short grass.

A species with a long history of cultivation and no certain place of origin possibly a hybrid. It shares many traits with Colchicum cilicicum. The flowers have no scent and are light pink with a prominent central white stripe. Each petal has a purple ti

Bears deep rose-lilac flowers in late summerWith barely any tessellation. It has a very noticeable white stripe down the centre of each petal which gives it a star like appearance at the base. The flowers tend to stand up to weather better than other co

Native to mountainous areas of northern Turkey and other parts of the Caucasus. Growing to 18 cm  tall by 10 cm wide. C. speciosum  produces reddish/violet flowers on stems up to 30 centimetres tall. The flowers strongly resemble those of the crocus. Flow

Native to mountainous areas of northern Turkey and other parts of the Caucasus. Growing to 18 cm  tall by 10 cm wide. C. speciosum  produces reddish/violet flowers on stems up to 30 centimetres tall. The flowers strongly resemble those of the crocus.

Large-flowering hybrid bearing violet flowers with a white throat. Flowers can reach 30cm in hight and appear in Sep-Oct. Best in deep fertile warm soils that are free-draining but moist. Ideal for front-of-border planting.

Vigorous cultivar producing up to 5 fully double pinky-lilac flowers per corm 8-10cm tall in Sep-Oct. Best in deep fertile warm soils that are free-draining but moist. Ideal for banks and rock gardens.

Vigorous cultivar producing up to 5 fully double pinky-lilac flowers per corm 8-10cm tall in Sep-Oct. Best in deep fertile warm soils that are free-draining but moist. Ideal for banks and rock gardens.
Lily-of-the-Valley with a narrow marginal highlight in yellow

Flower stalks branch a little to give more flowers to the stem and flowers themselves are broader and double so that they create a fuller effect. All together a  more 'bang for your buck' than the species but possibly at the expense of the simple elegant charm. Later into flower.

The significant difference to the species is that each leaf has the longitudinal leaf veins picked out in a bright gold which makes for a much more interesting foliage mat. A little prone to revert but green leaves can be easily removed to keep the colony pure.

Stiff little spikes hung on one side with little fragrant white bells like an old-fashioned maids bonnet. Easily grown and adaptable suited to leaving alone in difficult dry situations where it will happily carpet and provide fragrant little posies each
A bright ray of sunshine for early summer. A spreading clump former for the front of the border which will delight with a dense covering of 5cm rich yellow daisy flowers. 30cm.
Masses of cheery bright golden yellow semi-double flowers on a short stocky plant. flowers throughout spring into summer. 45cm. easy but avoid v.dry soils
Dozens of pale sugar pink daisies cover a 30cm mound of delicate dark foliage throughout the summer. Spreading clumps can be easily divided to produce more plants for the garden
In late summer a multitude of rich yellow flowers smile up from a sea of filigree green foliage. A well behaved neat bushy perennial that will flower for ages. 60cm. full sun

Prolifically produced lemon-yellow daisies on a neat bushy plant 20" (50cm) high. It is tolerant of Summer heat and makes a reliable long-lived plant which is reasonably drought tolerant.  12-18" (30-45cm) loved by bees. July-September full sun.
In late summer a multitude of rich yellow flowers smile up from a sea of filigree green foliage. A well behaved neat bushy perennial that will flower for ages. 60cm. full sun

Dozens of dusky-red daisies cover a 30cm mound of delicate dark foliage throughout the summer. A new colour break for a Coreopsis Spreading clumps can be easily divided to produce more plants for the garden
Dense heads of palest pink pea flowers with a lovely two-toned shading Makes a dense spreading mound which is a beautiful sight when covered in flowers and butterflies in summer.
Grown cheifly for it's delicate bronze and green foliage; this weed smothering beauty has the added advantage of charming spikes of yellow flowers in early Spring. 30*30cm
Mounds of delicate ferny foliage are topped off with charming spikes of light sky blue  flowers in early Spring. 30*30cm. For moisture retentive soil in shade or half shade
Mounds of delicate ferny foliage are topped off with charming spikes of sky blue  flowers in early Spring. 30*30cm. For moisture retentive soil in shade or half shade
Compact mounds of purple tinged ferny foliage are topped off with charming spikes of scented blue  flowers in early Spring. 30*30cm. For moisture retentive soil in shade or half shade
Charming and easily pleased forming dense clumps of ferny foliage covered in a mass of creamy white flowers from Spring throuygh Summer.

A newly introduced variety with the most striking yellow foliage which lights up anywhere it is planted. The flowers are a good purple. Grows best in a moist shady soil with plenty of humus incorporated. Spring flowering. 30cm

Distinguished by having flowers that age purple form a blue start earlier in the year. The foliage mounds up into a ferny bush of fresh appley-green leaves. Early Spring. 30*30cm. For moisture retentive soil in shade or half shade. Possibly more evergreen

This certainly has some Corydalis elata blood in it. The habit is fairly upright with the flowers being held high on tall stems and can come a month later than varieties such as Corydalis flexuosa ‘Pere David’. They are a rich blue in colour.  Early Sprin

Sumptuous velvety-bronze flowers on lanceolate blue-green foliage. This newly bred variety provides even more of a chocolate scent and is more compact for pot or garden culture than its predecessor 'Chocolate'. 35 x 30 cm. July-October
One of the largest and most impressive of perennials with huge glossy lvs and 8ft tall gypsophila-like cloud of scented white flws. Well drained soil. full sun. Ok for chalk

Clumps of sword like foliage send up arching spikes of lily like flowers in mid-late summer. This variety has large warm orange flowers with lovely yellow centres and grows 2' (60cm) high. They enjoy full sun and moisture retentive but well drained condit
A lovely compact Montbretia with good sized warm apricot-yellow flowers borne on shorter stems to 60cm. A rich shot of colour for the late summer garden. For sun or partr shade.
A relatively short montbretia (40cm) with crimson starry flowers with yellow centre. Good clump forming variety. Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage

Clumps of sword like foliage send up arching spikes of lily like flowers in mid-late summer. This variety has large warm orange flowers with lovely yellow centres and grows 2' (60cm) high. They enjoy full sun and moisture retentive but well drained condit
A relatively short montbretia (55cm) with deep bronze leaves. Dark orange flowers with brown markings are produced in high summer. Sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage

column9: A relatively short montbretia (35cm) with large flat flowers; bright golden orange with deeper red markings towards the throat Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage
A relatively short montbretia (40cm) with yellow starry flowers which are orange in bud. Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage
A relatively short montbretia (60cm) with long arching sprays of rich orange flowers. Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage

Named after Lord Nelson's lover. Similar in colouring to C.'Buttercup' with the main difference being the red calyces and coloured stems. The spikes are very upright and tightly packed with outward facing blooms in a rich warm yellow enhanced by the red calyces and apricot buds. 60cm
A large and startling montbretia. The foliage is tall and broad; the flowers a vivid glowing red; produced freely in late summer. Best in sun; or part shade; with some moisture. 120cm.
A relatively short montbretia (60cm) with deep  red starry flowers which are yellow in the throat. Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage
One of the shorter montbretia (50-70cm) with good sized outward facing flowers in a rich warm yellow produced in great profusion. Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage
One of the shorter montbretia (50-70cm) with smaller flowers in a two tone red and warm yellow produced in great profusion. Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage
A relatively short montbretia (55cm) with deep bronze leaves. Rich red flowers are produced on cobra like flowering stems in high summer. Sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage

Medium height. Flowers are held in a slightly arching way in well spaced spikes 4cm across in the warmest of rich egg yolk yellows with a richer reverse. Apricot tint to the buds and fading flowers. Leaves are a dusky olive green verging on bronzy brown. 80cm

An exceptionally large flowered form with dainty broad petal led flowers of soft apricot yellow paler in the throat. Beautifully contrasted with the red tinted buds and outer tips of the petals. Happy in most situations except excessive wet in sun or par

column9: A relatively short montbretia (40cm) with flowers in a two tone red and warm yellow.. Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage
Tall broad leaved variety of Montbretia with a spreading habit. Flowers are a rich deep sunshine yellow in a broad arching head
Long spikes of closely packed flowers in a deep flame orange. medium sized at 50cm tall Rich summer colour to bring a tropical feel. Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage

A tall branching variety with arching flower spikes. The flowers alternate rearing up from the spike with gaping mouths like little birds craving a feed. Each one is a narrow arching horn scarlet on the outside orange within. Similar to C.'Emberglow' more orange less red. 90cm
Clumps of sword like foliage give rise to arching stems bedecked with large lily-like burned orange flowers. To 3' (60cm). Hot sunny spot; moist but with good winter drainage

Huge flowers up to 5cm across with wide spaced flared lobes face straight up from a gently arching flower spike. The stamens are  very prominent standing high and proud. In colour the flowers are a luminous orange deepening to red at the edges and around the yellow throat. 60cm
A large and startling montbretia. The foliage is tall and broad; the flowers a vivid glowing red; produced freely in late summer. Best in sun; or part shade; with some moisture. 120cm.

A brand new introduction the results of an extensive breeding program. Large flowers of a glowing soft apricot marked with a darker orange stripe. A vigorous clone with a long flowering period. 115cm. July-Oct

A pretty delicate umbellifer with handsome purple foliage. In summer it sends up many fine purple stems carrying panicles of  myriads of tiny white flowers. For moisture retentive soil in dappled shade. 2' (60cm)

Cyclamen coum is the other cyclamen commonly grown out of doors in Britain. It is a little fussier than Cyclamen hederifolium but essentially requires quick drainage good winter light with a little shade in the hottest part of the day
Cyclamen hederifolium heralds the onset of Autumn when its charming white reflexed flowers push their way above ground in late August.
Cyclamen hederifolium heralds the onset of Autumn when its charming pink or white reflexed flowers push their way above ground in late August.
A magnificent architectural plant for a large space. An 8ft fountain of deeply divided silver grey leaves topped off with massive bue thistles. Enjoys a sunny site not too wet at the roots.

Attractive dainty Hounds tongue with  arching sprays of pale rose pink flowers like  little forget-me-nots. Good for mixing amongst  short early flowering perennials. 60cm
Perennial Hound's Tongue. The grey-green leaves appear early and are soon followed by flowers of the intensest royal blue. 30-60cm

Curiously attractive Hounds toungue with dense  heads of deep red flowers with an odd biscuity aroma. Biennial with attractive finely felted leaves produced in the first year. Seeds easily but not excessively.  60cm

A bit like a multi-headed waxy daffodil with long tubular flowers is this bulbous perennial from South Africa. It forms dense colonies of evergreen glossy strap like foliage producing flowers throughout Spring. It is just hardy if grown in a sunny well drained spot. 30cm
Japanese Holly fern. A most distinct fern with dark glossy fronds that are only once divided. Makes a most effective contrast to other more lacy ferns. Moist soil; sunless position. 60cm

All through the summer months the fresh green broad circular leaves make a bold dense clump before turning lovely scarlet in Autumn. The spring sees large round heads of pink stained flowers rise 3ft high like drumsticks sprouting from the soil. For moi

A tough grass which produces dense hummocks of narrow rough foliage topped by a fine airy cloud of gently swaying flower stems which last well in to the winter.
Lovely old fashioned garden pink with heavily scented blooms. Colouring is an even rich pink Semi double.

>A different colour form of this lovely hardy Diascia. It differs from the species in that the flower spikes are a lot less branched with the flowers held in quite tight short spikes. The colour is a soft orange-scarlet. A little shorter than the pink species also.
Robust 90cm stiff stems densely clothed in lance shaped fresh green foliage. Copious dusky pink flowers with darker markings are produced in terminal racemes from May until the frosts

Apple green ferny foliage emerges from a rhizomatous spreading rootstock making lovely ground cover for woodland conditions. Over this you get multi-flowered nodding panicles of pure white hanging lockets. Best in partial shade.
Fast growing clumps of deeply cut blue-grey leaves topped in spring with pendant pale pink blooms. leaves and flowers last best if given dappled shade

A charming dainty climbing relative of the Bleeding Heart. Climbing by means of tendrils the delicate foliage scrambles through any support producing in Summer through Autumn bunches of dangling yellow lockets. 6ft. Himalayas
The beautiful Bleeding Heart or Lady-in-the-Bath Fresh green ferny foliage above which arch stems dripping pink & white flowers like dewdrops. A picture of poise and grace. 3ft

Excellent spreading ground cover with elegant mid green deeply cut leaves and deep ruby hanging flowers. Height 15cm. Can flower for up to 5 months in the year

Compact and luxurious glaucous blue ferny foliage which forms sumptuous mounds 20cm high. More heat tolerant than the original D.eximia cultivars Multitudes of beautiful dark rosy pink ‘bleeding hearts’ with a prettily reflexed pale edge
Deeply cut blue-green leaves spread to form a lush carpet above which bob the pink stained ivory flowers. Charming and easily grown especially good in dappled shade. 30cm.

Early in Spring finely divided juicy fern-like leaves emerge relatively green for a creeping Dicentra. Nodding stems with clustered hanging lockets in shades of mauvey-pink. Best in moisture retentive soil ideally in some shade to prolong flowering.
Slow to grow but well worth a  wait with beautiful pure white blooms on upright stems. Seeds produce a volatile oil which can ignite spontaneously. OILS MAY CAUSE SKIN IRRITATION

Pure white flowers with very long exerted stamens giving an exotic effect borne on upright stems above glossy aromatic foliage.It is possible to ignite the vapour on a hot still Summer day. Slow growing plant taking its time to establish. 60-90cm. For a very dry sunny position
Salmon red bells dance gracefully in the breeze; suspended on threads from an arched stem. 40-60cm. Summer. Elegant; grassy; evergreen foliage
Angel's fishing rods. White bells dance gracefully in the breeze; suspended on threads from an arched stem. 5ft. Summer. Elegant; grassy; evergreen foliage
Beautiful new variety whose flowers are sumptuous rich dark purple bells dancing gracefully on arched stem. 5ft. Summer. Elegant grassy evergreen foliage. Likes full sun in a moisture retentive soil.
Pale pink bells dance gracefully in the breeze; suspended on threads from an arched stem. 5ft. Summer. Elegant; grassy; evergreen foliage

Long arching 'fishing rods' carry beautiful pendulous bells which sway in the breeze above tough narrow grass-like foliage. As the name suggests the bells are deep maroon. The wands of flowers are tall and strong up to 3 feet high but never need staking. July to August.

Long arching 'fishing rods' carry beautiful pendulous bells which sway in the breeze above tough narrow grass-like foliage. As the name suggests the bells are deep maroon. The wands of flowers are tall and strong up to 3 feet high but never need staking. July to August.

Beautiful new variety whose flowers are gorgeous lavender blushed white bells dancing gracefully on arched stem. 5ft. Summer. Elegant grassy evergreen foliage. Likes full sun in a moisture retentive soil.

A new hybrid Angel's Fishing Rod which is easy to grow in soil which is well drained but not dry. Arching stems to 1.3m (4') carrying pendulous clusters of pink flowers are produced from July to August. A good vigorous form which produces lots of flowers.
A new hybrid Angel's Fishing Rod which is easy to grow in soil which is well drained but not dry. Arching stems to 1.3m (4') carrying flowers that look up and out more than they hang down
Shaped like our native foxglove; but shorter; fully perennial and coloured a soft yellow; netted inside with brown. Very attractive. Sun/part shade  CAUTION- TOXIC IF EATEN

Immaculate evergreen glossy rosettes of long narrow dark green leaves.The flowers spikes are tall stiff and densely crowded with charming ochre yellow-lipped flowers. More yellow than the species. 4ft CAUTION- TOXIC IF EATEN
Imaculate evergreen glossy rosettes are a feature all year. The flowers spikes are densely crowded with charming yellow; lipped flowers. 4ft  CAUTION- TOXIC IF EATEN

Close spikes of rounded flowers; cream lipped with a rich ochre outside colouring orange near the throat. 45cm. Combines the best of parents. Light shade  CAUTION- TOXIC IF EATEN
One of the more unusual perennial foxgloves. The flowers are very rounded white with dense brown netting and a broad white lip. Light shade 60 cm  CAUTION- TOXIC IF EATEN

Thin spikes densely crowded with small bronze-red foxglove flowers make for a striking addition to any planting. 60 cm high July to September
Long straight spikes of tightly packed flowers; pure unspotted white; limey green in the throat. A plant of great distinction. Very good in woodland situations  CAUTION- TOXIC IF EATEN

A charming cottage garden plant with slender spikes of small strawberry pink foxglove flowers which are pale yellow inside. Long flowering season. Evergreen foliage
A beatiful new foxglove with almost tropical looking trumpets the colour of crushed strawberries. Inside the throats are yellowy cream edged strawberyy with spots of the same colour.

A new variety with much to recommend it. The flower spikes are long and narrow carrying flowers that open rich yellows form green buds. Each flower is warm sunshine yellow stained on the outside with cinnamon and spotted on the lip the same. Repeat flowe

A native of the heathlands and forests of New South Wales. It produces a dense tuft of Iris-like leaves above which are held beautiful pure white flowers that really do look at you. A charming and slightly scented treat for somewhere sunny with reasonable drainage.  30cm
Evergreen Solomon's Seal. A relative of the solomon's seal this spreading perennial has dark green leaves and hanging flared bells that have a lemon scent. A graceful plant for shade. 60cm
A particularly striking and sophisticated Disporum with leaves that can be as dark as night. Flowers hang in loose terminal heads pale creamy green. 3ft

A relatively short Disporum with classy arching wands clothed in sessile (unstalked) green grey and white boldly striped leaves. In late Spring the upper leaf axils carry special crem green and white tubular bells. Eventually forming clumps with many stems.

Creeping rhizome with fairly upright stems which have arching lateral branches thickly clothed in glossy lanceolate leaves. In May and June the upper leaf axils carry clusters of green tipped cream nodding bells followed by black berries.Sun or semi shade in moisture retentive soil.
A less usually seen form of shooting star. A relative of the Primulas For a cool moist spot.

Shooting Stars. The flowers on this relative of the Primulas have deeply reflexed petals all swept back in the manner of a cyclamen. The petals are pink and the centre of the flower is like a black yellow and white dart. For a cool moist spot.

A great asset as the bright yellow daisies are carried so early in the year bringing a little ray of sunshine into March. Best grown in a moisture retentive but drained soil with a little shade from the strongest summer sun. 30-60cm
Crowded heads of deep royal blue flowers rise above a neat mound of rounded sagey foliage. A charming tidy splash of blue for a well drained spot in full sun. 30cm
A magnificent form of the golden-scaled male fern. Will tolerate wide ranging conditions including dry shade; but prefers a moist soil. Semi evergreen fronds make a clump 100cm*100cm

An excellent fern for situations in deep shade where it will form a  large mound of rich emerald green foliage. Emergent fronds clothed in beautiful black scales. It will adapt to conditions from moist to quite dry. 45-60cm

Broad Buckler Fern. A beautiful form of a british native fern with large broad spreading fronds intricately congested and wavy up to 120cm long. Very good for naturalising in woodlands and near water. Best with a little moisture in the soil.
Broad Buckler Fern. A British native fern with large broad spreading fronds of triangular outline up to 120cm long. Very good for naturalising in woodlands and near water.
A real treasure; the bold fronds emerging coppery in tint; later turning a rich glossy green; decorated on the reverse with red spores. 60cm. tolerates dry when established

A popular crested form of our native male fern with fronds that are prettily ruffled around the edges. Adapts to most soils; tolerating very dry soils quite well. Evergreen if sheltered. 45cm high and wide

A form of our native male fern with fronds that are cut almost down to threads giving a fine cloudy appearance. Adapts to most soils; tolerating very dry soils quite well. Evergreen if sheltered. 60cm high and wide

Deciduous fern with leaves that are very deeply divided and triangular in outline. Leaves can achieve 90-120cm in length in ideal cool moist conditions. Leaves yellow tinted at first ageing pale green. 90cm

A lovely species form Taiwan. The leaves have a very even glossy appearance and appear in spring in glorious coppery tints. Similar to erythrosora but with narrower fronds with tighter leaflets. Medium size

Oddly shaped fronds that mark it out as quite distinct from any other Dryopteris. The leaves have a leathery quality with 2-5 pairs of broad pinnae and a long pointed terminal pinnule.  It requires adequate moisture and a sheltered position as it is not bone-hardy in every Winter
A beautiful majestic fern with fronds to 2m under ideal moist conditions. The lovely evenly divided  fronds emerge attractively tinted raw sienna Deciduous and requiring a sheltered spot

Deep green leafy clumps set off handsome large white daisies; the centre of each a  spiky green cone brightened with orange tips 100cm. Best in sun in a rich soil

Deep green leafy clumps set off handsome large deep pink daisies; the centre of each a spiky green cone brightened with orange tips This variety has particularly good flat flowers. 90cm. Best in sun in a rich soil
An excellent selection having large flat flowers of excellent form and a rich pink colouring. 85cm Scented. AGM
Vivid pink with a fully double tight bun centre surrounded by a horizontal rim of ray florets. The bun centre is accentuated by a darker eye.

Strong tall stems carry enormous blooms fit for a show girl. A rich shaggy pom pom in deep rosy pink sits atop a hanging skirt of pink ray petals. Flowers fade from a deep orangey-pink to a cooling guava.

Aptly named as the flowers are a gorgeous rich warm tomato red. The petals reflex from a dark central cone held upright on 80cm stems. A bushy variety with an excellent constitution and winter hardiness.
