column9: The pure white form of Rose Bay Willowherb. It can spread but it is less stout with the most lovely pure white flowers that add a startling backdrop to a planting scheme. Less vigorous than its pink cousin and well worth growing.
Lovely creamy white flowers clustered on 15cm stems. Good to flop at the edge of a border. Take cuttings as insurance through the winter. Non seeding

Long arching flower spikes that can carry up to 50 tiny flowers. Not as showy as some of its cousins but lovely with the cloud of small stars abundantly produced over neat foliage. Each flower has a starry arrangement of white sepals with a small central nose of yellow petals

Here's something quite different with flowers of a very atypical shape each one a small hanging bell formed mainly of the petals with the sepals reduced enormously. The flowers are carried 15-40 to the stem in an open upright pyramidal inflorescence.

Easy to grow and highly attractive ground cover. 50cm; spreading. Leaves are an asset all year; opening with red netting; colouring rich russet in autumn and remaining all winter. A tall species with upright stems carrying many delicate orange flowers

Flowers are a wide spidery cross in an almost translucent pale lemon yellow. The leaves however are something to behold being large with three arrow shaped leaflets apple green with a gorgeous variable overlay of maroon blotching.

Startling fat goblet shaped flowers of brightest yellow with yellow horns. The sepals are reduced to a little fleck of rusty red which is picked up by the dark red of the new leaves. The flowers are 1 1/4 inches but the 'tube' is flared to make the goblet shaped centre.

A deeply contrasting flower combination of white sepals and rich mahogany petals that really stand out. In the wild it grows in half shade along the edges of woods and close to streams. It is a fairly vigorous runner and flowers to a height of about 15cm

This is a selected form collected by Mikinori Ogisu and later given a cultivar name. Flowers are pink on the inner sepals and purple in the petals. In other respects like the species. Leaves are long arrow-shaped and a beautiful pinky bronze when young remaining red blotched when older.

Elegant sprays of pendulous white and violet deeply reflexed flowers reminiscent of a stellar pelargonium. The leaves are in 3 leaflets long arrow-shaped and a beautiful pinky bronze when young remaining irregularly red blotched when older.

New leaves are just the most lovely shades of crimson providing the perfect foil for the bright lemon yellow flowers. It doesn't sound special when written down but there is just something about the way that the leaves glow that is so right. Flowers are a strong lemony yellow

Long spurred brilliant snow-white flowers. The name refers to the pale yellowy green leaves and the slowly spreading rhizomatous growth habit. The new leaves as they emerge have an elegant well-defined mahogany rim with red freckles.

Clump forming ground cover plant forming  a mass of wiry stems which support bright green oval leaves. In spring lots of lavender violet flowers are produced which resemble sprays of minature daffodils. Shade or partial shade even under trees when establi

Flowers have petals that curve downwards in a shade of pale translucent yellow in a  compound pyramidal inflorescences of up to 30 flowers. The leaves are apple green paler at first developing an overlay of red blotching. Long and narrow with a quite spiky margin

A lovely plant that will add charm to any woodland planting performing well in most shady spots including quite dry areas. Clumps of pointed leaves will spread gradually making good ground cover. Trim off old leaves in early spring to reveal the tightl

The flowers are tiny but  made up for by the profusion in which they are produced - a cloud of tiny starry white butterflies. Stems and buds are black making a good contrast. Leaves are relatively large and emerge in a fabulous bright green heavily overlaid with deep burgundy-red

Relatively recent introduction collected in 1993 by the great Mikinori Ogisu. Epimedium ogisui is a beautiful pure white species quite close to Epimedium latisepalum from which it differs in small leaf details. The flowers are an essay in purity

One of the smaller epimedium species forming spreading dense clumps of pointed foliage with dainty sprays of translucent pink flowers nodding over the foliage in spring. Height 15cm flowering to 30cm. For moist leafy soil in partial shade.

Beautiful evergreen ground cover. The leaves open an attractive pale green; contrasting well with the last years foliage. Flowers are like strings of glowing small yellow daffodils. 45cm. Easily grown

Beautiful spreading evergreen ground cover. The leaves open an attractive pale green; contrasting well with the last years foliage. Flowers are like upright spikes of glowing sunshine yellow daffodils. 45cm. Easily grown in any good soil

Evergreen species with more rounded leaves than most growing to 45cm. Flowers yellowish-white with the inner sepals sometimes pale pink. The flowers are relatively small and held high above the foliage. One of the parents of Epimedium x cantabrigiense.

Exceptionally wide flattish flowers. The sepals are reduced to a small white cross 1cm across which backs the yellow petals which themselves are long and curved. The foliage is claret at first later becoming green and developing purplish and coppery mo

30cm; spreading. Leaves are an asset all year; opening with red netting; colouring rich russet in autumn and remaining all winter. small deep red flowers in spring. Said to be a stronger coloured form

Easy to grow and highly attractive ground cover. 30cm; spreading. Leaves are an asset all year; opening with red netting; colouring rich russet in autumn and remaining all winter. small deep red flowers in spring

Elongated leaflets whose edges are corrugated and tipped with irregular spines pointing in all directions like Jaws himself. Young leaves are an iridescent metallic bronze pink maturing apple green and evergreen. The flowers are large 4cm pale lemon richer coloured at the centre.

The form collected in by Roy Lancaster on the Wudang Shan mountain in China where it grew in and amongst rocky crevices. The sepals are long and white the petals small and yellow making small white stars produced in chaotic abundance creating a white cloud. spreading
The form of this species most grown in Britain. Originally collected by Roy Lancaster

Easy to grow and highly attractive ground cover. 30cm; spreading. Highly ornamental evergreen foliage emerges pale green; netted with russet veining; complimenting the sprays of pale sulphur yellow blooms.
column13: E\Epimedium x versicolor Sulphureum lvs large.jpg

column9: Easy to grow and highly attractive ground cover. 50cm; spreading. Leaves are an asset all year; opening with red netting; colouring rich russet in autumn and remaining all winter. A tall species with upright stems carrying many delicate orange flowers

The flowers remind us of an upside down quoit board in pale lemony yellow  borne on long pedicels hanging below a long arching dark stem like so many spiders. The foliage is long and narrow sparsely undulating with a spiny edge an ethereal pastel ochre when young

A hybrid possibly of wild origin forming small spreading dense clumps of pointed foliage with dainty sprays. Flowers pink shading to white nodding over the foliage in spring. Height 15cm flowering to 30cm. Very hardy for moist leafy soil in partial

A hybrid possibly of wild origin forming small spreading dense clumps of pointed foliage with dainty sprays of pure white flowers nodding over the foliage in spring. Height 15cm flowering to 30cm. Very hardy for moist leafy soil in partial shade.

A hybrid possibly of wild origin forming small spreading dense clumps of pointed foliage with dainty sprays of pale pink flowers nodding over the foliage in spring. Height 15cm flowering to 30cm. Very hardy for moist leafy soil in partial shade.

Lots of small apple green leaves which retain a red edge from their initial red flush. The flowers are produced profusely in a lovely shade of pearly lilac. The sepals are very prominent shaded pink and lending the flower an almost double appearance.
Magnificent vigorous Epimedium with lovely red spotted new leaves and tall spikes generously hung with dozens of red-mouthed amber flowers. For a nice humus rich moist soil in partial shade.

Flowers are shaped like a swept back Jester's hat speckled orange at the centre and very tip paling to parchment on the arms. Long spiny edged leaves richly mottled in mahogany and green. A cross between wushanense and rhizomatosum. Very similar to Epimedium 'Bieke'

Llarge and well rounded leaves turning fiery red or dark smoky purple black for winter. The flowers are held well above the foliage on tall upright stems. the flower form is well rounded made up mostly of the rounded sepals in pale lemon ochre overlaid with red stripes

A lovely introduction from Elizabeth Strangman with flowers in a gentle soft pink very much like its parent E.leptorrhizum. However each flower is neater and smaller and held in an elegant arching spray. The leaves can colour a rich ruby red in winter.

Well named as the flowers are of just that mix of pale yellow with a tinge of green that characterises that most noxious of elements. However there the similarity ends as the rest of this plant is lovely. Arching spike with each berberis like flower hanging most gracefully

The flowers are generous insize and number each topped by off white sepals under which curve petals of dunked rich tea biscuit brown to flesh coloured. Young leaves are suffused with a rich tan and they colour a lovely pinky-red in Autumn still with the darker red speckles

Flowers appear richly coloured in heavy sprays. The sepals are small and lilac under which curve much larger petal 'claws' deep purple fading to near white at the tips. New leaves are a fresh apple green staining orangey red towards the margins and then splashed in rich burgundy

The sepals are arched and slightly irregularly arranged over the petals and have a charming slightly flicked up appearance. They are richly suffused with purple flecks. The petals are ruby pink with paler spurs which sits very nicely with the bronzy new leaves.

Spectacular perennials for a warm spot in well drained soil. Tall poker like stems are topped with crowded foxtail heads of small lily flowers. Mixed colours through red pink and yellow. The lax clumps of bluish strap like leaves die away from mid summer

This is that sweet little candy and white daisy you see clinging for dear life from stone walls and amongst paving.The flowers begin a ruddy pink soon fading to pure white. carried on long stalks they make a lovely colourful daisy cloud softening the ed
Rewarding yet undemanding perennial producing a profusion of aster-like blooms throughout the summer. Avoid soils that lie wet in winter. 50cm. Lavender flowers
A taller; large-flowered form of this cheerful rewarding perennial. Large blue flowers are produced in profusion throughout summer. Aviod wet soils. cut back for 2nd flws
Rewarding yet undemanding perennial producing a profusion of aster-like blooms throughout the summer. Avoid soils that lie wet in winter. 50cm. Lilac rose flowers

Delicately divided grey leaves which are topped almost continuously with good sized 3.5cm mauvey pink flowers which are reminiscent of Pelargonium flowers. Each one is delicately picked out with darker pink veins and a burgundy blotch. It would enjoy a sunny and well-drained position

Tall imposing eryngium growing up to 2m tall. Long spiny-toothed leaves. Stiff strong flower spikes appear in summer well above the leaves and carry bunches of white thisle like flowers. For well drained  but not dry soil

A selected variety of an already highly desirable sea holly with an exquisitely lacy frill of steely blue bracts around a central bristly cone. One of the largest flowering and best coloured eryngiums. Good drainage. 60cm

Rosettes of deeply cut crisp curly grey-green leaves with silver veins give rise to branching spikes of blue-green thistles with blue spiky bracts. A beautiful plant all year 60cm (2ft) high which needs well drained soil in full sun.
column13: E\Eryngium bourgattii Graham Stuart Thomas Selected #2.jpg
column16: E\Eryngium bourgattii Graham Stuart Thomas Selected #1.jpg

column9: Rosettes of deeply cut crisp curly grey-green leaves with silver veins give rise to branching spikes of blue-green thistles with blue spiky bracts. A beautiful plant all year 60cm (2ft) high which needs well drained soil in full sun.
Miss Willmotts Ghost. Wide branching heads of silver white cones surrounded by large silver bracts. A marvellous architectural plant and an eery presence in the half light

An exceptional sea holly adorned in mid-late summer with large collared heads of brilliant steely blue further enhanced by the beautiful blue hue of the stems. 60cm. Sun and good drainage. Much loved by bees.

Bold architectural and takes no prisoners. The foliage is a narrow 2cm wide and forms a dense grassy fountain. The flowering spike can rise 2.5m high or more branched all the way up like a small tree to form a cylindrical cage of small deep maroon cones. 2-4m. Hardy to -10C

An impressive large sea holly with tall much branching spikes of purplish cone shaped flowers to 1.5 up to 4m (4-12ft). Handsome sword shaped spiky evergreen foliage. For any good rich (even wet) soil in full sun.
Sea holly. Spiky flower heads in shades of steely metallic blue. Loved by bees and butterflies as a nectar source. Good for drying for winter arrangements. well drained site in full sun.
This variety of sea holly is distinguished by its rich violet flowers and bracts and by its dwarf habit to 60cm. Spiky flower heads are good for drying. well drained site
Sea holly. Spiky flower heads in shades of steely metallic blue. Loved by bees and butterflies as a nectar source. Enhanced by the white and pink variegated foliage. well drained site in full sun.
Sea holly. Spiky flower heads in shades of steely metallic blue. Loved by bees and butterflies as a nectar source. Good for drying for winter arrangements. well drained site in full sun.
This plant is the Mexican representative of a related group of Sea Hollies all of which have long spine-edged strap-like leaves. Can grow up to 80cm tall with large heads which are quite distinctive.
A relatively short sea holly; to 60cm; with well branched flowering stems carrying a dense mass of spiky flower heads that age silver and blue. Good drying flower. Sun
Glossy evergreen leaves with startling white veins in A tight ground hugging rosette. Each cone of tiny flowers is surrounded by spiny silver-white bracts. Excellent for drying. 45cm

A Dutch hybrid and one of the best of the crosses made between E.alpinum and E.bourgatii. It is vigorous in growth and has large long-lasting heads of a bright metallic blue. Likes a position in full sun in not too rich a soil and not too wet. 75cm

A beautiful hybrid between E. alpinum and E. bourgatii. 60-75cm (2-2.5ft) high with large silvery / steely blue collars attractively cut but less frilly than in E. alpinum.The flowers which are loved by bees are produced  July-August
Electric Blue very finely frilly collars surround cone shaped flowers atop deep violet stems to 60cm
Small shrub with grey green leaves and a profusion of spikes of mauve purple flowers produced in spring. Flowers best in full sun and a well drained position
Small shrub with grey green leaves and a profusion of spikes of bright yellow flowers produced in spring. Flowers best in full sun and a well drained position
Perennial Wallflower. Sturdy; bushy small shrub with grey green leaves and compact spikes of highly scented sunshine yellow flowers. Buds streaked red. 45cm
Perennial Wallflower. Dense; bushy small shrub with narrow blue green leaves. Flowers open yellow/orange and fade pink/purple. Tall flower spikes produced over a long season
Perennial Wallflower. Dense bushy small shrub with narrow blue green leaves. Flowers open yellow/orange and fade pink/purple. Flower spikes produced over a long season
A neat tight bun; covered in spring in dense heads of bright lemon flowers that open from dark buds and fade gradually. Perennial wallflower; 15cm. Good scent
Perennial Wallflower. Small shrub with Dark green toothed leaves and a slightly lax growth habit. Scented flowers open reddy-orange and fade to a dark magenta purple. 45cm
Striking in flower as each bloom opens palest lemon ageing to a rich violet in a most pleasant way.
Small shrub with variegated leaves and a profusion of spikes of bright yellow flowers produced in spring from red buds. Flowers best in full sun and a well drained position

Compact pineapple lily with dwarf apple green strap-like leaves with nice rippled edge. In July short spikes crowded with pure white starry flowers are produced each spike topped with an apple green tufty top knot. The display last extremely well into September. 14" Southern Africa.

Useful late flowering plants for the summer border. Tall sturdy stems to 5' (160cm) carry whorls of rich green foliage which tinge bronze to set off broad airy clusters of white flowers - irresistible to butterflies. Equally at home in the border or wild

A really big bold statement of a plant for the back of large borders. Great clouds of ivory coloured almost white soft fluffy flowers sway on grey green stems which are richly clad in handsome whorls of fresh green foliage. 2m and irresistible to insects. Flowering from Juy-September

This lovely perennial makes a stout leafy statement at the back of the border or water's edge. Come July it is topped with great dense domed bunches of dusty pink flowers 12-18 inches across nicely set off by the red petioles

Useful late flowering plants for the summer border. Tall purple flecked stems to 5' (160cm) carry whorls of purple tinted foliage and are topped by broad airy clusters of dark pink flowers which are irresistible to butterflies. Equally at home in the bord

Useful late flowering plants for the summer border. Tall purple flecked stems to 5' (160cm) carry whorls of purple tinted foliage and are topped by broad airy clusters of dark pink flowers which are irresistible to butterflies. Equally at home in the bord
Year round interest from rich deep maroon evergreen foliage with lighter burgundy new growth Topped in spring with bright yellow/green flws HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT
Excellent groud cover; even for dry shade. Dark glossy rosettes. The flowers in spring are a glowing limey green; drying russet. Cut/dried flw. HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT
Evergreen shrub for a sunny spot. Each stem produces in spring an impressive cylinder of red eyed green flowers. cut out old flower stems HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT

All parts of this plant are attractively variegated white. Short rounded evergreen shrub for a sunny spot. Each stem produces in spring an impressive cylinder of yellow flowers. 1m.  HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT
Short rounded evergreen shrub for a sunny spot. Each stem produces in spring an impressive cylinder of yellow flowers. 1m. cut out old flower stems HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT
A beautiful tidy Euphorbia with year long appeal. Prominent white veins and a red edge to the leaves and broad rounded heads of a warm bright yellow. 90cm. non spreading
Pretty little Euphorbia with deep red new growth which fades a deep sea green; the perfect foil for the bright acid yellow flowers produced in profusion in spring. any soil. will run.

A delight in all seasons from the moment the new growth emerges in dark tones of pink through the deep purple flowers of summer to the dazzling red autumn colour. A dense spreading hummock to 30cm tall.

New leaves are heavily margined in burgundy with a pink flush to the midrib and outer leaf. This is all over a marbled green base. By the time the plant comes to flower the colouring fades to just the edge but in early season the effect is lovely.HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT
Richly tinted leaves enhance beautifully the bright orange long lasting 'flowers'. Will make a lovely clump if left to spread in a rich soil in full sun. HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT
Bright fiery orange bracts give a long lasting display; set off by the tinted leaves and stems. Spreads freely to 3ft high and as much wide. Best in sun  HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT
Natural hybrid of E.characias & E.amygdaloides Recommended by its compact growth; red stems and dense cylindrical heads of green flowers An excellent sub-shrub for a warm spot. 60cm
A small spurge whose trailing stems of grey  leaves terminate in a tight yellow head each spring.  Excellent in a dry spot such as in a wall. 2ft spread Harmful if eaten. SKIN / EYE IRRITANT
A species valued for its very broad yellow flower heads which are produced in long succession from summer well into winter. 90cm. HARMFUL IF EATEN. SKIN/EYE IRRITANT

15-30cm hairy-leaved stems which build to an intense show of terminal yellow bracted flowers like a little globe of sunlight. Cut back as flowers fade.White varietgated foliage which is tinged pink in spring. 2ft. Harmful if eaten. SKIN / EYE IRRITANT. Best in a drier sunny spot.

Each spring from a small shrubby base comes an intense show of yellow bracted flowers like a  little globe of sunlight. cut back as flowers fade. 'Purpurea' shows purple tinged foliage in spring.  2ft. Harmful if eaten. SKIN / EYE IRRITANT
Each spring from a small shrubby base comes an intense show of yellow bracted flowers like a  little globe of sunlight. cut back as flowers fade. 2ft. Harmful if eaten. SKIN / EYE IRRITANT
A beautiful tidy Euphorbia with year long appeal. Shoots emerge with a lovely pale ochre tint and the broad generous heads of yellow and lime flowers are a joy all summer. 90cm. mildly spreading
A newly introduced Euphorbia recommended by its compact growth; red stems and dense cylindrical heads of green flowers An excellent sub-shrub for a warm spot. 60cm
An improved hybrid from E.amydaloides. Enjoys a warm position with good drainage in teh winter.  60cm
Euphorbia Kalipso is a particularly compact and dense little bush. When in flower it will be completely smothered in green flowers so no foliage at all is visible. 40cm
A spiky grass with fine blue foliage and very dainty seed heads held well above the foliage Grow in full sun Best when clipped over in spring

Mahogany buds opening to neatly shaped bright glossy orange flowers. Each one has a darker mat orange central disc and a strong coloured orange boss of stamens. As the flowers age the petals spread and the central disc becomes more prominent whilst the

erfect heart-shaped shiny black leaves that show through green patches if you hold them up to the light. They are a perfect backing for the big bold blunt ended glossy celandine flowers that shine out so brightly in the cold late Winter.

An anemone centred celandine . Bright golden yellow with widely spaced rounded petals around a tight central boss of curved petaloid stamens. The leaves are a joy for they are variously marbled and splashed with green black and pewter.

Near black foliage contrasts heavily with the dark green stems carrying shining orange flowers to cheer the cold of Late Winter. Each flower has a central boss of orange stamens that open to reveal a green eye
Fully double blooms of a nice waterlily shape which are creamy yellow with a distinct blue-grey reverse. Plain green leaves.

Little cracker with endlessly double flowers in quite a lemony yellow with a lime green centre. The glossy petals are stacked up row upon row with a beutiful regularity and grace. With no central stamnes they are reminiscent of Waterlilies and of the flow
>This curious little variety produces fully double blooms of shiny green flowers streaked with yellow. Definitely a curiosity for the collector who likes to 'have the set'!

Gold-edged bronze buds open to a typical celandine colour except ‘Montacute’ has 4 ruffs of petals prettily incurved to reveal the contrasting bronzy reverse. Unlike ‘Flore Pleno’ the centres of te flowers are open revealing a green eye surrounded by a
Glossy Buttermilk petals shaded purplish on the reverse set off by a central boss of double-cream stamens. A nice contrast to the other cultivars or where the bold yellows are a bit too strident.

At first glance this celandine looks more like a very early Kingcup. It is bigger and more robust in every aspect than the majority of lesser celandine with large circular leaves held almost a foot high and large golden glistening blooms 2.5cm across.
Queen of the Prairie. Earning this name by producing in summer a large frothy head of many pink flowers on stems up to 8ft tall! Prefers a moisture retentive soil in sun
Delightful small meadowsweet with bright butter yellow foliage and fluffy cream flowers. Neat and small; ideal at the edge of a water feature. Prefers a moisture retentive soil in sun
Delightful small meadowsweet with a dense rich green rosette of ferny foliage and fluffy cream flowers from pink shaded buds. Neat and refined Prefers a moisture retentive soil in sun
Delightful small meadowsweet with a dense rich green rosette of ferny foliage and single cream flowers from pink shaded buds. Neat and refined Prefers a moisture retentive soil in sun

Clumps of beautiful feathery bronze leaves build up to make impressive mounds that are a perfect foil for bold leaves such as Hostas. The stems grow 4-5 ft high and are topped with delicate yellow umbells that are equally ormanental. dead-head to prevent
A form of wand flower with deep pink flowers on tall waving stems. Lovely evergreen leaves & long flowering make this worth a place in any  garden. Best in a shelterd warm spot. 50cm
BRIDAL WREATH. Tall waving stems of pink-blotched white flowers not unlike a larger version of Heuchera. Each individual flower is particularly long lasting. 90cm. keep dry in winter
A large flowered mixture of this vibrantly coloured border plant. Endlessly produced wheels of red and gold. Good for cutting Ideal for poor soils in hot positions. 60cm
A vibrantly coloured border plant endlessly producing a succession of Tangerine centred lemon-orange wheels. Good for cutting Ideal for poor soils in hot positions. 65 x 45cm
A short growing selection of this vibrantly coloured border plant. Endlessly produced red-amber centred golden yellow wheels. Good for cutting Ideal for poor soils in hot positions. 35cm
A short growing selection of this vibrantly coloured border plant. Endlessly produced red centred golden yellow wheels. Good for cutting Ideal for poor soils in hot positions. 35cm
A vibrantly coloured border plant endlessly producing a succession of Tangerine centred lemon-orange wheels. Good for cutting Ideal for poor soils in hot positions. 65 x 45cm
Goat's Rue. Makes a substantial clump; 4ft high and wide; covered in spikes of pea flowers; coloured in shades of lilac. Plant in full sun. Cut back after flowering

(Asperula odorata). Charming ground cover for shade where it will produce a carpet of fresh green whorled leaves topped with brightest white starry flowers. Smells of new mown hay when crushed. Good on chalk
SUMMER HYACINTH. Summer flowering bulb producing a 1.5m stem hung like a candelabra with drooping ivory bells. Dry sunny site prefered. Excellent pushing up through a mixed planting
Choice form of the Summer Hyacinth. Sturdy  stems hung with honey scented green bells Dry site prefered. Earlier than G.candicans & only half its height. Height 2ft
Choice form of the Summer Hyacinth. Sturdy tall stems hung with honey scented green bells Dry site prefered. Taller than G.princeps & later than it or G.candicans. Height 3ft
Variegated foliage and flowers that are white edged bright pink. Valuable for its liking of hot dry positions and its late flowering. 1m; spreading rootstock
Pure white flowers opening from deep reddy pink buds create a long-lasting & graceful cloud. Valuable for its liking of hot dry positions and its late flowering. 1m; spreading rootstock
Pure white flowers opening from deep reddy pink buds create a long-lasting & graceful cloud. Valuable for its liking of hot dry positions and its late flowering. 1m; spreading rootstock
Willow gentian. In late summer every leaf axil on the gracefully arching stems carries several trumpets each rich blue; marked white in the throat. 75cm. Very choice
Neat; short; ground-covering geranium. Leaves retain a bright green colour and have a wonderful fresh  scent. Flowers are a veined white; produced in masses. Sun

The flowers of this new Danish cultivar are a pearly blueish pink with a distinct white border. The effect is enhanced by a darker pink eye and stamens and the deep colour of the calyces which persist after the flowers fade. Intensely fragrant mats of low
A German cultivar raised by Konigslutter with large white flowers with just a hint of pink; less pink staining than 'Biokovo' but with more mat leaves.
Neat; short; ground-covering geranium. Leaves retain a bright green colour and have a wonderful fresh  scent. Flowers are a rich pink; produced in masses. Sun
One of Alan Bremners first crosses. Short ground-covering geranium. Leaves retain a bright green colour and have a wonderful fresh  scent. Flowers pure white. Sun
Neat; short; ground-covering geranium. Leaves retain a bright green colour and have a wonderful fresh  scent. Flowers are a rich pink; produced in masses. Sun
Charming small geranium for the rock garden or front of border. Tight mounds of olive foliage covered during May with wide open palest pink flowers heavily marked with maroon stripes. 15cm. sun
Charming small geranium for the rock garden or front of border. Tight mounds of olive foliage from which stare up surprisingly large darkly veined pale pink flowers. 15cm. sun

Charming small geranium for the rock garden or front of border. Tight mounds of olive foliage from which stare up surprisingly large darkly veined pale pink flowers. A more darkly stained flower than 'Ballerina'. 15cm. sun

Charming small geranium for the rock garden or front of border. Tight mounds of olive foliage from which stare up barely pink flowres with delicate striping and a noticeable green eye. 15cm. sun and good drainage
Deeply divided foliage forms a spreading low mound which; in summer; is covered in a mass of clear pink flowers produced in an endless succession.
Deeply divided foliage forms a spreading low mound which; in summer; is covered in a mass of rich lilac-purple flowers; produced in an endless succession
Deeply divided foliage forms a spreading low mound which; in summer; is covered in a mass of purple veined white flowers produced in an endless succession
Very short carpeting geranium with glossy dark green leaves setting off the mass of sugar pink flowers produced throughout the summer. for sunny position
Strong growing stalwart geranium freely producing warm salmon pink blooms over  an extended period throughout summer. Benefits from a haircut mid season. 60cm

Large circular pure white flowers (4.5cm 2in) with pleasantly undulating edges. The centres are pale the anthers inconspicuous but the many bee lines are picked out in deep papal purple creating the ghost of blush centre. The outer third remains pure white. Nepal. 30-45cm.
Pale green cut foliage in a spreading mat; topped with large saucer blooms in a beguiling shade of sky blue. A neat and most beautiful cranesbill for the front of a bed. 45cm. Excellent autumn colour
Pale green cut foliage in a spreading mat; topped with large saucer blooms in a beguiling shade of sky blue. A neat and most beautiful cranesbill for the front of a bed. 45cm. Excellent autumn colour
Only a foot high; but a gem of a plant. Pale green cut foliage in a spreading mat; topped with double; lilac purple flowers; tinted with pink. Excellent autumn colour
A large showy geranium with large soft leaves; covered annually with a profusion of large rich violet flowers. Best grown in full sun. 2ft high by 3ft wide

Dormant through the hottest months of the year. The dark shining leaves appear in Autumn and persist throughout winter. In the Spring it then sends up its shoots topped with large (4cm) veined lilac blue flowers.Pretty and well worth a warm spot.  30cm
Dense mounds; 2ft tall; of soft; fragrant; weed smothering leaves and freely produced dark pink flowers. Easily grown and very reliable
The darkest form of this geranium. Dense mounds; 2ft tall; of soft; fragrant; weed smothering leaves and freely produced dark pink flowers. Easily grown and very reliable

The popular blush pink form of this geranium. Dense mounds; 2ft tall; of soft; fragrant; weed smothering  leaves and freely produced pale pink flowers with contrasting red calyces. Easily grown and very reliable

An exciting new colour form from Greece with pure white flowers with a pale green calyx set over fresh apple green foliage. Beautiful to enliven a dry shady spot but also easy and reliable elsewhere. 30cm spreading
Dense mounds; 2ft tall; of soft; fragrant; weed smothering leaves and freely produced dark pink flowers. Easily grown and very reliable

Summer dormant  producing leaves in Late Autumn and grows through Winter until the Summer droughts force it below ground. Finely cut foliage spreads well into quite large mats if grown in the sun and well-drained soil. Flowers pale pink.

istinguished by the most lovely clear pale sugar pink flowers that it shows off to great effect in outward facing clusters above the pale green foliage. Larger and more deeply coloured than ‘Shameface’. Geranium maculatum is a variable moisture loving sp

Impressive leaves which are deeply fingered and coloured brown. Flowers are produced early and are pale pink. The whole plant is a little smaller than ‘Elizabeth Ann’. Geranium maculatum is a variable moisture loving species; the best of the North Americ

A form of Geranium maculatum. In Spring the foliage is notable for having a rich red-purple flush which gradually fades through a glossy green towards Summer. The flowers are a mid purpley-pink with a central white eye. A nice addition to these shade loving Geraniums. Best in a moist soil

An excellent geranium that produces a dense mound of foliage that can be almost obscured by the mass of blue-violet flowers that are produced in a great flush in May. In general very similar to G. x magnificum but with flowers that are perhaps a little larger and paler in colour.
A large showy geranium with large soft leaves;  covered annually with a profusion of large rich  violet flowers. Sterile and therefore long flowering Best grown in full sun. 2ft high by 3ft wide

One of a group of Geraniums that pack up for a Summer dormancy growing through the Winter months.Really rich intense purple with heart shaped-petals held slightly apart from each other. Needs sun and good drainage to perform at its best. from Southern spain to Morocco and Algeria.
(G.phaeum x G.reflexum). Forming stout clumps of maroon spotted foliage and tall stems of nodding mauve-purple flowers. Prefers light shade; but tolerant of most conditions

Slightly reflexed petaled flowers with a white eye and a ring of smokey blue eye-liner. Generous clumps of large  leaves are handsomely marked with strong maroon blotches and stand well in shade even if dry. Even better is the lovely golden hue the leaves take on in early Spring
A good plant for ground  cover in troublesome dry places. The flowers; held on tall stems above the foliage have swept back petals coloured rose-pink; banded blue at the centre. 80cm

Variegated form of this robust geranium that so excels at difficult dry situations. The variegation takes the form of variable bright white splashing that covers at least 50% of the foliage. It looks particularly effective in Autumn as senescent yellow tones add into the mix.

1 inch wide rich purple petals each with a distinct pale lilac edge are overlaid with a shimmering indigo lustre and enhanced with 3 strong magenta pink veins. The orange style and lilac anthers complete the effect.

1 inch wide rich purple petals each with a distinct pale lilac edge are overlaid with a shimmering indigo lustre and enhanced with 3 strong magenta pink veins. The orange style and lilac anthers complete the effect.

Flowers  are well sized at 4cm and have clearly spaced petals. The colour can vary from a soft lavender to a lavender pink dependent on light and temperature. They flower pales to the centre and each petal has 3 really strong burgundy lines.

Mauvey-pink typical Geranium nodosum flowers but with an almost ragged edge formed by lobes of differing lengths. Strong purple bee-lines and a paler eye finish the effect. Nice green foliage and good in dry shade

Pinky-mauve flowers with purple rays. Each petal is heavily notched into 3 lobes giving it the effect of a scalloped collar. Nice green leaves and very good for naturalising in dry shade.From Robin Moss Hexham Northumberland

Lovely apple green glossy leaves topped off with glistening white flowers over a very extended season. The perfect plant for bringing a little sparkle into a difficult dry shady spot in the garden. May to September.Particularly good at coping with dry sha

Named after a house not one of it's characteristics. The flowers are some of the darkest of the group being a rich pinky purple at the centre fading out towards pink at the edge with a white edge. Strong bee lines complete the design.
Excellent ground cover in a wide variety of conditions. Pretty all summer with a long display of silver pink flowers. Cut to the ground after flowering. Height and spread 2-3ft

Glistening white petals with translucent veins and strong notched petals give the impression of 10 rather than 5 petals. Young flowers have grey-mauve anthers and the impression of colour in the veins but older flowers are pure white with green eyes.Unblotched leaves. 20-30cm high

Very pale silvery-pink flowers with a network of dark magenta veins. Spring through Summer. 45cm x 60cm. Forms excellent ground-cover with green leaves which are a fersh limey green when young carrying strong reddy-brown blotches.

Sweetie shop Geranium leaves they emerge creamy green and fade to a nice cream with an irregular central splash of green painted with bubble-gum pink dots. It sounds a bit garish but as a Spring foliage plant it is eye-catching and pleasantly decadent.

This is the near white form of this tough geranium which was named in honour of the great geranium enthusiast and expert Trevor Bath. Flowers are produced from June until the frosts and are palest blush almost white fading pinker. 60cm.
Each flower opens palest pink and darkens considerably with age giving a delightful two-toned effect over the whole of the 40cm weed covering hummock. long flowering
MOURNING WIDOW. The pure white form of this useful ground cover plant with striking white flowers held high above dense clumps of pale foliage Succeeds even in deep; dry shade. 80cm

The leaves are distinguished in that all of the veins are yellow giving the leaf a netted appearance. The colour fades as the leaf ages leaving them somewhat mottled. The flowers have swept back petals. With the rich purple colouring and white eye. Good i
Not a named cultivar just a very good dark form with dark stems as well. Excellent in shade

A cross between G.phaeum 'Samobor' to which it is like a large version and G.phaeum 'Golden Spring'. It has plum purple flowers above leaves that are well marked throughout the season with maroon blotches but show a paler centre in the early season. The flowers are a plum-purple.

These fowers warrant the closest of inspection as they posses the sort of intricate beauty that can easily get overlooked amongst some of their more brash cousins  Each flower is a translucent lavender-white shaded to the edges and picked out lavender in
A striking form of this cranes bill; distinguished by its larger flowers of a rich dark purple with pale centres. Dense clumps of pale foliage Succeeds even in deep; dry shade. 80cm

Handsome foliage especially in Spring and Autumn when the hearts of the leaves are cool cream gradually mottling out towards the edge. Further decorated by strong black spots. 50cm. Flowers are silvery purple highly reflexed with pink tipped anthers.

Geranium phaeum 'Mottisfont Rose' adds a completely different colour into the Geranium phaeum family. The flowers are quite flat and are shaded with Rose Madder. Not at all sombre like many cultivars but a lovely pastel.

Geranium phaeum 'Raven'. MOURNING WIDOW. A useful ground cover plant with striking dark purple flowers held high above dense clumps of pale foliage. Raven has unspotted leaves and purple-brown flowers and is relatively short growing at just 40cm.A seedling from 'Lily Lovell'

Dusky-pink just the colour of Rose Madder. Sprays of reflexed petalled flowers with a protruding style and stigma are produced from April intermittently throughout the Summer. Good clumps of palish green leaves with slight spots between the lobes.

Golden Spring foliage becomes suffused with green and is marbled with a maroon roughly heart-shaped ring at the depths of the lobes. The flowers are the deepest richest royal purple. Like all the phaeums it positively thrives in dry shade though the ye
The flowers are only slightly back-swept and are coloured a really rich purple-burgundy. Good strong variegation to the foliage. A garden seedling introduced by Mr Stephen Taffler.

A quite different form of the mourning widow which originated in the same garden as Geranium ‘Rozanne’. G. ‘Waterer’s Blue’ has flowers which are palest Air-Force blue with a central ring of cobalt-blue.
MOURNING WIDOW. A useful ground cover plant with striking dark purple flowers held high above dense clumps of pale foliage Succeeds even in deep; dry shade. 80cm

The original large flowered form of Geranium phaeum var. lividum by Bill Baker. An attractive pale lilac seedling was selected and named after Bill’s wife Joan. Robust geranium whichgrows strongly to 90cm even in quite dry shade making a very useful pla
MOURNING WIDOW. Particularly striking leaf markings distinguish this useful ground cover geranium. Dark maroon flowers add to the effect. Succeeds even in deep; dry shade. 80cm

Attractive native cranesbill with beautiful pure white blooms with yellow anthers displayed over lush dark green foliage. 2ft. A strong growing plant whose charms are equally well placed in the border or wild garden
One of the best of the dark leaved pratense geraniums growing strongly with deep maroon foliage and large lavender purple flowers during June and August. 40cm high.
Dark leaves and sugar pink flowers

Stunning new cultiver with leaves of a striking purple-black above which deep purple saucer shaped blooms are proudly displayed. Place in a prominent position where the unusual many fingered leaves will always provoce comment. Best in sun. 2-3ft
Beautiful flowers of powder blue with pale translucent veins; displayed over lush dark green foliage. 2ft Equally at home in the border or wild garden

Beautiful double cranesbill with powder blue flowers borne in a colourful haze on stout branching upright stems. A non spreading geranium that looks equally at home in  a formal border or in natural plantings. 2ft. sun

Beautiful double cranesbill with rich violet flowers borne in a colourful haze on stout branching upright stems. A non spreading geranium that looks equally at home in  a formal border or in natural plantings. 2ft. sun

Stunning new cultivar with leaves of a striking burgundy-black above which deep purple saucer shaped blooms are proudly displayed. Place in a prominent position where the unusual many fingered leaves will always provoke comment. Best in sun. 2-3ft
Unusual sport with white flowers randomly splashed  and striped in blue. Makes a sturdy upright  plant providing interest and colour in early summer Equally at home in the border or wild garden
Unusual sport with white flowers randomly splashed  and striped in blue. Makes a sturdy upright  plant providing interest and colour in early summer Equally at home in the border or wild garden

Beautiful double cranesbill with sky blue flowers borne in a colourful haze on stout branching upright stems. A non spreading geranium that looks equally at home in  a formal border or in natural plantings. 2ft. sun

Stunning new cultiver with leaves of a striking purple-black above which deep purple saucer shaped blooms are proudly displayed. Place in a prominent position where the unusual many fingered leaves will always provoce comment. Best in sun. 1-2ft

Stunning new cultiver with leaves of a striking purple-black above which deep purple saucer shaped blooms are proudly displayed. Place in a prominent position where the unusual many fingered leaves will always provoce comment. Best in sun. 2-3ft

Attractive native cranesbill with beautiful blue blooms (occasionally white  displayed over lush dark green foliage. 2ft. A strong growing plant whose charms are equally well placed in the border or wild garden
Forms a dense weed smothering clump of handsome foliage topped by startling rich magenta flowers each with a black eye. 1m A little shorter and paler than the species

Pure white form of that oh-so strident pink species from Turkey laking either the dark eye or veins of the species. Collected by Andy Byfield from meadows in Turkey it is a significant departure from norm with foliage in a clean mid green and flowers of the cleanest of whites.
Unashamadely bold and brash. Forms a dense weed smothering clump of handsome foliage topped by startling rich magenta flowers with black eyes. Grows best in dappled shade. 1.2m

Unusual growth habit producing numerous lax stems from a central crown that keep extending in length unless cut back. Maple-like leaves densly hairy. giving it an attractive silvery green appearance. Flowers which are better in hotter sunnier location

The flowers held on tall stems above the foliage have swept back petals coloured pale pink with a blue band at the point of reflex. 80cm. Excellent groundcover for light shade where it will carpet with an impenetrable ever spreading mat of pale green lea
Flowering from summer until the frosts with light magenta flowers produced continuously on trailing stems. Forms a low spreading mound of silvery green foliage. Best in full sun
column13: G\Geranium x riversleanum Russel Prichard flower.jpg

column9: Cheerful little cranesbill producing wide soft hummocks of foliage covered in summer in pure white blooms. Foliage colours vivid red in autumn. 30cm tall by 60cm wide

A delightful short spreading geranium ideal for the front of border or scuttling about beneath shrubs and roses. The foliage is reminiscent of G.sanguineum but the flowers are well rounded and of a glowing sugary pink. Produces a single flower from each a
Cheerful little cranesbill producing wide soft hummocks of foliage covered in summer in clear pale pink blooms. Foliage colours vivid red in autumn. 30cm tall by 60cm wide
Cheerful little cranesbill producing wide soft hummocks of foliage covered in summer in deep magenta blooms. Foliage colours vivid red in autumn. 30cm tall by 60cm wide
Cheerful little cranesbill producing wide soft hummocks of foliage covered in summer in pale sugary pink blooms. Foliage colours vivid red in autumn. 30cm tall by 60cm wide
Cheerful little cranesbill producing wide soft hummocks of foliage covered in summer in deep magenta blooms. Foliage colours vivid red in autumn. 30cm tall by 60cm wide
Small geranium with the most vivid deep magenta flowers; produced throughout the summer months. Forms a neat compact mound of foliage. Full sun at the front of border or rockery. 15cm
Glossy medium green leaves form a good clump to 1ft tall; setting off perfectly the glistening white flowers; produced in May Grows best in partial shade
Whilst not quite a 1 blue Geranium ‘Amy Doncaster’ certainly boasts the bluest flowers of the sylvaticum cultivars. The flowers are neat and rounded 2.5cm across with a clear white eye.
A new variety from Cyril Foster with particularly well sized flowers in a pleasing lavender shade.
Glossy medium green leaves form a good clump to 1ft tall; well above which are held in May the white centered rich violet- blue flowers. Best in partial shade

This cranesbill is a spring specialist running underground with small tubers and sending up delicate mats of foliage topped with veined lilac blue flowers in Spring. The foliage disappears by summer. Use it at the front of a border where larger plants ca
Charming flowers; rounded in outline with a deep powder blue edge and white centre; heightened by the black stamens. Late season. Stems trail 2ft from a central crown

Large white flowers are so heavily networked with mauve veins as to give a ghostly mauve effect highlighted with purple anthers. A form of G.erianthum that was grown from seed collected in Alaska and given to Michael Pitkin at Viburnum Gardens Sydney Australia

A superb sterile hybrid which yearly spreads from a central crown to form a bush 3ft across studded with flowers of deepest pink. Foliage emerges golden; later fading green. Full sun. G.procurrens x G.psilostemon

A cranes bill with the same parentage as 'Anne Folkard' but with a less spreading habit. The effect is the same wild combination of vivid magenta held above mounds of golden foliage. 50 cm X 90cm spread. G.procurrens x G.psilostemon

A new introduction with very large flowers each a rich blue with a white central eye. More upright than sprawling with a good strong constitution. Has very long flowering season form june onwards. 45 cm
A dwarf spreading cranesbill with freely produced deep sugar-pink flowers over neat ground covering mats of shiny chocolate brown shaded leaves. Spread 45cm
A new variety with rounded flowers of a charming summer sky blue. The flowering stems will trail or happily scramble up through a shrub to a height of 1m. Cut back as the flowering stems fade.

A beautiful cranes bill of subtle charm with  delicately cut foliage of greyish hue and wide open saucer blooms  of pearly translucent blue; flushed pink. Non invasive; forming a neat but substantial mound. 2ft. sun. Seedling from 'Brookside'

This variety is a cross between 'Ann Folkard' and wallichianum 'Buxton's variety. Yellow leaves of the former longer lasting than the parent with flowers in a pinky-blue produced all throughout the summer. It has a low growing sprawling habit making it ideal for the front of the border

column7: (Geranium clarkei Kashmir Purple x Geranium pratense)
column9: A lovely new hybrid which combines strong growth and beautiful finely divided foliage with amply  produced large deep clear blue flowers; each paler in the centre. 60cm. (G.pratense x G. Kashmir Purple)
A vigorous weed smotherer. Will make dense leafy clumps in sun or shade. Lilac pink flowers produced in summer Evergreen. Height 2.5 feet

A newly bred variety which forms a low spreading mound of softly felted marbled leaves above which are held slightly cupped almost circular flowers that open with a pink tinge and quickly turn white with red veins. A beautiful compliment under old roses.

A fairly new and very promising hybrid. Dilys forms a 90cm wide 20cm high mound of soft finely cut foliage covered in soft purple darkly veined flowers. Attractive in leaf and with a very long flowering season. G.sanguineum x G.procurrens
column13: G\Geranium Dilys with gypsophila Rosy Veil #1.JPG

column9: A new hybrid geranium that produces a wealth of bright starry cyclamen pink flowers over a spreading mat of yellow tinted foliage. Best grown in full sun for best flowering.

Sumptuous greyish foliage with a sagey quality is topped with large silvery pink flowers of charming gradated colour each veined cerise. Bred as a ground covering variety. May to September. 40cm high by a greater spread. A prolific and long season flower
A newly bred variety which forms a low spreading mound of gorgeous burgundy foliage. From May to September the plant will be studded with baby pink flowers 30cm spread
A newly bred variety which forms a low spreading mound of gorgeous burgundy foliage. From May to September the plant will be studded with baby pink flowers 30cm spread

Quite compact form probably seeded from the bloody cranesbill. 4cm glowing magenta with papal purple shading  paler at the edges to highlight the flower with a mauve halo. The centre of each flower is also near white with each petal rayed with magenta lines. Happy in full sun.
An excellent variety from Jenny Spiller. Large mounds of foliage which is yellow in spring and an abundance of strong pink flowers all summer
Large flowers (5cm ) with strong dark veining and an unusual habit (for this type of Geranium) of producing greenish yellow leaves early on. Sun to part shade 40cm high by 50 wide.
A deservedly popular hardy geranium whose rich  pure blue flowers are produced in endless succession  throughout summer.The effect is further enhanced by fine silvery foliage. Sun. 30cm

A joy all year with almost evergreen mounds of soft marbled leaves and cupped flowers that are a gentle pink enlivened with red veins produced over an extended season from spring until autumn. 45cm spread. Gtraversii var elegans x G.lambertii

A dwarf form derived from Geranium psilostemon about 30 cm tall which will form good ground cover covered in bright glowing cerise flowers with striking black eyes. Bred by Jan Spuyt. The name derives from the French for 'Can you see me'.
Deeply divided foliage forms a spreading low mound which; in summer; is covered in a mass of clear lavender blue flowers; produced in an endless succession
Flowering from summer until the frosts with pale sugar-pink flowers produced continuously on trailing stems. Forms a low spreading mound of foliage. Best in full sun
column13: G\Geranium x riversleanum Mavis Simpson flower.jpg

column9: Combining the lovely form of the one and the long flowering season of the Other. Plentiful 2-3cm  rose pink flowers veined in a darker shade which are carried in large heads . It grows 60cm high in compact clumps with handsomely divided foliage.

A fine new cultivar which is already earning a good reputation. The foliage which emerges ochre tinted is finely cut and pale apple green and provides an excellent foil for the starry lilac flowers that are continuously produced in summer.

A fine new cultivar with dark green  finely divided foliage which creates a lovely foil for it's large dark purple flowers with carmine veining. Flowers are freely produced over a long season on a mound of foliage which will scramble through roses etc if

A newly bred cranes bill. The low growing mats of smoky green softly hairy foliage provide a perfect foil for the masses of bright pink flowers that are produced  all through the summer. Perfect for filling a gap

G. psilostemon x G. endressii. A really strong and startling new geranium that inherits the shocking cerise flowers from one parent and the strength and vigour from the other. A large and robust plant that will make a vivid statement throughout the summer
Neat mounds of soft felty grey green leaves offset the clusters of bluey purple flowers with strong veining. Long flowering period 40cm
This is the Pink form of the ever-popular Geranium 'Rozanne'
A cross between G.albiflorum and G.sylvaticum. Upright habit with terminal clusters of numerous small flowers in violet-blue. 45-90cm . May onwards. An Alan Bremner cross

A new introduction with very large flowers each a rich blue with a white central eye. More upright than sprawling with a good strong constitution. Has very long flowering season form june onwards. 45 cm

G.lambertii x G.procurrens. Similar in habit to Ann Folkard with long sprawling stems that will ramble through neighbours. Yellow marbled leaves in spring and a continuos succession of plae lavender flowers with dark veins and a black eye
An outstanding new hybrid that produces masses of large flat bright pink flowers continuously for several months through the summer. A plant that will earn its keep in any planting scheme. 90cm
Fast spreading clumps of deeply divided leaves covered in rich purple flowers bobbing on long waving stems. ideal at the front of the border; growing 30-45cm tall. Full sun best

Gorgeous 35mm soft lilac flowers with a a dramatic almost black eye which radiates through the petals in a network of purple veins. June until August with a flush in Autumn. Soft foliage in a small 30cm mound 50cm wide. Sun or part shade and decent darinage. Good ground cover

Excellent recently introduced cranes bill. Deep green felty leaves with darker markings and often a pale rim over which are freely produced dark eyed reddish purple  blooms. A brilliant splash of colour all summer. A cross between G.oxonianum and G. Salom

Packs a real punch and also bears the closest inspection.In flower this geranium carries a mass of miniature rosebud flowers each one a double opening cream with a green eye and developing into the lovliest lavender-pink. Short bushy habit.

Flowers are of a good size (4cm ) opening relatively flat with widely spaced petals showing the green calyx behind. There is a bold white central disc and prominent dark bee lines. The colour varys considerably from a lavender blue to a pink
A wonderful new cultivar with al compact spreading habit. Chocolatey brown foliage is studded with bright pink flowers over a long season. Easy to grow and excellent ground cover

his cultivar has the benefit of a growth habit and leaf like a G.sanguineum but with flowers on branching flower stems. It is long flowering with large flowers for its size each Purplish red with darker veins. Leaves redden well in the Autumn.
The tightly crowded clump of fresh apple- green foliage forms a perfect foil for the wide open rich apricot flowers. For a moist soil in sun or shade. 25cm
Colourful and easily grown perennial forming a stout weed smothering clump of leaves and freely producing 2ft stems of warm yellow semi double flowers in summer.
Colourful and easily grown perennial forming a stout weed smothering clump of leaves and freely producing 2ft stems of bright red semi double flowers in summer.
column16: G\Geum Mrs J Bradshaw single close #3.jpg

column9: The tightly crowded clump of fresh apple- green foliage forms a perfect foil for the wide open soft apricot flowers. For a moist soil in sun or shade. 25cm

This is one for those of you that like something a bit more subtle – a bit of a symphony in cream and green. There are up to 3 rows of petals each one long stalked giving a gap at the flower base. They are white deliciously green shaded in the bee lines
One of the denser clumping geums of mid size. The flowers are white
The tightly crowded clump of fresh apple- green foliage forms a perfect foil for the wide open rich apricot flowers. For a moist soil in sun or shade. 25cm

Compact Geum with large semi-double flowers of deep coral-pink with darker vein detail and petal edges. The petals have a lovely goffered edge. Dark stems and calyces emphasise the effect. For a sunny or partially shaded site in decent soil. 40 x 40cm. Spring
Colourful and easily grown perennial with flowers in the brightest zingy orange that stare up over dense foliage throughout the summer. Cut out spent stems to encourage extra flowers.

5 rows of frilly petticoat-like petals in a warm soft yellow all suffused with peach. The centre of each flower has a big boss of yellow stamens tipped with brown anthers all ringed around with the red styles in the middle. Apricot reverse with a dark red calyx and stem.

Semi double flowers of good size the colour of crushed strawberries at the edges bleeding into cream. Petal with slightly frilly edge. A good boss of golden stamens enhanced by the highly divided scarlet style. A very free flowering sterile variety. 60cm
Certainly a Geum to fall in love with. Geum 'Flames of Passion' is relatively short and neat at a foot high. The flowers are 2cm across and look down in a rather coy fashion

Warm yellow petals tipped and suffused with coppery peach tones. It has 3 rows of petals which are not only ruffled but also beautifully frilly at the edge. The effect is neat delicate and quite charming. Nodding buds are wrapped in pomegranate red calyces.

Taller growin holding its flowers outward facing on tall upright stems. The flowers are large at 3cm with 6 petals with undulating edges in a soft tangerine with pinker strawberry tones on the reverse. In cooler conditions it can take on a shades of burnt orange as well

When it first opens this reminds me of the simple cotton caps worn by maids in years gone by with frilly edges all gathered together with a band. At first nodding and a fresh lemon in colour the flowers open flatter and fade to a rich buttermilk. A good clumping variety.

This subtle little geum is quite close to its rivale roots. The flowers all nod down with lemon yellow petals that remain in a tight little bell just showing proud of the calyx. A good little clump former.
One of the denser clumping geums of mid size. The flowers are large frilly and a beautiful red stained peach. Keep cutting out old flowering stems to encourage a succession of flowers.
A bright fiery orange geum of the larger coccinea type. Semi-double with 2-3 rows of gently undulating petals. Height 30-60cm. Introduced by Michael Wickenden of Cally Gardens in Scotland
Colourful and easily grown perennial with large frilly blooms in the brightest zingy orange produced all throughout the summer. Cut out spent stems to encourage extra flowers.

This Geum has built up a great reputation for reliability and impact. A sterile hybrid that will hold its zingy semi double orange flowers on stems up to 90cm tall and keep on producing them over an extended season. The Rich orange back towards a more mellow shade.
One of the denser clumping geums of mid size.  Keep cutting out old flowering stems to encourage a succession of flowers.

A slender willowy erect perennial with red stems clothed with almost sessile trifoliate leaves. 75-90cm tall. In June the graceful stems are topped with fluttery 5 petalled white flowers which contrast beautifully with the red buds and calyces.

Combines the lovely flower form of the hybrids with a fair degree of hardiness. Very soft coral/scarlet with the classic form. Inside the lower three petals is a soft lemon flash which is picked up by a yellow central vein on the wings and the lemon colour of the stamens and pistil.
A hardy gladiolus with hooded flowers in a pale slatey lilac; cream inside with purple markings and a striking yellow blotch. A curious beauty that always fascinates.
A hardy gladiolus with hooded flowers in a pale slatey lilac; cream inside with purple markings and a striking yellow blotch. A curious beauty that always fascinates.

Ruby is classed as a hybrid of papilio and you can certainly see the influence in the shape of the flowers and their slightly sinister hooded nature. The flowers are a rich ruby red with darker staining on the interior.

A dwarf relative of the giant rhubarbs forming tight foliage mats; spreading to about 1m; but only 15cm high. Curious spikes of bright red fruits are an interesting and unexpected bonus. For moist soils.

A delicate native fern that creeps along to form loose mats. The foliage is delicate and fresh produced on short wiry stalks. It reminds me of what you would get by crossing adiantum with a buckler fern
A 1m round hazy cloud of tiny double white flowers. Beautiful both in the garden or cut to add to bouquets. Grows best in a well drained sunny spot. July-Aug

Cheerful saucer shaped blooms over grassy foliage that provide a welcome late burst of colour before the end of the season. Major is a strong growing brilliant crimson. Enjoys a warm site moist in summer. Mid season flowering Sept to October. 60cm spre
Babies Breath. A 1m round hazy cloud of tiny  pink flowers. Beautiful both in the garden or cut to add to bouquets. Grows best in a well drained sunny spot. July-Aug
Babies Breath. A smaller hybrid. The flowers produce a delightful 30cm round airy cloud of delicate pale silvery pink double blooms in summer. Will grow to its best in a dry sunny site.
Babies Breath. A 1m round hazy cloud of tiny white flowers. Beautiful both in the garden or cut to add to bouquets. Grows best in a well drained sunny spot. July-Aug

Soft and billowing like the surf as it reaches the beach this exquisite grass forms low growing domes of limey yellow ribbony blades in a shady position. The more sun it gets the less lime and more gold you get but happiest in partial shade. Deciduous 30-40cm
Tiny buttons of yellow surrounded by a fresh green collar. A charming little plant for a cool spot. A dwarf relative of eryngiums and Astrantia.
A mixture of different coloured Sneezeweed ranging from red through to pure yellow. Showy daisies from late summer through autumn Easily grown in any good soil. 90cm

A yellow sport from Moerheim Beauty. Profuse in flower making a striking show from July through September with its mass of bright yellow daisies with brown button centres. Easily grown in any good soil. 60-90cm
The large rich orange daisies of this profuse flowering variety of Sneezeweed make a striking show from July through September Easily grown in any good soil. 90cm
A good rich yellow form of Sneezeweed providing a powerful splash of warm colour to the border in late summer. Easily grown in all but the very wettest and driest soils. 1m

A new development in Heleniums. with a double row of ray florets giving each flower a much fuller and more frilly appearance. Flowers are a bright sunny yellow produced over a very long period in mid to late summer. Easily grown in all but the very wette
The large rich copper red petals of these cone nosed daisies  profusely  flower  from July through September making a striking show. Easily grown in sun and  any good soil. 120cm
A useful mid to late summer flowering sneezeweed with canary yellow petals and centre a wonderful  warm colour for the summer garden. Easily grown in all but the very wettest and driest soils. 1m
The large rich deep red daisies of this profuse flowering variety of Sneezeweed make a striking show from July through September Easily grown in any good soil. 60-90cm

Deep red typical daisies with a prominent brown golden tipped pin cushion boss in the centre. The petals have a faint gold edge but the overall effect is of a rich deep red which resists fading well. 75cm

Bears a display of deep red typical daisies with a prominent brown golden tipped pin cushion boss in the centre. The petals are rich deep red which fades slowly to orange. The upright stems are rather stiff to about 75cm making a relatively short neat habit for an Helenium.

A new development in Heleniums combining a dwarf size with a much branched habit and a multitude of small deep red flowers produced over an extended period. Mid to late summer. Easily grown in all but the very wettest and driest soils. 50cm

A lovely summery daisy with prominent brown centres loved by bees. Flowers open yellowy-orange streaked with darker orange and become redder with age creating a rich mix of colour which goes on and on from June to October. 1m high.
Valuable shorter growing Sneezeweed with bright orange and red dark centred daisies  produced in abundance from July through September Easily grown in any good soil. 60cm

Loosely double flowers in a strong sugar pink darkening to red around a yellow centre. Lovely to cascade over a warm wall. Plant in full sun in good drainage. 20-25cm. Trim very lightly after flowering and more thoroughly in Spring. Flowers May to September

Unlike any other sunflower the leaves are reduced to long narrow threads.Flowering head is quite open with a small number of rich chrome yellow sunflower that are like yellow Cosmos. Full sun and moisture is best but tolerates drought and poor soils. Spreads
Tall stems crowned with a mass of dark centred lemon sunflowers; each 7cm across. Makes an excellent late summer show & superb late nectar source for bees .6ft
Tall stems crowned with a mass of dark centred lemon sunflowers; each 7cm across. Makes an excellent late summer show & superb late nectar source for bees .7ft. Taller than 'Castle Kobena'
An elegant grass forming bold  spiky clumps of grey foliage.  Flowers give a long & valuable display Foliage 18 inches; flowers 3 feet Full sun

Beautiful silver grey marbled evergreen foliage and white flushed pink flushed flowers in a delightful terminal cluster. Combines the best hardy features and flower size of H. niger with the foliage and pink flush of H. sternii. A real gem for the winter
Splendid evergreen. The large heads of 2inch apple green flowers are produced in late winter lasting into spring. Sun. Cut out old stems.  HARMFUL IF EATEN

New selection of this easy evergreen Hellebore with beautiful lemony coloured palmate leaves which become chartreuse green in Summer. from Feb-May airy bunches of greenish flowers are freely borne. 40cm. Any situation but greener in deep shade.   HARMF
Possibly the best garden form of this hellebore. A lovely contrast of pale apple green flowers in a dense head above rich glossy foliage. Winter to Spring    HARMFUL IF EATEN
A lovely contrast of pale apple green flowers in a dense head above rich glossy foliage. Winter to Spring. A form with a red flush to the stems.   HARMFUL IF EATEN
A lovely contrast of pale apple green flowers in a dense head above rich glossy foliage. Winter to Spring    HARMFUL IF EATEN
A lovely contrast of pale apple green flowers in a dense head above rich glossy foliage. Winter to Spring    HARMFUL IF EATEN
A brand new twist on the classic Christmas Rose. This beautiful new strain Has a tight ring of many petals around centre of the flower ofeth tipoped green or yellow

A brand new twist on the classic Christmas Rose. This beautiful new strain carries countless extra narrow twisted petals giving the flower a starburst appearance. Extra petals are persistent keeping their shape as the large startling white flowers age gr
Charming wide open pure white waxy blooms with bright yellow centres Long lasting flowers to cheer the depths of winter best in light shade. 15cm  HARMFUL IF EATEN

A cross between Helleborus niger and argutifolius resulting in a  larger but similar plant to H. niger with more vigour and  with much larger heads of flowers. In established plants of this clone the white Christmas Rose flowers have a second row of small

A cross between Helleborus niger and argutifolius resulting in a  larger but similar plant to H. niger with more vigour and  with much larger heads of flowers. In established plants of this clone the white Christmas Rose flowers may have a second row of s

LENTEN ROSE. Charming nodding flowers in pale creamy white with the edge of each petal picked out in dark pink. The petals are further enhanced withrays of dark pink and a dark 'eye'. 2 feet high.  Versatile; best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN
Charming nodding flowers in white with pink shading some heavily spotted; opening  soon after Christmas. 1 to 2 feet Versatile; best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN
Seed grown stock grown from our own seed harvested from a wide selection of choice varieties collected over the last 20 years.
These plants are selected picotee (white with a pink edge) forms of Lenten Rose grown from our own collected seed. These could be pure or spotted.
HARMFUL IF EATEN
These plants are selected pink shades of Lenten Rose grown from our own collected seed.
These plants are selected purple shadesÂ of Lenten Rose grown from our own collected seed.
Charming nodding flowers in a range of purples; some heavily spotted; opening  soon after Christmas. 1 to 2 feet Versatile; best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN
Charming nodding white flowers heavily spotted inside; opening  soon after Christmas. 1 to 2 feet Versatile; best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN
