column9: These plants are selected white formsÂ of Lenten Rose grown from our own collected seed. These could be pure or spotted.
Charming nodding flowers in the darker slatey shades of purple some heavily spotted; opening  soon after Christmas. 1 to 2 feet Versatile; best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN
Charming nodding white flowers some heavily spotted; opening  soon after Christmas. 1 to 2 feet Versatile; best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN
Charming nodding flowers in a soft yellows; some heavily spotted; opening  soon after Christmas. 1 to 2 feet tall. Versatile; best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN

An exquisite new strain of the charming Lenten Rose. The pastel coloured flowers are fully double just like a winter flowering rose and are borne in nodding sprays from February until May. An easy going plant happy in many situations.  HARMFUL IF EATEN
LENTEN ROSE. Charming nodding flowers in a range of pinks; some heavily spotted; opening  soon after Christmas. 1 to 2 feet Versatile; best in light shade. HARMFUL IF EATEN
(H.argutifolius x H.lividus). Dwarf seed strain sometimes less than a foot tall. marbled grey green foliage and pink flushed flowers in a delightful terminal cluster.
(H.argutifolius x H.lividus). Lovely seed strain with red flushed stems of spiky grey green foliage; terminated in early spring by clusters of pink-tinged; green flowers.
column13: H\Helleborus x sternii Boughton Beauty Strain.jpg

column9: A brand new Hellebore with the size and strong growth of Helleborus argutifolius combined with beautifully white marbled leaves whose reverse and stems are a contrasting red. Good on alkaline soils. Enjoys a warm spot. Flowers green in terminal clusters i

One of a new range of hybrids between The Christmas Rose and H.sternii. The plants are exceptionally prolific producing multiple flowering stems each well furnished with flowers. The flowers begin white becoming ever more pink as they age. 45cm.

One of an excellent new range of hybrid of H.sternii. The plants are exceptionally prolific producing multiple flowering stems each well furnished with flowers. The flowers begin white becoming ever more pink as they age. 45cm.

One of a new range of hybrids between The Christmas Rose and H.sternii. This plant is close in looks to H.nigercors but producing more flowering stems with exceptionally large flowers which begin white and age green. 60cm

One of a new range of hybrids between The Christmas Rose and H.sternii. The plants have beautiful marbled foliage and are exceptionally prolific producing multiple flowering stems each well furnished with flowers. The flowers are pure white becoming pin

Flowers are large at 14cm with a clean shape like an Asiatic lily. The colour is a rich deepest dark purple-red. The edges of each petal are lined with white and the yellow throat positively glows out. A Midseason reblooming Diploid variety.

Strong growing forming dense clumps of stap-like foliage which start very early in to growth. Summer sees a prolonged sucession of largepale lemon lily-like flowers with a strong central purple blotch. Best in full sun
Strong growing forming dense clumps of stap-like foliage which start very early in to growth. Summer sees a prolonged sucession of largeburnt orange lily-like flowers. Best in full sun
Strong growing forming dense clumps of stap-like foliage which start very early in to growth. Summer sees a prolonged sucession of large apricot lily-like flowers. Best in full sun
Charming small woodland plant with shining evergreen three lobed leaves amongst which the beautiful sky blue flowers nestle in spring. 15cm for leafy soil in shade

Rich speckled pink saucer shaped blooms over grassy foliage that provide a welcome late burst of colour before the end of the season. Enjoys a warm site moist in summer. Mid season flowering Sept to October. 60cm spreading

Cheerful saucer shaped blooms over grassy foliage that provide a welcome late burst of colour before the end of the season. Jennifer is a warm mid pink. Enjoys a warm site moist in summer. Mid season flowering Sept to October. 60cm spreading

Cheerful saucer shaped blooms over grassy foliage that provide a welcome late burst of colour before the end of the season. Major is a strong growing brilliant crimson. Enjoys a warm site moist in summer. Mid season flowering Sept to October. 60cm spre

Can look like a slightly pinker version of H.coccinea 'Major' but later on the petals can reflex beyond flat and the petals take on a satiny coral red colour streaked with red and also revealing a pale eye. 6.5cm across. Useful if Major is too strident a red for your taste

Delicate palest pink saucer shaped blooms over grassy foliage that provide a welcome late burst of colour before the end of the season. Enjoys a warm site moist in summer. Mid season flowering Sept to October. 60cm spreading

Tall slender stems 100 to 120cm with 4 petalled flowers. Heads of highly perfumed flowers reminiscent of willowy stocks. Much loved by pollinating insects. An old Cottage Garden favourite. Short lived but good for naturalising in damp shady or grassy
A pleasure all year as the leaves emerge a bright apple green and remain all winter a deep scarlet red. Flowers are white; held well above the foliage. Succeeds in most soil types. 45cm
A perennial plant forming clumps of attractively marbled foliage; with wiry stems displaying sprays of tiny bell-shaped deep scarlet flowers Good ground cover. sun-part shade. 50cm

A large Heuchera with rich purple leaves overlaid with silver markings. A distinctly more purple shade than the many burgundy shaded cultivars. Tall in flower with large leaves on long stems. height 45cm. Flowering in April-June

Stunning leaves make this a must for any flower arranger. On a pale green background are overlaid red and plum markings brought to life with a bright rim.  Colouring alters as the seasons progress. 60cm

A lovely Heuchera prized for it's strikingy foliage shaded with rose-pink raspberry and blackberry colours. Bold habit and a combination of heat loving and cold tolerant habits from its parentage.  22 x 40cm

A new variety with densely packed ruffled leaves that are chocolatey on top with a rich burgundy reverse. Produces a profusion of tiny purple flowers in early summer. 25 x 40cm. Good in sun or shade or as a pot specimen.
Wonderful slightly ruffled glossy near black foliage creates  an impressive plant for the border or a patio pot.

A very richly coloured Heuchera with bold maroon and blackberry leaves with ebony veins. Tall in flower with large leaves on long stems. height 45cm. Flowering in April-June. Ideal for the border or pot culture
A perennial plant forming clumps of attractively marbled foliage; with wiry stems displaying sprays of tiny bell-shaped flowers in crimson to coral pink. Good ground cover. sun-part shade. 50cm
A lovely new introduction with deeply ruffle edged leaves of a rich maroon-purple overlaid with paler marbling. Rapid but compact growth. Swaying stems of pale pink flowers to 50cm
The large rounded purple leaves of this new variety are generously overlaid with pewter markings making it attractive at the front of any border and an asset in a patio pot. Rapid grower . 55cm
A lovely introduction with deeply ruffle edged leaves of a muted maroon with brighter underside. Rapid but compact growth. Swaying stems of pale pink flowers to 50cm
Lovely clumps of ruffled edged ebony foliage are topped off in April to June with sprays of large ivory flowers making a super contrast. Ideal for the border or patio pots.Evergreen. 45cm in flower
A lovely bright eye-catching Heuchera with mounds of glowing wine-red leaves. Pink and white bi-coloured flowers are produced over a long perios from April to July on dark red stems. 20 x 40cm
This Heuchera has the double advantages of attractive purple red flowers and heads of relatively large flared dusky-salmon flowers. Good ground cover. sun-part shade. 50cm
One of the latest Heuchera. This variety combines a compact habit with deep purple leaves silvered between the veins that crest to form a Japanese Geisha's Fan. 20cm high by 50cm wide
One of the newest Heuchera. Evergreen leaves are always a delight in varying shades of green with a darker overlay. New leaves emerge ochre with red veins Swaying stems of buff flowers to 55cm

Really super compact dark purple foliage heavily over-laid with silver is topped off from April till July with spikes of intense rose red flowers. 20 x 40cm. Excellent for the patio pot or the border.
Wonderful slightly ruffled glossy near black foliage creates  an impressive plant for the border or a patio pot.
Excellent evergreen foliage interest provided all year by the rich purple tones of the leaves which form a dense compact plant..

A lovely Heuchera prized for it's shiny rufflle edged foliage which is a rich mahogany red. The hue of the leaves changes with the seasons being more purple in cool weather and redder as the temperature rises. 20 x 40cm

Excellent evergreen foliage interest provided all year by the rich dark purple tones of the sculptured leaves irregularly splashed with pink spots. Dense compact plant. Spotting brightens with age. 40cm.

A lovely new heuchera with large mint green foliage which is overlaid with a soft silver frosting. The veins remain dark and create wonderful patterns. Leaves take on pinkish tones in winter. Flowers are sprays of small bell shaped blooms. 60cm
Wonderful slightly ruffled glossy near black foliage creates  an impressive plant for the border or a patio pot.
Excellent evergreen foliage interest provided all year by the rich purple tones of the leaves. Dainty pink flowers in summer are an added bonus Slowly spreads to form good ground cover.

A Large strong growing heuchera whose leaves display a rich tapestry of plum burgundy and silvered shading which looks good throughout the year being a particular asset in winter. the flowering spikes are tall and graceful.
Charming dwarf Heuchera with closely crowded leaves varying in shades of bronze and purple with a silver overlay. Ivory pink flowers on darkened stems. Good in dry areas; ideal for patio pots. 45cm
The beautiful evergreen leaves are unsurpassed with their pewter overlay on a purple-maroon ground. New growth is brighter; soon followed by cool ice pink flowers

A Large strong growing heuchera whose leaves display a rich tapestry of coppery plum with silvered shading which looks good throughout the year being a particular asset in winter. the flowering spikes are tall and graceful.

One of the most attractive new heucheras with its enchanting combination of purple and pink shading; washed over with pewter and silver. Maroon and green flowers. 50cm Rapid growth rate; easy in most good soil types

A very different new Heuchera whose leaves are a shiny purple all year but emerge from winter with a silvery violet hue. Excellent vigour combines with a comapct growth habit. Flowers pinky-white. 25*45cm; easy in most good soil types
Excellent evergreen foliage interest provided all year by the rich purple tones of the leaves. Dainty pink flowers in summer are an added bonus Slowly spreads to form good ground cover.
Excellent evergreen foliage interest provided all year by the rich dark purple tones of the sculptured leaves which form a dense compact plant..'Large' white flowers to 45cm.
Excellent purple leaves which create a lovely foil. The new leaves are ruffled being even more frilly in the winter months. Stems of tiny cream flowers in summer. Good in dry situations
Excellent evergreen foliage interest provided all year by the rich purple tones of the leaves. Dainty pink flowers in summer are an added bonus Slowly spreads to form good ground cover.
Heavily marked leaves are fresh green in summer leaden grey in winter enlivened with a coral rim. Rapid but compact growth. Swaying stems of pale buff flowers to 50cm

column9: A stunning new heuchera whose compact habit and beautiful leaves are sure to gain it popularity. The leaves are a deep maroon so heavily overlayed pewter as to have a silver sheen. 35cm
Attractive evergreen for the front of the border with its cream speckled leaves and bright scarlet flowers in summer Leaves form a 1ft mound; flowers to 18in
A lovely Heuchera prized for it's burgundy foliage. The hue of the leaves changes with the seasons being more purple in cool weather and misty orange as the temperature rises. 20 x 40cm
A lovely new introduction with deeply ruffle edged leaves of a rich maroon-purple overlaid with paler marbling. Rapid but compact growth. Swaying stems of pale pink flowers to 50cm
A stunning new heuchera whose compact habit and beautiful leaves are sure to gain it popularity. The leaves are a deep maroon so heavily overlayed pewter as to have a silver sheen. 35cm
One of the newest Heuchera. Evergreen leaves are always a delight in varying shades of green with a bright silver overlay. New leaves emerge ochre with red veins Swaying stems of buff flowers to 55cm

A pretty clump forming perennial halfway between its parents (Heuchera and Tiarella). Attractive bright green leaves marked with black and beautifully margined in winter. Pretty pale pink fower spikes. 30-45cm tall

The large maple shaped leaves are a deep shining bronze perfect to set off the airy spikes of starry pink flowers that are produced from  April to October. An easy and rewarding evergreen perennial even tolerating dryish shade under trees

Marbled green maple shaped foliage offsets the  branched spikes of flourescent pink which are produced in profusion over a long period from April to October. An easy rewarding evergreen plant even tolerating dryish shade under trees.

Maple leaf foliage emerges a fresh apple green soon fading to a bright yellow with the veins picked out in red. Creamy foam flowers appear above the foliage from April through to summer. Best in dappled shade.
Beautiful evergreen maple shaped leaves are silvery green and bear a dark star. Foamy pink flowers are produced from april to june. AGM. Decent soil sun or semi shade

Broad leaves in two tone green with burgundy veination topped with ample spikes of pale salmon pink flowers from April to October. An easy and rewarding evergreen perennial even tolerating dryish shade under trees

The large maple shaped leaves are a shining bronze overlaid with silver perfect to set off the airy spikes of starry pink flowers that are produced from  April to October. An easy and rewarding evergreen perennial even tolerating dryish shade under trees

Large evergreen maple shaped leaves are a striking orange tea colour with a large cinnamon star. leaves darken in Summer lighten again in Winter. Foamy white flowers are produced from April to June.. Decent soil sun or semi shade. 25 x 40cm

Beautiful apple green maple shaped foliage is marbled with burgundy which creates a beautiful evergreen foil for the spikes of bright pink flowers flowers which appear from spring until autumn. An easy and rewarding evergreen perennial even tolerating dry

Silvered and flushed red maple shaped foliage offsets the  branched spikes of deep coral pink flowers from April to October. An easy and rewarding evergreen perennial even tolerating dryish shade under trees
A very delicate and beautiful grass which produces feather light flowering heads in red tones which waft gently in the slightest breeze. 30cm. An annual to perennial which will seed itself about.

Large. A Japanese garden hybrid. Each leaf is broadly arrow shaped a deep forest green with a relatively narrow irregular white margin. The edges of each leaf are distinctly rippled and the tip has a characteristic twist. A little slow to establish
Perhaps the most beautiful of Hostas with leaves unfurling pale creamy yellow with a variable green edging. Leaves fade to marbled green by mid summer
Mid green leaves with a bold heart-shaped outline beautifully picked out in gold. Strong growing with ample lilac flowers held well above the leaves. Lvs below 30cm
Good contrasting variegation with bright gold broad edges set against strong green centres. Leaves narrow on young plants; becoming broader with age. Medium sized to 7cm across

Small. A form that can attain a height of 30cm but is also very suitable for bonsai use. The leaves are a classic heart shape in a mid green. Flowering is very free with each flower a rich mauve in a nice flared trumpet on relatively tall scapes. The scapes are noticeably ridged.
Magnificent foliage perennial. Up to 3ft of large; ribbed; heart shaped blue foliage with the added bonus of white lily-like flowers. Best in shade; dislikes dry soils.
Magnificent foliage perennial. Up to 3ft of large; ribbed; heart shaped blue foliage with the added bonus of white lily-like flowers. Best in shade; dislikes dry soils.

A medium sized Hosta whose leaves when mature are well rounded deeply puckered and of a beautiful blue tint. A moist shady spot in rich soil will allow this excellent species to realise its full potential. The leaves are more slug resistant being of h
Medium sized Hosta with relatively narrow leaves; edged white. Variegation lasts the season well. Lilac flws on tall stems give an elegant appearance
A relatively compact variety with leaves that emerge twisted with a variable creamy splash up the centre; margined with different shades of green. Variegation lessens in summer
Large. 60 x 170cm. A upright Hosta with a fast growth habit. Dark green leaves with a wavy edge and glod margin. Sport of H . 'Sun Power'
Giant. A fabulous blue Hosta with puckered heavy textured leaves round in outline and distinctly cupped. Great topped with the white flowers. Just wait for it to rain ! H. 'Tokudama' x H. sieboldiana
A medium to large sized Hosta with large puckered leaves that become a uniform clear yellow . Requires some sun to develop it's colour. Flowers a beautiful lilac
A medium to large sized Hosta with large puckered leaves that become a uniform clear yellow . Requires some sun to develop it's colour. Flowers a beautiful lilac

Large. Fast growing with fragrant lavender flowers. A lovely sport which has much stronger variegation than its parent. Beginning the year with leaves that are fairly even green the centre gradually develop a paler colour eventually in enough sun becoming quite yellow.

Giant. 65 x 160cm. Very large ;puckered; deep glaucous blue leaves make an impressive large clump to 1m across. Short dense spikes of near white flowers. An excellent pest resistant variety. Sport of H. 'Fortunei Robusta Variegated'
One of the large blue leaved Hostas with short dense spikes of pale flowers. Each leaf is large; relatively narrow for the type; tapered to a point; blue with a pale bloom
Very large puckered; deep glaucous blue leaves make an impressive large clump to 70cm across. Short dense spikes of lavender flowers. An excellent rapid growing pest resistant variety
Open clumps of triangular deep glaucous blue leaves to 75cm across & graceful pale lavender flowers make this a most desirable medium sized Hosta.
A medium sized Hosta that quickly makes a good size. The leaves are strikingly marked with broad creamy edges and an irregular dark green central splash. Texture is puckered and leaves are cupped.
A medium to large sized Hosta with  very large broad exceptionally well variegated leaves. Each leaf is margined with a broad yellow band.  Makes a striking specimen when grown in a tub
A medium sized Hosta with pointed narrow shiny yellow leaves with a narrow green edge.  Leaves become all green in late summer. Lavender flowers on 28" stalks.

Hosta ‘Color Festival’. Medium. 30 x 50cm. An eye-catching combination of fluorescent yellow streaks between a dark green margin and a white centre make a stunning Hosta. Sport of H. ‘ Enterprise’.  (D vanEechaute 2007)
Medium. 45 x 60cm. A good Hosta for providing contrast in a collection or as a foil to delicate flowers. Deep green leaves of a good satiny texture form lovely even mounds. Sport of H. 'Halcyon'

Medium. A Lovely Hosta with bold variegation. Well rounded leaves that have a bold creamy margin steaked toward the centre of the leaf. A vigorous cultivar if given plenty of moisture when in growth. The flowers are particularly notable being very large and shapely.

Large. height 100-120cm. A very large Hosta with satiney dark-green rounded leaves with a distinctive blue cast. Â The habit is rather open. Sport of Hosta 'Sum and Substance' or possibly of its sport Hosta 'Lady Isobel Barnett'.

Medium-Large. Near white flowers. A Sport of H.'Great Expectations' with faster growth rate but still a little slow to establish. When mature it forms a spectacular large mound of intensely blue leaves with a broad central splash of yellow. Identical to H.'Dream Weaver'

Medium. 50 x 75cm. A striking medium sized hosta with a very neat appearance. Intensely Blue-green leaves greyer towards the bright white margins. A Hosta that always gets noticed. Good substance. A sport of H.'Halcyon'

Giant. 140 x 250cm. For those who like the biggest this is the Hosta to have. The leaves are of a mid blue green and grow to massive proportions with a clump that can easily be 2m across and standing almost as much tall in leaf alone this is an imposing
Medium. 45 x 75cm. A reversed form of H.'Patriot' with white centred leaves with a dark green edge. A striking and good growing variety. Centre can go green in too much light. Sport of H. 'patriot'

Medium. Striking and notable for the unusual combination of yellow leaf and red petiole. Leaves are a bright buttery yellow as they emerge  gradually becoming more chartreuse as the season progresses. Siting in shade will help the colour persist. Quick to increase

The beautiful leaves and petioles are dramatically margined and streaked with dark green on a bright ivory white ground with some paler green feathering. The leaves are lanceolate with sharper tips. Ideally site in a position that receives 2 hours of morning sun or only dappled shade

Large. Forms a large open mound of large well rounded leaves that are a pale green in the centre with a narrow margin of yellow. The flowers which are abundantly produced if given enough sun and moisture are large and fragrant on tall scapes. White emerging from pale pink buds
A very graceful Hosta. Deep green leaves with a narrow bright silver edging are most elegant. Flowers are lavender; freely produced well above the leaves. Rapid growth rate
A very fine large Hosta. The large cupped and corrugated leaves are variegated with a sea green base and broad creamy yellow margin. A moist shady site will see the full potential
A very fine large Hosta. The large cupped and corrugated leaves are variegated with a sea green base and broad creamy yellow margin. A moist shady site will see the full potential

Large. For sun or shade. Large fragrant flowers. Leaves are of an even colouring beginning the year a bright yellow and slowly fading to a fresh yellow-green. Prominent veining and a graceful shape make this a very nice Hosta. Excellent flower quality is just a bonus.
A short variety with narrow pointed leaves; deep green with a bright white edge and intermediate striping of variable shade. Short spikes of rich mauve flowers

Hosta 'Gold Edger'. Small. 30 x 90cm. An excellent edging Hosta with heart shaped leaves of heavy substance that change in colour from light green through chartreuse to gold. A very dense grower that will tolerate sun all day long. H. 'Blue Cadet' selfed or x H.'Gold Cadet'

Medium-Large. For shade. A seedling from H.'fortunei Aurea'. A large dense mound of very pleasant yellow-green leaves with a lovely graceful habit. Leaves emerge citric yellow from red buds with a green cast gradually spreading from the petiole to cover the whole leaf.
A real summer star develops from a modest spring green hosta with dark green margins. In summer the centres brighten to pure gold. A medium to large grower 70cm 30"
Large heart shaped leaves are chartreuse green . Produces lots of lily like lavender flowers. Medium sized grower 24 x 18" (60 x 45cm)

An imposing large Hosta with deeply crinkled green leaves with a broad irregular lime-green and white central splash.This variety is known for its excellent sun tolerance Best grown in miost soil. 90 x 90 cm
This very neat; fast growing Hosta has heart shaped leaves of a yellowy green with a bright golden edge. The flowers are lavender; held high. Repeat flowering.
This very neat; fast growing Hosta has heart shaped leaves of a yellowy green with a bright golden edge. The flowers are lavender; held high. Repeat flowering.

Medium. Identical to H.'Touch of Class'. Sport of H.'Carder Blue' . Still a very good Hosta and one of the earliest to come to flower. Broad blue leaves with a strong yellow centre. Recorded as being similar to June except for a more solid broad blue edge.

Small-Medium. Tissue culture sport of H.'Golden Tiara'.  The main distinction is that the yellow edge is much broader at least half the width of the leaf. Leaf colour better with some morning sum. A polyploid sport ie it has extra chromosomes which give the leaves a thicker texture.
A medium to large Hosta (55 x 75cm or 2 x 3') with heavily puckered heart shaped leaves. The leaf centres are yellow fading white and they are surrounded by a broad blue green margin.
Large. Graceful glossy leaves with an undulating edge and prominent parallel veining. Forms a low mound of gently cascading green foliage.
Short; narrow leaved Hosta with excellent cream variegation. Flowers well with deep lilac blooms on 2ft stems. Spreads well once established. Good edging plant

Medium. 25cm x 50cm. An open mound of rounded sagey leaves margined dark green. A fast grower for a sunny spot where it will quickly achieve its potential. fragrant flowers in August. Sport of  H. 'Fragrant Bouquet'
A small to medium sized Hosta with leaves of a very good blue and short dense spikes of lavender flowers held just above the foliage. A good specimen for tub culture. to 30cm
A small to medium sized Hosta with leaves of a very good blue when grown in full shade. Short dense spikes of lavender flowers held just above  the foliage are an added bonus. to 30cm
A small to medium sized Hosta with leaves of a very good blue when grown in full shade. Short dense spikes of lavender flowers held just above  the foliage are an added bonus. to 30cm

Medium. A fine Hosta of the sieboldiana type which you would be forgiven for thinking was just another blue in the Spring. However as the weeks progress the centre of each broad puckered leaf turns gradually to a creamy yellow leaving just a narrow blue margin.
A very different Hosta. Large soft textured pale apple green leaves topped with fragrant lilac-flushed white flowers. Tolerates moderate exposure to sun. 60-90cm
Large broad Hosta with deeply puckered leaves that are shaded green and bright yellow with a subtle green rim. American Hosta Soc. award winner. Lavender flowers. A form of H. montana. 1m wide

Small. 25 x 30cm. A very distinctive Hosta on account of the very glossy and thick nature of the bright green leaves. Fragrant near white flowers. A very fast growing variety. H. ‘Aden 314' x H. ‘Aden 802'

Medium. Begins with shiny yellow leaves with very red petioles. By mid Summer this is hard to tell from Invincible but in Spring the leaves emerge yellow with a narrow green edge greatly enhanced by the shine on the leaves.

Medium. From plantaginea this variety inherits marvellous flowers. Large fragrant and outward facing they open on tall straight scapes from lilac buds becoming white with lilac veins. The foliage is no slouch with a broad yellow margin fading cream around a solid green centre.

Very Large. Slow to establish but well worth the wait. The leaves are twice as long as wide tapering to a narrow tip with very prominent parallel veins and a rippled edge. A lovely elegant graceful green leaf variety for a moist position in light shade.

Medium-Large.  On younger plants the leaves are quite narrow on maturity the leaves will be broad and rounded with a base colour of blue-green. This dominates in Spring but as the season progresses leaves become variable with leaf edges half leaves or even entire leaves that are yellow.

Medium. 37 x 50cm. A medium sized extremely tidy hosta with heart shaped leaves strikingly marked. The margins are a variable blue green whilst the broad central area is a pale lemony green fading to creamy white in sunlight. Lavender flowers. 60x50cm. Sp

Medium. Along the same lines as June the difference being that June Fever looks like the contrast knob has been dialled to max. Spring leaves are bright glowing yellow with a narrow green edge. the colouri gradually fades to chartreuse retaining a narrower edge than that of June

Large. 50 x 50 cm. Very distinctive colouration. the leaves are overall a good blue green with a central region that ages golden yellow from a blue green edged in an irregular white line. Sport of H.'Striptease'

Giant. 90 x 90cm. A large impressive plant suitable for specimen planting. Glaucous grey-green leaves become large and deeply corrugated. Tall stems of lily-like flowers sway gracefully above foliage. H. 'Nigrescens' hybrid
The leaves of this Hosta medium sized variety are narrow and pointed. The variegation is strong and regular with blue green centres and a broad creamy yellow edge. 60cm

Very Small. Very vigorous and fast. Can be used as ground cover or reduced to bonsai culture. Forms a dense mound of narrow pointed leaves in a pale chartreuse green. Flowering is prolific with tall scapes of outward facing mauve trumpets. Can rebloom if deadheaded. Not sun tolerant.

Very Small. A similar variety to 'Lemon Lime' except that this variety has a narrow dark green edge to each narrow chartreuse coloured leaf. Very vigorous and fast growing Can be used as ground cover or reduced to bonsai culture.

Giant. 100 x 100cm. A very large fine Hosta with a leaf that is blue-green ageing light green with a very bold wide bright yellow margin. Rugosity improves with age. A must have variety. Tetraploid sport of H.'Sagae'

Medium. This is a slow to increase variety but on one that ultimately produces very sculpted leaves that would catch the eye of any flower arranger. Leaves are well rounded with a yellow centre and irregular blue-green margin. They are heavily seer-suckered. Plenty of moisture
A medium sized Hosta with large very round leaves with a broad gold edge which fades cream. Lavender flowers in late summer on 28" stalks.
Medium-Large. Thick shiny green leaves. Seedling from H.siboldiana. U.Syre-Herz. A excellent large deep green variety with heavily seersuckered and dimpled leaves in a large unruly mound.
A large broad spreading Hosta. The heavy textured heart shaped leaves are gently cupped and have striking broad white margins and become puckered when mature. Reasonable sun tolerance.
Mid to dark green leaves have beautiful slightly rippled silver margins and develop a slightly puckered texture when mature. Medium sized (35 x35cm) (18")
A really striking Hosta with a sharp contrast of darkest green irregular leaf margin with a bright gold centre. Thick textured heart shaped leaves and lavender flowers. Medium size - 90cm spread
Small-Medium. Yellow green leaves with a very wavy edge tapering down to a narrow point. A relatively quick grower once established. H.minor x H.'Piedmont Gold'. P.Hall
Leaves emerge mottled with a rich butter yellow; later fading to mid green. The flowers are well coloured; mauvey-pink; held well above the leaves. Lvs below 30cm

Large-Very Large. A fine cultivar that takes a while to get established. Large rounded leaves are held fairly flat with just a slight dish on mature plants. Heavily seersuckered with a good blue base colouring edged in creamy white. Site in partial shade for best results. Pest resistant.
An imposing large Hosta with deeply crinkled blue leaves and a generous cream margin. Best grown in a moist site with light shade where the leaves can grow to their best poitential. 90 x 90 cm

Large-Very Large. 120 x 80cm. A very fine large Hosta. The large cupped and corrugated leaves are variegated with a sea green base and broad creamy yellow margin. A moist shady site will see the full potential. Similar to H.'Frances Williams' but will not

Small to medium spreading Hosta. Fabulous heart shaped yellow leaves are margined and streaked with dark and mid greens. Leaves take on puckered nature with age. Flowers lavender. Highly sought after new variety.
A large broad spreading Hosta. The heavy textured heart shaped leaves are gently cupped and have striking broad white margins and become puckered when mature. Reasonable sun tolerance.
Medium sized Hosta with heart shaped gold leaves with a broad blue green margin. Leaves become slightly puckered with age and the centres become greenish white. 18" 45cm wide. Flowers white.

Large. Quite similar to H.'Krossa Regal' differing in that the leaves are maybe a little narrower on longer petioles and slightly darker in colour. In spring they are very thin and snake-like in the way that they unfurl from narrow pointy buds. A fine cultivar if a little slow.

A medium sized Hosta that quickly makes a good size. The leaves are strikingly marked with broad creamy edges and an irregular dark green central splash. Leaves are distinctly heart shaped on long petioles. Lavender flowers.

Large. A big bold Hosta with well rounded well puckered leaves. Quickly makes a large if not shapely mound of tough leathery textured leaves that are noted for their deep blue green colouring. Vigorous grower. Surprisingly small and delicate pink flowers for such a butch Hosta.
Medium. 35 x 40cm. A unique variety with twisted pointed leaves that are held very erect. Leaves dark green with a blue tinge accentuated by a narrow yellow edge. for light shade

Medium. This is the variety to have if you are looking for glossy leaves as they can look as if they have been waxed. The centre of each long petioled leaf is a rich deep green with a bold regular margin of creamy yellow. Forms an open mound. A nice tidy distinctive variety.

Large. Upright grower. Nice shape with a gently undulating margin. Pale yellow fading more creamy in sun with a margin that is a very muted green sometimes fading entirely. Seer suckering towards the petiole and veins retain some blue-green colouring. Forms a tight crown of leaves.

Giant. 90 x 100cm. A large impressive plant suitable for specimen planting. Glaucous grey-green leaves with a narrow cream edge become large and deeply corrugated. Tall stems of lily-like flowers sway gracefully above foliage. Sport of H. 'Krossa Regal' w
A medium sized Hosta whose leaves are rounded in outline with a pointed tip. The striking and unusual markings feature a rich green edge surrounding a green flecked creamy centre. 60x45cm

Medium. A Hosta that is hard to ignore in the Spring. The leaves emerge from red petioles and are a pale sharp acid yellow with a white margin. Develop a seersuckered surface with age. Leaves will develop from yellow to green with a variable white and yellow edge.

Medium-Large. A quick growing variety whose leaves are lovely but of a slightly thin texture requiring a little protection. They emerge a fresh apple green but soon become a bright yellow with a narrow white margin. The texture is very well seersuckered.

Large. Heart shaped puckered leaves with a wavy margin. A very attractive variety with its variation in leaf colour as they mature at different rates. Each one starts off chartreuse turning a bright yellow as they age all the time with a cream to white margin.

Medium. One of the first of the Hosta out of the ground. A rapid grower with long leaves that have a variable yellow and cream centre streaked with apple green and an edge like a granny smith apple. Can develop a quite pale creamy centre with sun exposure.
Large heart shaped leaves are chartreuse green with broad creamy yellow margins. Produces lots of lily like lavender flowers. Medium sized grower 24 x 18" (60 x 45cm)
Perhaps the most beautiful of Hostas with leaves unfurling pale creamy yellow with a variable slightly wavy green edging. Leaves fade to marbled green by mid summer
A large impressive Hosta with a very round leaf downturned at the edges. The colouring is an irregular creamy gold edge around a dark blue green centre. size 2-3ft across

Medium-Large.  A lovely form creating a gently arching fountain of foliage which is best appreciated when grown in a pot. The leaves are long and narrow with an undulating edge. They begin the season quite yellow fading into the season to a green yellow centre and darker edges.

Medium. 25cm x 50cm. Like its parent an open mound of rounded gold leaves margined dark green but with leaves brighter all season. Prominent veins earn it its name. A fast grower for a sunny spot where it will quickly achieve its potential. fragrant flo

Medium. A quick growing variety. The narrow leaves have a very distinctive patterning consisting of a broad blue-green margin and apple-green fading chartreuse centre with flecks of bright white at the junction between them. Light levels are important to get the best colour.

Giant. 90 x 150cm. Very large ;puckered; golden chartreuse yellow leaves; getting bigger and better as the plant ages. Flowers are pure white in tight heads. Plant in sun to achieve the best leaf colouration.
Medium. Quite similar to H.'Great Expectations'. A Hosta that is slow to produce its final form which is a richly seersuckered heart shaped leaf with moderate blue border and wide creamy centre

Medium. A dramatic cultivar with many similarities to H.'Color Festival'. The leaves sport a variably wide central splash of chartreuse which bleaches out white as the leaf matures. This is surrounded by a border of mixed greens. Leaves develop seersuckering with age

Large. Thick corrugated texture. Forms a dense fountain of leaves which begin life yellow-shaded chartreuse and gradually age a much brighter lemony yellow-green with a white edge. One of the earlier varieties out of the ground. Lavender flowers

Giant. 75 x 170cm. Slow growing but ultimately very impressive Hosta. Upright growth with large wavy edged blue green leaves narrowly margined yellow. Very stately habit makes it a distinctive variety. Improved sport of H.'Sagae'

Medium. Colouring somewhat like an over ripe lime. Leaves begin yellow with a creamy margin taking on much more of a green cast as they age with a whiter margin. The yellow colouring is more prominent in more sun though good moisture at the root is needed if this is the case.

Very Large. 200x75cm. A slow starter but eventually a very large and impressive hosta with lovely leaf shape. Matt mid-green with a blue cast. They are deeply veined seersuckered with a slight ripple on the margin. Needs ample moisture.
Medium. 40 x 75cm. A very attractive cultivar whose leaves are blue on the edges streaking in to the bright green and yellow centre. A Tetraploid sport of H.'June'

Medium. 40 x 75cm. Leaves are  a creamy white gradually turning greener through the season with an irregular dark green edge streaked to the middle. Leaves with a distinct terminal twist. Tetraploid sport of H. fortunei 'Hyacinthina'.
A medium sized Hosta with broad exceptionally well variegated leaves. Each leaf is margined with a variable width cream band. Makes a striking specimen when grown in a tub

Very Large. 150 x 90 cm. Large open mound of thick glossy leaves chartreuse green with a narrow irrregular yellow margin. Good growth rate once established. Plant in morning sun with plenty of moisutre at the root. sport of Sum and Substance

Large. An extremely striking Hosta early in the year when the leaves seem to shine with their own light. Very pale lemon yellow. Paler and more eye-catching than Fire Island. They maintain this colour well but can turn very slowly to green by the end of Summer.
Slow growing but eventually a large specimen The large broad leaves are deeply puckered; pale lemon yellow with a metallic sheen. Tolerates moderate exposure to sun
Medium sized Hosta with heart shaped gold leaves with a broad blue green margin. Leaves become slightly puckered with age and the centres become greenish white. 18" 45cm wide. Flowers white.
GOLDEN HOP. Strikingly attractive large yellow leaves on a climber that grows yearly from ground level to 5m. Female forms produce Hop fruit. Colour develops best in full sun in a moist soil.
A low dense shrub with musty aromatic foliage. Tight spikes of rich blue flowers cover the bush in late summer and are a magnet to butterflies. 2ft. Prune in Spring
A low dense shrub with musty aromatic foliage. Tight spikes of soft pink flowers cover the bush in late summer and are a magnet to butterflies. 2ft. Prune in Spring
A low dense shrub with musty aromatic foliage. Tight spikes of blue or pink flowers cover the bush in late summer and are a magnet to butterflies. 2ft. Prune in Spring
A plant of great refinement; its pale pink tubular flowers gracefully held above delicate foliage. Semi shrubby habit. Prune regularly. For very well drained sunny spot or pot culture

Tropical looking with large opulent gloxinia like blooms carried on stiff 60cm upright stems. Plant in a rich soil in full sun where the yellow throated pink blooms will be freely produced. Good drainage
A free flowering Iris for a moist to wet situation notable for the deep velvety near black flowers produced on tall stems above lax grassy foliage. 45cm. Early Summer

A beautiful japanese Iris with lavender pink petals. The falls are a darker shade than the standards and are further enhanced with crimson flecks. To 95cm (3') in flower which occurs in early summer. Best in moisture retentive soil. Sun to semi shade

Richest deepest purple. Falls are large rounded shields held with great grace. At the top centre of each fall is a bright yellow line marking the way in for insects. Japanese Iris grow best in boggy soils with constant access to moisture. intolerant of alkalinity preferring acid.
Pale yellow form of the Stinking Gladdon Large numbers of flowers in broad foliage followed by large pods of bright orange berries best grown in moist shade
Stinking Gladdon. Pale mauve; veined flowers nestle amongst broad bold green foliage. Autumn seed pods split to reveal vivid orange berries. best grown in moist shade. 60cm

Robust clumps of  sword like foliage from which rise in May tall stems of flamboyant bearded Iris flowers. This variety has deep purple falls and lavender standards brightened with a glowing orange-yellow throat.  Easy to grow in a sunny position.
Beautiful Irises for the bog garden or damp situation at the margins of a pond. Bred to have large flat flowers in a stunning range of colours and patterns
Most beautiful in spring when the bluish  leaves pierce the soil broadly margined with creamy white edges. Flowers are pale blue; produced in late spring. 40cm

A lovely tetraploid form of our native flag Iris. The flowers are a lovely shaded pale lemon yellow with a signal that is picked out boldly in deep red. In the garden it really stands out like it has its own light. It is both vigorous and floriferous. Mid season. 60cm
Most beautiful in spring when the leaves pierce the soil broadly striped pale green and cream. Flowers are strong yellow; produced in late spring. prefers a moist soil. 60cm

Beautiful moisture loving Iris which will produce a dense clump of grassy leaves and a profusion of rich velvety dark purple flowers in mid summer. The flowers are relatively flat with excellent form the richness of the blue being the perfect setting for

The flower colour is much more intense than the species. The falls are a wonderful intense purple blue becoming even deeper sapphire blue towards the centre where the egg-yolk yellow beard is cross hatched by white rays. The standards are stained ruby red in the throat.

Come November to March when the skies are grey and most border plants have long gone to ground this intrepid little Iris starts into growth and on mild Winter days can delight the jaded eye with its most delicate mauvey blue fragile flowers
A dwarf Iris for a well drained spot in full sun. Variegata doesn't refer to the leaves but instead refers to the intricately marked red on white falls. Bright yellow standards.

Excellent vigour deriving from its hybrid nature. The falls are well rounded spoon shape palest creamy lemon-yellow with a marvellous highly intricate pattern of veining picked out in Wedgewood blue. Bright yellow flash with dark veining pale blue standards. Early to mid season. 45cm.

Beautiful moisture loving Iris which will produce a dense clump of grassy leaves and a profusion of rich royal blue flowers in mid summer. The flowers have well rounded descending falls showing to great effect the delicate fall markings. 90cm
Wonderful broad petals of rich deep purple-blue with deeply ruffled edges. Standards also goffered in style and slightly paler in colour. Falls held quite flat. Mid season and will rebloom. 80cm

A tetraploid hybrid in denim blue with falls mottled with paler blue held relatively flat fading to the edges. Standards palest blue. Mustard yellow flash with darker veining. A classic shape with big bold flowers. Mid season. 100cm
Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing  yellow standard petals with cream falls. 60cm. mid summer

Intense dappled blue paler and silvery along the edges of the ruffled falls. Lovely lemon yellow signal suffuses into the blue picked out in the veins. The standards are dappled paler denim blue. A long blooming variety. Floriferous mid season and reblooming.

The flowers of this beautiful Iris have tall standards and distinct rounded falls giving a graceful outline. The colouring is a pale chartreuse yellow deepening to a rich yellow in the throat. Plant in a moist soil. Mid summer. 90cm.

Beautiful moisture loving Iris which will produce a dense clump of grassy leaves and a profusion of papal purple flowers in mid summer. The flowers have well rounded horizontal falls showing to great effect the delicate fall markings. 90cm
Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing rich royal blue flowers with an attractively veined yellow and white throat . 80cm. mid summer
A wonderfully girlie Iris with a delicate blush of pink which suffuses the ivory white falls. Exquisite veining at the throat.  Broad falls and broad waved standards. Mid season reblooming. 85cm

An amazing colour break in a Siberian Iris. The falls are heavily veined and mottled in coppery brown on a turmeric yellow ground. The standards are pale lemony cream heavily suffused lavender Extraordinary. Early. 75cm. Pronounced sweet fragrance. Good long flowering season.

Extravagant fully double blooms. A fully double hose-in-hose with 6 or more falls and 6 standards. Layers of ruffled petals in rose-violet. Pinky lavender falls with a suggestion of a paler edge. White signals with intricate purple veining becoming yellow in the throat. Mid season.76cm
Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing Richly veined velvety maroon flowers with yellow and white basal staining. 90cm. mid summer

Standards are like parchment. The falls have the most intricate patterning yellow with the veins picked out in purple paling and branching towards the sepal edge so that the fall has a strong yellow margin surrounding a lilac-brown haze and bold yellow throat. Early Mid season. 71cm
This hybrid Iris has the form of its parent I. pseudacorus but has flowers beautifully veined purple on a buff ground. Thrives in a moist soil; ideally by water. 60cm

Early through to Late  90cm Falls are shades of violet overlaying bright yellow.Yellow dominates the throat and edges violet bleeding out from heavy netting to wash over the main body. Standards are paler blue violet cream at the edges. Falls held horizontally with a lovely twist.
Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing Richly veined pinkish-maroon flowers with yellow and white basal staining. 60cm. mid summer

The flowers start from a delicate lemon yellow emergence and then as the falls open they pale out to a ruffled white with a lemon edge and rich yellow throat. The standards are clean white ruffled and just touching each other - almost like a central cone. late Season. 70cm

Double but not crowded at all. The flowers are held near flat.aThey have 6 fall petals and no standards with a well rounded ends and narrow base so that the flower has the shape of a snowflake. Rich royal blue towards purple withwhite markings well down into each  petal. Mid season. 70cm

Rounded falls having a generous scooped profile with the tip descending with just the right amount of twist. Very palest of lavenders darkening on the veins of the standards. Falls are yellow in the throat mottled with lavender-pink. Buds are a contrasting dark lilac. Late season. 75cm

Rounded falls have a deep ripple in the edge and are held reasonably flat in a mix of raspberry pinks starting darker and fading paler in the ground darker in the veins and towards the yellow signal. The Standards are white overlaid in pearly shades. Early Mid season. 70cm

Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing delicate powder blue flowers with an attractively veined yellow and white throat . 140cm. mid summer

The Standards and falls are mottled with strawberry pink over a pale ground with all parts having a pronounced wave. The style arms are pale with just a hint of blue. Compare this with I.'Mesa Pearl' which is similarly coloured on a different shape of flower. Early Mid Season. 75cm

Mid season. 90cm A halfway house in terms of doubling which just the standards which sit on the top of the flower in a swirl of petals like a top knot. The falls are generous held towards flat with a lovely rippled edge. Strong cobalt blue with modest throat markings.

Mid season. 75cm A lovely double variety whose doubling has produced a flower that holds itself with an even grace. Nicely rounded and the colour a pleasing pinky-lilac formed by a subtle lilac spotting on a pale pink ground. The throat is yellow edged with a heavy red netting

Rich magenta falls of good shape with a pleasing wave. The standards are a paler lavender as are the style arms the latter being like 2 fused with a crest so that they add greatly to the centre on the bloom. Mid season. 90cm

A really good performer. Very flat flowers in midnight blue with a prominent white flash. The standards are absent having been replaced by an extra set of falls. Paler than the similar I.'Kita-No-Seiza' and broader in its roundness. Mid season. 70cm

Beautiful moisture loving Iris which will produce a dense clump of grassy leaves and a profusion of rich velvety dark purple flowers in mid summer. The flowers are relatively flat with excellent form the darkness of the purple being the perfect setting f

Flowers are beautifully ruffled. The falls are held fairly well out and are shaded purple-blue with darker veins leading to a richly marked throat. The contrast of much paler standards and style arms held like a central cone completes the form beautifully.

Beautiful moisture loving Iris which will produce a dense clump of grassy leaves and a profusion of rich velvety dark purple flowers in mid summer. The flowers are relatively flat with excellent form the darkness of the purple being the perfect setting f
Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing Richly veined velvety maroon flowers with yellow and white basal staining. 90cm. mid summer

Rich glowing magenta falls deepening to purple as you move towards the richly marked throat. The waved edge is accentuated by the fact it is paler. Standards are paler lilac-pink. Lovely form with the horizontally held wavy edged falls. Mid late to Very late season. 70cm

Each flower is slender in all parts with plenty of 'air' within. Standards are bright lemon at the base blended to powder blue. In-between each of these is a palest lemon style arm. Each fall has a bold yellow arm which ends in a well rounded tip of pale powder blue.
Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing rich royal blue flowers with an attractively veined yellow and white throat . 140cm. mid summer

Blooms of a rosy-violet would be more descriptive. The blooms are very full and a little chaotic in their arrangement but the splash of rich colour they produce is not to be ignored. The falls are well marked in the throat with white yellow and red netting.

Tthe effect is pearly with an overtone of flesh. The standard a lilac flushed white and the falls a lovely shading of pearly blues and lavenders. Signal is quite broad and yellow with lines that radiate well down the fall. A good and floriferous variety. Mid season reblooming. 60cm
Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing white flowers with an attractively veined yellow and white throat . 100cm. mid summer
Moisture loving iris producing dense clumps of narrow grassy leaves and a forest of tall stems bearing white flowers with an attractively veined yellow and white throat . 100cm. mid summer
Forming neat hummocks of foliage and dense heads of dark blue 'scabious-like' flowers on 1ft stems; this perennial has a place at the front of every border. Late summer

Dense spreading shrubby mound of creamy-white edged leaves. Eventually its all topped off from late Summer into Autumn with bunches of little mauve daisies with reflexed petals from which shine out a golden boss of stamens to tempt the bees. 30-50cm sunny position.

Handsome perennial which is related to Hydrangea. Crowns throw up 1m high stems of broad opposing apple green leaves topped in summer with loose drooping clusters of waxy yellow flowers. Moist humus rich lime-free soil in dappled shade.
Over dense foliage clumps come a mass of arching stems bearing dense pincushion flowers in a rich range of pastel pink shades. An easily grown and rewarding plant for full sun. 2-3ft
Over dense foliage clumps come a mass of arching stems bearing dense pincushion flowers of a deep rich crimson. An easily grown and rewarding plant for full sun. 80cm

This new variant on Knautia departs somewhat from the light and airy cloud of the species. Instead this variety is quite compact and a good deal shorter at 30-45cm. the foliage is generously variegated such that the stem leaves are nearly completely cream
Over dense foliage clumps come a mass of arching stems bearing dense pincushion flowers of a deep rich crimson. An easily grown and rewarding plant for full sun. 2ft

A very graceful kniphofia whose slender flower spikes glow in a warm apricot. The flower spikes are open and light and the whole plant of generally graceful appearance. Distinctive narrow grassy foliage with a pale midrib. Summer. 60-90cm
An eye-catching Kniphofia producing tall slender pokers in green and pale yellow over a long season from August even into December. 75cm. Award of Garden Merit.

A lovely short variety with dense broad flower heads. The colouring is one of the finest. The whole spike starts green with soft coral tones at the tip. Gradually the flowers open from the bottom in shades of orange kissed pale ochre finally ending up c
Strong growing richly coloured Red-Hot Poker with flowers in striking single colours. Choose from a range of rich shades; yellow through red.  Dense clumps of grassy foliage. Full sun & good drainage
A tall strong growing variety which is a little cooler than its red-hot cousins. Flowers begin green and gradually turn cream as they age. 150cm. full sun with access to moisture in summer

Very straight sided spikes which begin as coral buds in a very muted shade. However as they mature the colour brightens and the flowers eventually open to cream as the coral recedes. There is no hint of yellow about these at all save for the occasional exerted stamen.

A very graceful kniphofia whose slender flower spikes fade from a soft coral-apricot at the top to a rich cream at the base. The flower spikes are open and light and the whole plant of generally graceful appearance. One of the earliest to flower in June.
An old Irish hybrid with good really red flowers to 75cm high (2'6'') produced from July to September. Tolerant of a wide range of soil conditions as long as its not too hot and dry.
A slender medium sized Red Hot Poker whose narrow flower spikes sport flowers that open yellow from green buds. For a warm spot not too dry in summer. 3ft
A charming dwarf Red Hot Poker selected by Beth Chatto for its short habit and beautiful flower spikes shaded from pale yellow to cream at the base. Full sun & good drainage
Unusually short slender spikes of rich dusky coral  red  flowers are produced July to October. Easily grown in a sunny spot. At only 50cm high it is short for a Red Hot Poker

Easy to grow variety with extra long pokers which fade from a glowing salmon bud through yellow to a cream flower. Unusually the pokers often branch like a candelabra. 110cm. Full sun with moisture in summer.
Outstanding Red-Hot Poker with dense spikes of green and yellow pokers that attractively fade cream as they age. Novel and beautiful. A strong grower. 75cm Full sun & good drainage
Strong growing richly coloured Red-Hot Poker with flowers changing from intense red in bud to lemon yellow in flower.  Dense clumps of grassy foliage. Full sun & good drainage
An eye-catching Kniphofia producing tall slender pokers in green and pale yellow over a long season from August even into December. 75cm. .

An outstanding Red Hot poker. The large flowering heads fade from deep tawny brown buds into rich cream flowers all enhanced by the dark bronze stems. Growth is vigorous and flowering is prolific from July to October. 1.2m sun
Easy to grow variety with flowers in shades of soft salmon peach and cream made all the prettier by the flared ends on the trumpets. Bronze flower stems. 70cm. Full sun with moisture in summer.
A medium-tall variety whose dusky flower spikes sport flowers who fade from russety brown through apricot to a soft cream. 120cm. full sun not too dry in summer
A cracking Poker with broad heads that change in colour from lime green buds through shades of warm apricot finally ageing lemon. A shorter variety at 1m high. Good easy and floriferous. AGM
Bright silver; veined leaves and yellow flowers crowded tight to the stem make this; the neatest of the Lamiums; a cheerful and adaptable plant for all situations. 30cm

This is a very valuable if seldom seen member of the deadnettle family. It grows well in dry shady areas where it covers the ground in a low spreading mound of felty foliage. In spring the whole mound is an absolute picture as it erupts with a covering

Just the plant to bring a bit of life into a troublesome dry spot in the garden with its easy habit and lovely richly silvered foliage. Flowers are a rich pink. Useful for ground cover in a wide range of soil and light conditions growing in all but the w
This is the pure white flowered form of this stately deadnettle. Rather than the usual ruddy pinks of the species the dragon-mouth flowers are clean white shading a little green from the leaves.

Flowers are produced in a ring of half a dozen around each node up the stem ruddy pink with wide open mouths and shaggy lips and more than a passing resemblance to a guard of Chinese dragons. It doesn't spread around like so many of its cousins. 30-45cm.

A perennial pea which throws up numerous stems of pale apple green leaves which will reach 60cm with a little support. The flowers are of delicate apricot borne on short flowering stems which stand clear above the foliage. Happiest in a little dappled sh

A charming perennial bushy vetch-like pea. Rich ferny foliage to 2' (60cm) which can be allowed to spread or trained to good effect as a small pyramid.  In the leaf axils are borne clusters of white vetch like flowers. Any soil sun or part shade
A perennial sweet pea with rounded; waxy textured pink flowers carried in large clusters  Self climbing to 6ft using tendrils
A perennial sweet pea with rounded; waxy textured deep pink flowers carried in large clusters  Self climbing to 6ft using tendrils
A perennial sweet pea with rounded; waxy textured pure white flowers carried in large clusters  Self climbing to 6ft using tendrils
Spring pea. A beautiful little treasure for the spring garden that is both dainty and robust Dense lush foliage topped with many small pea flowers in shades of pink & blue. 30cm

Spring pea. A beautiful little treasure for the spring garden that is both dainty and robust Dense lush foliage topped with many small pea flowers. This form has petals that are a delicate sugar pink stained red at the base with a whiter keel.. 30cm
Spring pea. A beautiful little treasure for the spring garden that is both dainty and robust Dense lush foliage topped with many small pea flowers. cyaneus is the blue form 30cm
Spring pea. A beautiful little treasure for the spring garden that is both dainty and robust Dense lush foliage topped with many small pea flowers in rich pink staining purple with age. 30cm
Classic English Lavender. One of the hardiest and most reliable varieties. 100cm. Native to the Mediterranean region from Europe to North Africa

A shorter growing variety with silvery foliage and good strong coloured flowers. Plant in full sun with good drainage. Excellent variety for cutting and drying as angustifolia has a very high oil content which persists well when dried.
An early-flowering compact variety with richly coloured flowers. 60-75cm.

The flowers of this special Shasta Daisy are large and fully double with pure white frilly petals giving an old fashioned cottagey bloom. Plant in any reasonable garden soil preferably in sun.  1.5m. cuts well. Looks lovely amongst blue flowers
A fully double White Shasta Daisy that stands up well in the garden and cuts well for the house. Plant in any reasonable garden soil preferably in sun. 1.2m
A fully double Shasta Daisy that stands up well in the garden and cuts well for the house. Plant in any reasonable garden soil preferably in sun. 1.5m
Massive Shasta Daisy with pure white blooms up to 15cm across carried on sturdy red stems Plant in any reasonable garden soil preferably in sun. 1.5m. cuts well

The flowers of this special Shasta Daisy are large semi-double with pure white frilly petals giving an old fashioned cottagey bloom. Plant in any reasonable garden soil preferably in sun.  1.5m. cuts well. Looks lovely amongst blue flowers

Large flowered Shasta Daisy with uniquely coloured blooms that open a cheerful pale sunshine yellow and fade buttermilk. Plant in any reasonable garden soil preferably in sun.  1.5m. cuts well. Looks lovely amongst blue flowers

This is our native Ox-eye Daisy distant cousin to the Schasta Daisies to which it is similar but more delicate and refined in all it’s parts. This one evokes childhood memories of walking behind the finger mower in Summer meadows
Semi-double white daisies with shaggy effect to the petals are borne on branching stems to 2' (60cm). An easy going cottage garden perennial for a sunny site. RHS Award of Garden Merit
A dwarf strain of Shasta daisy suitable for even the smallest garden. The cheery large white daisies are produced on compact 40cm tall plants. Suits wide ranging conditions
Pure white hanging bells tipped with green
This variety of Gayfeather was bred specifically for cutting; the long foxtail blooms are large; even and of a bright pink-violet. Height 60-90cm
This variety of Gayfeather was bred specifically for cutting; the long foxtail blooms are large; even and of a glistening white. Height 60-90cm
This vivacious perennial has tall  foxtail blooms are bright violet pink and unusually open from the bottom up.. Height 60-90cm Much loved by bees. Guaranteed to brighten up any sunny spot
Splendid stout perennial for moist situation. Large rounded purpley  leaves surmounted by a glowing tuft of bright orange daisies produced in late summer. 120cm

Leaves with a deep wave and edges that are heavily fingered a mix of muted green and purple and the wave in the leaf helps to show off the rich ruby reverse. The flowers are a rich sunshine yellow carried on stems of maroon. Plenty of moisture to get the best growth and largest leaves.
Splendid stout perennial for moist situation. Large rounded deep purple leaves surmounted by a glowing tuft of bright orange daisies produced in late summer. 120cm
First rate architectural foliage for moist  or boggy soils. Leaves are rounded; ruffled  and deeply cut and of a beautiful shade of green. Bright orange daisies produced in late summer. 120cm
A feature for both its handsome leaves and the 6ft tight spikes of yellow flowers that rise on near black stems. Prefers a moist soil to grow well.

Splendid new introduction.. Large rounded purple  leaves surmounted by a glowing tuft of bright orange daisies produced in late summer.  For moist situation 120cm. An improvement on Othello in that the leaves retain the rich purpling all season.
column14: L\Ligularia Brit Marie Crawford leaves late.jpg

column9: Striking in both leaf and flower forming stout clumps of ragged edged leaves and tall yellow spires rising on near black stems. Prefers a moist soil to grow well. 1.2m

Individual segments are cut down to threads. However each one is recurved so that the leaf has quite a dense structure but made up of the finest of elements. Think green cloud. Cow-parsley umbels of pure white flowers. monocarpic. sun to part shade tolerating some dryness. 60cm
Unusual double flowered form of Tiger Lily with all the stamens replaced by petals. to 2m tall; flowers orange spotted with brown Plant deeply in well drained soil in full sun
Magnificent sturdy Tiger lily; carrying up to 50 bright orange blooms on a sturdy stem to 2m tall. Performs well in garden situation Plant deeply in well drained soil in full sun
Beautiful highly fragrant white trumpets; marked purple without & yellow in the throat. Easily grown and quick to increase. 3ft Adds much to the garden for so little space
Pure white flared trumpets; stained bright lemon in the throat and delightfully fragrant. When grown in rich soil; flowers can reach 20cm in length and hang 9 to the stem. to 120cm
An evergreen mound of glaucous leaves arches out with 3ft flowering stems covered with bright citric yellow snapdragons with darker yellow throats. Plant in full sun
A mix of shades from purple through peaches to cream witha smattering of magenta. All the results of crosses between Linaria Peachy and Linaria purpurea
Delightful pale sugar pink toadflax. Continues all summer with its display of elegant spikes crowded with many tiny snapdragons. Evergreen. Suits wide ranging sites
Toadflax. Startling white tiny snapdragon flowers crowd up elegant spikes continuing all summer with its display. Evergreen. Suits wide ranging sites. 60 - 90cm
A long summer display of elegant spikes crowded with many tiny purple snapdragons. Evergreen. Suits wide ranging sites including dry sites in full sun. Cottagey feel.
Small mat forming toadflax with prostrate grey stems and leaves and upturned flower spikes of small creamy snapdragons marked with a rainbow of colours. Dry site in sun
Three Birds Flying.Large spurred snapdragons in pink or violet carried in whorls of three on the 60cm stems. Flowers freely until the frosts if given a hot well drained spot

Spires of elegant snapdragon flowers over a very long seasonon attractive glaucous foliage. The flowers are a coppery peach becoming creamy yellow with pink flushed hoods as they mature. Sterile hybrid of L.dalmatica and L. purpurea.
A short almost shrubby flax. The flowers shine; being shaded from a bright lemon to a rich chrome yellow. The broad green leaves are an excellent foil. 20cm. full sun
Although each bright blue flower lasts only one day; they are produced with such abundance on every stem that the display last all summer. best in sun

This is a good all rounder for every garden. Useful for ground cover for edging or as a flowering plant in its own right. Neat arching shining green rush-like leaves are evergreen and in their prime in Winter. They are happy in sun or shade but flower b
Good little edging plant that will form a neat clump of evergreen grassy foliage amongst which nestle  short tight spikes of mauve flowers in autumn.  sun or shade. well drained soil
(Lithospermum). Flowers of an intense royal blue abundantly produced on a low creeping mat of foliage. Best trimmed after flowering to keep compact. Well drained lime free soil
Hardy perennial lobelia giving a striking display of rich purple; 3-lipped flowers in late summer. The crowded flower spikes can be 2ft long and may need s taking
3ft spikes of pure sky blue; 3-lipped flowers produced in great abundance Very hardy. prefers a heavy soil Used medicinal ly by N.American Indians
A compact series of herbaceous Lobelia with stained leaves and a dense spike of 3-lipped flowers in shades of pink and red produced in late summer. Moist soil in sun. 60cm
A compact growing herbaceous Lobelia with fresh green leaves and a dense spike of rose-pink 3-lipped flowers produced in late summer. Moist soil in sun
A compact growing herbaceous Lobelia with fresh green leaves and a dense spike of vivid scarlet 3-lipped flowers produced in late summer. Moist soil in sun
A compact growing herbaceous Lobelia with fresh green leaves and a dense spike of deep rich pink 3-lipped flowers produced in late summer. Moist soil in sun
A compact growing herbaceous Lobelia with dark; red stained leaves and a dense spike  of bright scarlet 3-lipped flowers produced in late summer. Moist soil in sun
Striking beetroot coloured foliage with tall spikes of startling bright red flowers. An excellent focal point for border or bedding scheme Enjoys a moist to wet situation. 100cm
An unusual and strikingly attractive combination of deep beetroot red foliage and tall spikes of pink three-lipped flowers. An elegant plant for any moisture retentive soil. Height 80cm
A short stocky lobelia which makes a bold statement over a long period with its bold deep cerise flowers held proudly on red stained stems. 40-60cm. Flowers June-September
More perennial than the species with mauve flowers and purses that are violet flushed when fresh. Good for shade and very early to flower in the year

A pure white biennial Honesty. Heart-shaped green leaves with broad frosted edges.. The flowers are followed by attractive elliptical papery silver seed heads which dry well. April and May. Variegation develops in the second year. 100cm. great in shade.

Attractive British native plant that grows naturally in damp meadows. In spring numerous flowering stems are thrown up carrying ragged-petalled pure white flowers that are excellent nectar sources for bees. 60cm

Attractive British native plant that grows naturally in damp meadows. In spring numerous flowering stems are thrown up carrying ragged-petalled pink flowers that are excellent nectar sources for bees. 60cm
A plant of dramatic contrasts with dainty yellow flowers nodding from between the bold dark purple foliage. Colonises well in any moist soil in sun or shade. 90cm
1m high leafy stems crowned in late summer with tightly packed spikes of tiny white flowers; each spike curiosly curled sideways like a wave. Runs well in moist soil
An interesting foliage plant to use as a foil for flowering subjects. Dense semi- shrubby habit with attractive grey/green marbled leaves. Enjoys a moist soil. 60cm
Young shoots emerge in spring an eye catching shrimpy pink. As they mature they become cream and green variegated. From June to September it produces masses of clear yellow flowers. 75cm 2'6''
From June to September it produces masses of clear yellow flowers. 75cm 2'6''
Very distinctive lythrum with broad pale leaves and dense spikes of pale sugary pink flowers which fade with age. Equally at home in a moist border or by water. 100-150cm

A lythrum of narrow pointed outline with slender well  branched spikes of dark purple-pink flowers. The effect is further enhanced by the dark stems. Equally at home in the border or by water. 100-150cm.

A compact floriferous lythrum with well branched  spikes of bright purple-pink flowers. Most useful in  the late summer border and much loved by butterflies.  Easily grown in a border or by water. 100cm
A good reliable late flowering perennial with excellent powers of attraction for butterflies. Shrubby habit with tall dense  spikes of red-pink flowers. 100cm

Reliable late flowering perennial with excellent  powers of attraction for butterflies. Shrubby  habit with tall dense very even foxtail spikes of rich rosy-red flowers. 100cmA lythrum of narrow pointed outline with slender well  branched spikes of dark p
Reliable late flowering perennial with excellent  powers of attraction for butterflies. Shrubby  habit with tall dense very even foxtail spikes of rich rosy-red flowers. 100cm
Plume poppy. A beautiful perennial in leaf and flower. Large handsome blue-grey vine-like leaves and feathery plumes of rusty flowers to 7ft. non-invasive
Plume poppy. A beautiful perennial in leaf and flower. Large handsome blue-grey vine-like leaves and feathery plumes of rusty flowers to 7ft

A delight for those who love the subtle combination of green and white. Plants from a very slowly spreading clump of graceful arching stems which zig-zag from leaf to leaf along stems up to 60cm long. Flowers are terminal a dense bottle brush of small st

Arching stems to 60cm with broad lanceolate leaves with prominant ridges. Starry flowers with narrow green petals held on a branching terminal raceme that begins drooping and gradually opens out and straightens. Followed by bright orange berries. This is the dark stemmed form

Arching stems to 60cm with broad lanceolate leaves with prominant ridges. Starry flowers with narrow green petals held on a branching terminal raceme that begins drooping and gradually opens out and straightens. Followed by bright orange berries. This is the green stemmed form
Musk Mallow. Thriving best in full sun in a moderately dry soil; these reliable perennials will give an extended display of large saucer-shaped white blooms
Musk Mallow. Thriving best in full sun in a moderately dry soil; these reliable perennials will give an extended display of large saucer-shaped pale pink blooms
A mallow of low sprawling habit; the flowers a dusky powder blue with darker veining; nestling amongst deep green foliage. Plant in full sun at the front of the border to see it at its best. 30cm
A mallow of low sprawling habit; the flowers a dusky powder blue with darker veining; nestling amongst deep green foliage. Plant in full sun at the front of the border to see it at its best. 30cm
Erect stems carry a profusion of striking white to pale pink silky blooms with dark eyes and deep purple veining flaring out from the centres. 3 feet 90cm Sunny site
A tall border plant rearing a profusion of holly-hock like wavy edged silky blooms in deep magenta with darker purple streaks. 4 feet 120cm. sunny site
Ostrich Plume Fern. A bold fern for a damp to wet site; the creeping underground stems producing a colony of regular; tall; pale green shuttlecocks. to 150cm. Shade and moisture

Though not a long lived lasting only a couple of years but gently seed themselves about in perpetuity. A short 'bush' of evergreen velvety leaves and from June to October  smothered in highly scented pure glistening white 4 petalled flowers. Well drained soil in sun. 24 inches 45cm
HIMALAYAN BLUE POPPY. This charming woodlander holds its beautiful large cobalt blue 'crepe paper' flowers with great grace on 2ft stems.  For moist humus rich soil in part to full shade
Clear bright lemon crepe paper blooms nod over pale green lush foliage. A plant to allow to naturalise in cool moist conditiions. British Native
HIMALAYAN BLUE POPPY. This charming woodlander holds its beautiful large cobalt blue 'crepe paper' flowers with great grace on 2ft stems.  For moist humus rich soil in part to full shade
Striking leaves with their dense covering of yellow hairs. Erupts with a 3ft tall fountain of red to pale yellow poppies. Monocarpic (ie dies after flowering but will regenerate from seed)

A treasure of a plant for a moist leafy site in partial shade. Stiff flowering stems carry well shaped poppies of the most intense bluest of blues with a generous central boss of stamens. 'Lingholm' is known as one of the more reliably perennial of the b
Fantastic plant for a tropical foliage effect. Plant in a warm spot sheltered from winds to maintain leaves at their best.

This is the lesser known cousin of Melianthus major. Smaller in overall growth and in the broadness of the leaflets so that it is not as imposing but  no less charming and with green rather than blue foliage it is easier to place. A little hardier as well.
Oyster Plant.Trailing stems of intensely blue foliage each ending in a cluster of wonderful 1 blue flowers. Well drained position favoured. Once eaten in Britain as a delicacy
Charming perennial for a shady location where it will happily spread. Soft textured pale coloured leaves above which dance pretty forget-me-not bells. 2ft
Large and showy relative of the campanulas Tall stems carry a long succession of 10cm wide pure white many petalled flowers; each marked purple on the reverse. 2m. sun
Bowles Golden Grass. A gorgeous grass for the early Spring garden; lovely with bulbs but retaining its pale yellow foliage until Autumn. Best in shade. 12 inches
This is one of the shortest of the Miscanthus forming a plant that resembles a small Pampas grass more than the arching columns of some of the more usual taller forms.

A real winner for interst and structure throughout the Season although it is in the Autumn when it really comes in to its own. The leaves which cascade down turn the most gorgeous tints of yellow and then rich red and settle finally into burgundy. 2m

Excellent award winning variety of medium height  (1.5-1.8m tall). Leaves are narrow nicely arching with a narrow edging of white which give this variety an elegant refined and bright appearance. Very pretty when it catches the the low sun from behind. Panicles are red-bronze. Deciduous
An excellent variety for good Autumn colour with the leaves turning a rich mix of plum purple shades. The leaves a have a distinct white midrib during the season. Mid height at aboout 1.5m

A Tall bold grass to back up a planting scheme. Narrow and upright with large droopy feathery plumes which start off narrow with a distinct a pink tint and then explode into a feathery mass. Good yellow Autumn colours. 1.7m

Aromatic foliage (used to flavour Earl Grey Tea) and dense heads of purple flowers in late summer. 100cm. They grow best in a moist light soil with the flowers lasting much better if they receive only morning sun
A reputation for being the very best of the red Bee Balms. It shows excellent (but not guaranteed) resistence to mildew and is a highly attractive to bees and hummingbirds 1m tall
One of a new race of mildew resistant Bee Balms. Aromatic foliage (used to flavour Earl Grey Tea) and dense heads of mauve- purple flowers in late summer. 100cm. Sun
