One of a new race of mildew resistant Bee Balms. Aromatic foliage (used to flavour Earl Grey Tea) and dense heads of pink flowers in late summer. 100cm. Sun
One of a new race of mildew resistant Bee Balms. Aromatic foliage (used to flavour Earl Grey Tea) and dense tiered heads of ruby-red flowers in late summer. 100cm. Sun
An elegant plant with a fragrant thistle-like rosette and beautiful heads of tubular flws which are waxy and change from white to crimson on fertilisation. Sun. Moist well drained soil
British native herb useful as a it has a sweet aniseed flavour that can be used in food for diabetics.
Upright stems to 80cm clothed in soft green leaves and topped with spikes of pure blue; white lipped; flowers in summer. From rather dry sites in Kashmir but adapts to most soils
With sprays of lavender blue flowers from mid Summer until Autumn; catmint deserves its popularity as a cottage garden stalwart. Trim to keep tidy and encourage 2nd flowering. 50cm

A very different catmint both for its very airy upright habit and its flower colour. The flowers which are borne on loose spikes and are of a soft lemon-yellow with a darker yellow lip. The foliage is of a pale apple green with a distinctive minty arom
A beautiful strong growing catmint with sprays of soft blue  flowers set off by sea- green foliage. Lovely when grown beneath old roses. Similar in habit to Six Hills Giant. Loved by butterflies. 2ft
A beautiful strong growing catmint with sprays of soft pink flowers set off by sea- green foliage. Lovely when grown beneath old roses. Loved by butterflies. 2ft
A beautiful strong growing upright catmint with sprays of soft blue  flowers set off by sea- green foliage. Lovely when grown beneath old roses. Loved by butterflies. 2ft

A large growing catmint with blue-green foliage  and tall narrow flowering spikes of a lovely dusky pink. Lovely with dark roses. Best in well drained soil in full sun. Cut back after flowering. 60-100cm

Densely packed racemes of intense pink catmint flowers on long fat bottlebrushes stand upright above nice pointed creased green leaves. Bees just love it ! June to September. 40 x 30 cm. dense and intense pink
A dense shrubby perennial flowering in late summer with short dense spikes of pure blue flowers. Best in well drained soil in full sun. Cut back after flowering. 30-60cm

A useful edging plant especially in warm dry borders with soft curving stems providing an almost continuous display of white catmint flowers on mounds of soft silver-grey scented leaves. 30cm pure white. May to September.
Bright violet flowers over grey green foliage. Bob Brown's collection of seed from the south side of Lake Sevan Armenia.

A must for summer plantings with its subtle grey green foliage and tall arching sprays of pale lavender blue blooms. Whilst superficially similar to Six Hills Giant it is shorter at 75cm and once established has a stiffer more upright constitution.
(N.'Blue Beauty'). This catmint has large flowers of a good blue-mauve on open spikes; produced over a long period. Its spreading habit gives excellent ground cover. 45cm

This rather attractive catmint has a broad pyramidal head of flowers that are pale sky blue with markings of yellow and white in the throat. A neat plant for growing near the front of a sunny border. 30cm

Unusual amongst the nepetas for carrying its flowers in tight vertical column more like some Salvias. Leaves and stems are woolly giving a soft grey effect. For sun and a well drained soils. Roots are swollen into Dahlia like tubers – an adaptation to dr
Nepeta 'Chettle Blue' is of the Nepeta grandiflora type with a strong bushy habit. It is distinguished by the strong blue of the flowers.

A must for the front of any sunny border where it produces with great reliability a 3-4ft wide mound of soft grey green foliage and a hazy cloud of lavender blue flowers which the butterflies adore. Trim to encourage second flowering. Easy to grow and div

A new sport from an old favourite. Like Six Hills Giant it produces a 3-4ft wide hazy cloud of lavender blue flowers which the butterflies adore but in the early spring the blue green foliage is pleasantly variegated. Trim to encourage second flowering.

Fascinating as the beautiful 10cm wide pure white blooms open daily towards dusk. They glow in the moonlight and are faded pink by dawn. Plant has a creeping habit. Best in full sun in well drained soil
SUNDROPS. 3cm wide cups of brightest sunshine yellow shine on this short shrubby perennial. Foliage tinged red and irregularly splashed with yellow. Best in full sun. 50cm
SUNDROPS. 3cm wide cups of brightest sunshine yellow shine above dwarf; lush foliage clumps. Red flushed stems and buds add to the effect. Best in full sun. 50cm
SUNDROPS. Always interesting with pink and red stained young shoots that arch and drip with bright sunshine yellow flowers in summer. Autumn colour is a deep glowing red. Best in full sun. 50cm
Excellent at the front of the border where the trailing stems can flop forward to display  their huge 10cm wide glowing yellow blooms Best in full sun in well drained soil
This charming little free flowering evening primrose is ideal for covering soil or filling in hot dry spots. Best in full sun Many small pink flowers on creeping 60cm stems
A lovely evening primrose with wide open blooms of pale lemon colour; fading a delicate amber. The red buds and stems add to the plants charm. Tall straight stems to 90cm
This beautiful little plant will brighten any shady spot in spring with its abundant charming bright china blue flowers. The attractively ridged foliage is evergreen
This beautiful little plant will brighten any shady spot in spring with its abundant charming bright china blue flowers with an unusual white edging
This beautiful little plant will brighten any shady spot in spring with its abundant charming bright china blue flowers. The attractively ridged foliage is evergreen
Pretty litle annual for a sunny spot in well drained soil. Flowers last well when cut. 40cm
Excellent ground cover under shrubs or in a woodland situation. bright blue forget-me-not flowers produced over a lush mat of green. spreading habit. 15-20cm
Sainfoin. Dense evergreen tufts of vetch-like leaves sending forth 2ft stems ending in dense pyramids of bright pink; veined pea flowers. Good nectar source. Neutral to chalky soil
Sensitive Fern. Creeping roots produce pale green quite broad fronds that often emerge coppery and fade a translucent yellow. A good coloniser for a damp to wet site. 45cm. will take some dry
Spiny Restharrow. Short dense sub-shrub covered in two-toned pink and white peas. to 45cm.
Scotch Thistle. With densely woolly; white leaves and similarly covered flattened stems reaching 6ft and over; this biennial will add a dramatic accent to any planting.

A sweet little plant for edging off all sorts of different areas. Neat spreading clumps of narrow grassy leaves that are evergreen. In Summer the flowers appear in short spikes amongst the foliage pure white followed by occasional berries.
Fascinating relative of Liriope with its black grassy foliage; purple flowers and black berries Will grow in sun or shade; but best in full sun in a well drained soil. 15cm; spreading habit
The tightly packed heads on this compact origanum vary from white to pale pink; sometimes coming with contrasting dark calyces. A useful filler and edging plant
A beautiful short selection bearing dense heads of tightly packed pink-lilac flowers. Foliage purple flushed during winter and when young. Good for butterflies.45cm. sunny position
Airy flower heads go on and on producing their dark pink flowers from late summer through autumn. A beautiful sight when covered by the butterflies it attracts
Small mauve flowers surrounded by whorls of beautiful large hop-like bracts in delicate pale green; ageing pink. Prefers good drainage. Best appreciated trailing over rocks or walls
Produces a low spreading mound completely obscured in late summer by the mass of rich pink flowers crammed in tight rounded heads. A sight only enhanced by all the butterflies it attracts
(Origanum vulgare) An essential ingredient in so much mediterranean cooking. Excellent with tomato reliable hardy perennial. Pretty border plant. 45cm
Interrupted Fern. The fertile pinnae on this moisture loving fern are reduced to seperated dark clusters; giving rise to the common name fronds in a pale green shuttlecock to 120cm

Royal Fern. Well named majestic fern; having a bold shuttlecock outline topped by the rusty fertile fronds. Fronds emerge with a purple tint and senesce with gold and russet tints. 120cm. ample moisture
Royal Fern. Well named majestic fern; having a bold shuttlecock outline topped by the rusty fertile fronds. Fronds emerge coppery and senesce with gold and russet tints. 120cm. ample moisture
Rich purple daisies over an extended season. One of the more cold hardy varieties

Understated but a great foil to Hellebores and bulbs. The leaves are rounded forming good spreading groundcover. Deep green taking on purple veins in Winter. Open cylinders of small pure white flowers on stems about 1 foot high.In shade they really shine out.best in shade
Clear lemon yellow Paeony blooms on a 6 ft shrub. Large pale apple green foliage. Cut old stems to the ground periodically to envigorate the shrub and control size

A gloriously double white fragrant Peony whose flamboyant blooms are decorated with a few dark red flecks which emphasise the beauty of the dark green foliage. 3' (90cm). Flowers early to mid season. Full sun and enriched soil.
A clump-forming perennial with deep bronze spring  foliage and many large double purple - red  flowers on strong stems. Height 60cm. Good cut flower and foliage takes on attractive autumn tints.
A clump-forming perennial bearing many blush pink semi- double flowers in small clusters. Fragrant. Height 85cm. Good cut flower and foliage takes on attractive autumn tints.
Common Peony. A clump-forming perennial with deep green foliage and pretty large double rose pink  flowers. Height 60cm. Spread 60cm.  Good cut flower and foliage takes on attractive autumn tints.

Memorial Day Peony. A clump-forming perennial with deep green foliage and sumptuous huge deep red fully double flowers. Height 60cm. Spread 60cm.  Good long lasting cut flower and foliage takes on attractive autumn tints.
Beautiful glossy leaves and delicate pale pink flowers

Gorgeous small species peony. The leaves emerge coloured like polished bronze and retreat in autumn with similar fiery colours. The pure white flowers are borne in ones and twos and nod gracefully. A short plant for a prime sunny position. 45cm tall

Gorgeous small species peony. The leaves emerge coloured like polished bronze and retreat in autumn with similar fiery colours. The magenta pink flowers are borne in ones and twos and nod gracefully. A short plant for a prime sunny position. 45cm tall x 6
A really striking lactiflora hybrid. The rounded outer petals are a rich rosey pink  goblet surrounding a mass of clamouring yellow staminodes.Mid to late season. 90cm

A magnificent sight in June when large  fully double pure white blooms with a creamy centre are borne on strong stems above handsome dark green foliage which often colours well in autumn. A sunny situation is required to enhance flower production. 90cm (

A very free flowering cultivar considered to be one of the very best double whites. As if the large creamy-white flowers with their creamy yellow centre and hints of red flecks aren't enough the blooms also have a strong rose scent. Mid to late season.
A really lovely lactiflora hybrid that stands 90cm tall on strong stems. The fragrant blooms are produced late in the season and are fully double blush rose in colour.
An erect growing grass forming a tight column. Leaf tips are red and reflexed.  Fine airy seed heads are held just above the foliage. Height 3 feet.

Frilly party dress of layer upon layer of salmon pink tissue paper petals. The centers are stained with cherry pink. A short and stocky poppy only 50cm high. Flowers May to June and sometimes again in September-October after a brief siesta in the height of Summer. for Full Sun
Possibly the best of the 1 red oriental poppies with a strong upright habit and large blooms of a rich blood red. May need staking in rich soils. 100cm
Enormous flouncy apricot blooms open wide and face upwards. A gloriously extravagant splash of colour for any scheme. 90cm. late spring. Sun. Easily grown
This oriental poppy bears enormous flowers with mauve pink petals like crepe paper. Foliage dies back soon after flowering; appearing again in late winter. height 1m
Typical of the English cottage garden; a good blood red; black spotted; oriental poppy with large blousy blooms in early summer. performs best in full sun with a deep root run. flowers to 100cm.
A tall variety which produces its clear orange flowers in abundance during June. Especially beautiful when the flowers glow with the light shining through them. 1m
Upward facing long lasting blooms of clear translucent pink with crinkled petals make this a wonderful poppy for a sunny spot. 75cm high.. Easily grown. Foliage dies down in mid summer
Typical of the English cottage garden; the oriental poppy displays large vivid blousy blooms in early summer. performs best in full sun with a deep root run. flowers to 100cm.
This oriental poppy bears enormous flowers with mahogany-red petals like crepe paper. Foliage dies back soon after flowering; appearing again in late winter. height 80cm

One of the newer cultivars with extremely pretty flowers that are relatively flat resembling more a shirley poppy. The colour is a light rose pink deepening towards the centre. Performs best in full sun with a deep root run. flowers to 50cm

An unusual colour break for an oriental poppy with  large flouncy blooms of old fashioned stone red produced in may and june. performs best in full sun with a deep root run. Good strong flower stems to 85cm.
Deservedly the most popular oriental poppy. The large bright salmon pink blooms are exquisitely formed and held upright well. 90cm. late spring. Sun. Easily grown
An unusual colour break for an oriental poppy with  enormous flouncy blooms in rich maroon-purple  freely produced in early summer. performs best in full sun with a deep root run. flowers to 100cm.
Large white poppies with a strong dark centre; fading blush. A beautiful oriental poppy which adds  a flamboyant splash to the early summer border. Best in sun. 90cm. foliage fades after flowering
Very popular poppy with large white blooms with a variable width orange edging. Foliage dies back soon after flowering; appearing again in late winter. height 60cm
Typical of the English cottage garden; the oriental poppy displays large rich pink blousy blooms in early summer. performs best in full sun with a deep root run. flowers to 100cm.
A new selection with a wealth of features to recommend it. Striking blooms which are white with a broad red edge are carried on compact plants with excellent foliage. height 75cm

Vey large Blooms in a soft salmony pink with central black blotches. An extravagant splash of colour which will lounge gracefully out of the early summer border. Foliage dies away in late summer. 80cm
Vey large Blooms in a soft pale pink with central black blotches. An extravagant splash of colour which will lounge gracefully out of the early summer border. Foliage dies away in late summer. 80cm

A very lovely new oriental poppy with rich pink blooms of a good size on strong stems.  An extravagant splash of colour which will shine out in the early summer border. Foliage dies away in late summer. 80cm. Best in sun
Beautiful well formed creamy white flowers with contrasting black blotches and stamens. A poppy with great charm and refinement. For full sun with a deep root run. 80cm
Beautiful well formed creamy white flowers with contrasting black blotches and stamens. A poppy with great charm and refinement. For full sun with a deep root run. 80cm
So typical of the English cottage garden. Glowing red-orange crepe-paper poppies bloom in abundance in early summer. Best in full sun. 85cm
A  sturdy Oriental poppy with huge dark red blooms in early summer Performs best in full sun with a deep root run.  Flowering stems to 40cm.

Large frilly poppies on strong straight stems. The colour is a soft maroon pink with dark centres and a heavy dark spot. A strong new variety of a well loved cottage garden favourite.  May-June. 85cm

Typical of the English cottage garden; the oriental poppy displays its large blooms in early summer.  A variety producing many smaller blooms in soft pink.  best in full sun with a deep root run. flowers to 80cm.
Large flouncy petals the colour of Water melon flesh crown this 70cm high poppy from May to July. Sunny position in well drained soil.

Vey large Blooms in a soft salmony pink with central black blotches. An extravagant splash of colour which will lounge gracefully out of the early summer border. Foliage dies away in late summer. 80cm

A lovely evergreen perennial poppy for the cottage garden. Heads of tissuey petals in tangerine orange are produced from april to august (dead-heading increases the number of blooms)  45cm high. Easy to grow in a sunny spot.

Attractive glaucous leaves are produced on trailing stems from a central mound. Evergreen and especially attractive in spring as the young stems are produced. Spikes of blue flowers with dainty long stamens im spring and summer
A fan forming grass. Seeds are like fluffy fox-tails; quite stiff and produced in Autumn.  Very pretty with Sedum spectabile. Height 12-18 inches
A short growing and early flowering variety of penstemon; coming in red; violet; rose and lilac shades. Plant in full sun in a  well drained spot for best results. 30cm
A short growing and early flowering variety of penstemon; coming in red; violet; rose and lilac shades. Plant in full sun in a  well drained spot for best results
Bright scarlet flowers on tall stems give a dainty but bright lift to any planting. One of the hardiest penstemons. 90cm well drained spot in full sun for best results
Very pretty mauve lipped white flowers.
A tough penstemon forming a low mound absolutely smothered in summer in rich blue flowers. Excellent garden value at the front of the border. 18in Cut back lightly in Autumn; harder in Spring

Very much as the more common P. bistorta 'Superbum' but in darker tones with slightly narrower foliage. It is an adaptable plant growing in many situations however to get the best grow it where moisture is always at hand. An excellent cut flower for the flower arranger.

This is a really excellent foliage plant if you want to add a dramatic splash of burgundy foliage into a scheme.  New growth in good light is rich burgundy but later it tends more towards brown and can be quite green in low light or shade. Cut back to refresh

Charming umbellifer with delicate clusters of rich rose pink cow parsley like flowers on a branching clump forming perennial around 90cm tall and 45-60cm spread. Nice green foliage a bit like waxy felt-leaved parsley.

Grows wild in rock crevices in full sun. It produces low arching stems rarely more than 15 inches high clothed with elegant whorls of narrow lanceolate leaves with unusual cirrose leaf tips.  2-8 flowers are produced in the upper leaf axils followed by by coral-red fleshy fruits

Exceptionally smart green and white striped leaves clothing its gracefully arching stems which rise no more than 18 inches high. Not as vigorous as either of its parents or its green cousin. Rather than making clumps of leafy stems it instead rises dramatically here and there.
Beautiful in late spring when the arching stems are adorned with paired leaves above and dainty creamy white bells below. 60cm; spreading A plant of great charm for any cool sunless spot

The flowers on this variety are absolutely stuffed with extra petals such that the mouth of each little bell-like flower is completely filled up. The petals are green with a white rim.  A little shorter than the other Solomon's Seals. The leaves are all swept back dramatically

Each part of each pinna is even and narrow with short rounded lobes giving a very pleasing even appearance. The overall effect of each frond is very much like of one the larger ferns like a dryopteris or polystichum so that the plant creates a lush ferny carpet.

An even central blade which get shaggier as you progress outwards. The pinnae have an elongated diamond outline so that there is a good deal of overlap  combined with broad pointed lobes with the ends pointing in random directions to create a very pleasing shaggy frond

Individual pinnae are quite broad in outline but shaggy in their parts with lots of random overlap creating a very full frond. They are narrower at the stalk than Prestonii so that there are more gaps and the frond is consequently more lacy overall. A very fine fern
An adaptable Cornish variant of our native fern whose spreading habit makes it ideal for evergreen ground- cover. Will grow in quite dry conditions This form has attractively branching fronds

Foliage is an asset all year being covered in silky hairs and looking for all the world like silvery strawberry leaves. Yellow-orange with a red eye produced on lax branching stems. This is the sort of plant that is really easy to squeeze in at the front of border. full sun. 40cm
Shining bright lemon yellow flowers produced in summer over large felted leaves. A cheerful plant for the front of the border in full sun. 15-30cm

Brilliant pink strawberry-like flowers with cherry red eyes produced in profusion from May to July over mounds of rich green fine fingered foliage. More compact and softer coloured than Potentilla 'Miss Willmott'. 30 x 45cm

Strong clumps of pale green leaves; and an endless succession from late winter through spring of large pale red flowers. grows best in part shade. Flowers cut well

A plant that is never going to set the world alight but a subtle beauty for those that appreciate its delicate charms. This is the pure white form of the usually red flowered Pulmonaria. It forms a neat mound of pure apple green leaves with clusters of f
Strong clumps of unspotted leaves; and an endless succession from late winter through spring of pale pinky red flowers. grows best in part shade. Flowers cut well

A picture in spring with pale pinky lilac flowers and distinguished by it leaves whose spotting is so heavy as to render many leaves completely silver. It prefers to grow in a moist shaded position; away from hot sun. 15cm

A joy for the spring garden this Pulmonaria has handsome evergreen oval leaves heavily decorated with paler green spots. The flowers are conspicuous with dark pink buds in  velvety purple calyces opening bright rose pink.

A strong but light blue. Quite a short little plant which scoots about the spring woodland garden by way of a gently creeping rhizome with mottled greyish green leaves here and there rather than in one big clump. Tolerates some sun.
Interesting all year round whether it be the deep pink flowers that cheer the garden in spring or the broad leaves with their large silver spots. Good ground cover for shade. 30cm high spreading
A picture in spring with pale pinky lilac flowers Attractive white spotted leaves make good ground cover. It prefers to grow in a moist shaded position; away from hot sun. 15cm
The pale green leaves are heavily spotted silvery cream and are topped off in spring with clusters of mauvey blue and pink flowers.

Almost completely silver foliage and good trusses of lovely nicely flared and shaped baby-blue and pink flowers which look outwards rather than down. The combination of flower quality superb foliage and pretty colour combination is sure to make this a
A strong vigorous clone producing masses of mid blue flowers throughout early spring. Deep mat- green leaves. Assorts well with bulbs in a moist shaded position; away from hot sun. 30cm
A strong vigorous clone producing masses of deep blue flowers throughout early spring. Deep mat- green leaves. Assorts well with bulbs in a moist shaded position; away from hot sun. 30cm
A joy for the spring garden this Pulmonaria has handsome evergreen oval leaves heavily decorated with paler green spots. The flowers are conspicuous with dark pink buds  opening bublegum pink.
A neat short ground covering Pulmonaria which in spring is covered by masses of pale blue flowers. An attractive foil is provided by the  semi-evergreen pale green heavily silver spotted leaves

The leaves of this plant look stunning from summer to mid winter being long apple green with a heavy  silver guilding. the large violet blue flowers appear in february and continue until May. A excellent all rounder.

Handsome silver spotted foliage is refreshed in late summer to make attractive winter ground cover. In spring the plant is covered in sprays of short borage like flowers which open pink and turn blue.

Evergreen velvety leaves of dark bluish green are handsomely marked with copious white spots. Conspicuous white flowers are borne in early spring from blush pink buds. 30cm x 60cm (1x2 ft)
Excellent ground cover and a must for the spring garden.

Evergreen velvety leaves of dark bluish green are handsomely marked with copious white spots. Conspicuous white flowers are borne in early spring. 30cm x 60cm (1x2 ft) Excellent ground cover and a must for the spring garden.

This Pulmonaria makes a big clump excellent for ground cover it's large leaves are handsomely marked with large silver spots which make a perfect foil in spring for bunches of large really bright blue flowers. A lovely addition to the spring garden.

Remarkable for having leaves that are almost entirely silver; making it excellent for lifting a woodland planting scheme.  Flowers produced from Mar to May are pink fading purple.  Best in a moist shady position; away from hot sun. 25cm
A picture in spring with pale pinky lilac flowers Attractive leaves white spotted to wholly silvered make good ground cover. It prefers to grow in a moist shaded position; away from hot sun. 15cm

The foliage on this variety is a rich dark green with particularly well defined bright silver spotting. Flowers are a good pale blue ageing pink. Forms a fairly dense clump with an altogether neat and tidy appearance.

A super new variety of Pulmonaria . Its ground covering leaves are borne in neat rosettes and are heavily decorated with bright silver spots. In spring umbels of opalescent pale blue flowers are produced making it a sheer delight in the winter and spring

A joy for the spring garden this Pulmonaria has handsome evergreen oval leaves heavily decorated with paler green spots. The flowers are conspicuous with dark pink buds in  velvety purple calyces opening bright rose pink.

This new variety has bright green leaves with startling clear white spots to cheer even the winter garden when they are further enhanced by a blush of purple. In spring umbels of flowers are produced in shades of purple. Sun tolerant.
This new variety has narrow green leaves with startling clear white spots to cheer even the winter garden. In spring umbels of flowers are produced in shades of raspberry pink. Sun tolerant.
An exceptionally good variety which would be worth growing for the startling narrow silver spotted leaves alone. Flowers are pale blue borne in spring. Good ground cover for shade. 30cm spreading

Evergreen velvety leaves of apple green are handsomely marked with copious white spots. Purest white flowers are borne in early spring. 30cm x 60cm (1x2 ft). Excellent ground cover and a must for the spring garden.

Narrow dark green sparsely spotted foliage and tight heads of clear pink flowers. Just before the flowers shed they become washed over with blue but the predominant impression is that this a lovely bright pink form with tight bunches of slightly pendant funnel-shaped flowers. 30cm

This variety of lungwort has relatively long leaves deep mat green in colour overlaid with bright silver spots. The flowers borne in profusion in spring are of a bright royal blue. Good spreading ground cover for shade.
A striking spring flowering perennial forming clumps of narrow dark green leaves with bold white spots. The violet blue flowers are borne in tight heads from February to May. Prefers a heavier soil

A beautiful variety with compact silver spotted foliage and masses of magenta flowers. Good ground cover for shaded areas where its early flowers (March onwards) are excellent nectar sources for insects. 30 x 40 cm.

Mixed colour forms of the attractive Pasque Flower; with flowers that are semi-double and fringed. A trait that becomes more pronounced on older plants. Attractive silky seed heads follow. 1ft. Well drained. Good on chalk
Spring brings large; nodding silky flowers in rich deep shades of crimson-red followed by attractive silky seed heads. 1ft. Well drained soil. Good on chalk
Pasque Flower. Spring brings large; nodding silky flowers in rich shades of mauve and purple followed by attractive silky seed heads. 1ft. Well drained soil. Good on chalk
Charming fully double buttercup 3ft tall stems carry a multitude of tight yellow pom-pom flowers in summer Easy to grow and non-invasive. non-seeding

4 foot tall stiff stems are topped off in late Summer with lemon yellow cone flowers with broad petals which hang down in a lovely bobbed curtsey below a prominent cone.Like a more lady-like version of Rudbeckia with the colour more lemon than golden.

Handsome spike of rich pink gloxinia-like trumpet shaped flowers on 2 foot stem reminiscent of a foxglove. May to July. Well drained even stony poor ground in full sun or shade. Very cold tolerant if dry. Can succumb to moulds in warm wet winters.
a modest little plant producing mats of lily like pale apple green foliage. It is very useful for shady evergreen groundcover contrasting with bolder foliage of cyclamen arum or epimedium

A most dramatic plant with huge rhubarb leaves that unfurl darkest maroon from scarlet buds and then are topped by a 7ft spike of pink fluffy flowers. Best grown in a damp site where the roots can find water

The leaves are heart shaped with rich burgundy reverses stems and veins which are shown of beautifully by the way they are carried stiffly upright. The flowers are carried 1.5m high and are of a creamy white. A robust but not overlarge clumper. Thought

Charming bright crimson flowers are borne from Spring until Autumn. Grow in free draining moisture retentive soil in sun. Appreciates plenty of moisture in active growth but requires drier conditions in Winter.

Lacking only the fully palmate leaves of its parent this hybrid form is a treasure for any shaded or moist site. The tall pyramids of cream flowers rise high above rough textured ochre-green leaves. Ideal for pond side or naturalistic woodland plantings.

Flowers start off with a deep red bud emerge a pale sugar pink and gradually fade through red to the deep maroon and highly ornamental persistent calyces. The emergent leaves are beautifully bronzed fading a deep green. Similar to R.pinnata 'Elegans'

This variety has handsome dark foliage throughour the spring later greening but with red under-tones. In June pink flowers are produced in curled panicles.Ideally for a moist situation but the more shade it gets the better it withstands drier conditions.
Handsome leaves for moist shade. Standing up to 3ft tall they are burnished when young; colouring well in autumn. Flowers are pink; similar to Astilbe
Handsome leaves for moist shade. Standing up to 3ft tall they are burnished when young; colouring well in autumn. Flowers are cream; similar to Astilbe

Magnificent perennial for moist or pond side plantings. Large  palmate leaves that take on rich burnished red tones form the late summer onwards. Spikes of tiny cream flowers are a bonus.Spreading habit. 3ft plus

An especially large leaved variety of an already magnificent perennial. For moist or pond side plantings. Large  palmate leaves take on rich burnished red tones form the late summer onwards. Spikes of tiny cream flowers are a bonus.Spreading habit. 5ft

Vivid red stems the colour of rich ruby rhubarb. Handsome lanceolate rich-green leaves surround the stem. The showy assymetrical orchid-like flowers are borne in terminal clusters and are a remarkable shade of rhubarb-orange-red. 30-60cm dependant on conditions.
A strain selected by Rodney Davey for its creamy white flowers. Very unusual
One of the last flowers of autumn with rich glowing yellow daisies each enhanced by its black central cone. Reliable cheerful colour for the late season. 1m. Any soil in full sun

A bit like a perennial sun flower this plant shines out from the border from July to September with its large fully double dahlia like golden yellow flowers topping off its 4 tall upright branching stems clothed with glossy divided foliage.
A brilliant splash of sunshine for late summer into early Autumn. 7.5cm shining yellow cone centred daisies top 5ft high stems in dense clusters. Plant in rich soil in sun for best effect.

Lovely rich-yellow daisies sway gently on 2m high branched stems perfect to accompany the warm tones of Autumn. Equally suited to modern prairie planting schemes or to the traditional mixed border. Plant in full sun.
A beauty for late summer as the orange and red flowers just keep coming in an ever increasing flower head. Perennial but with a tendency to flower itself to death. Sunny position with moisture

One of a new series of Echinacea / Rudbeckia crosses made by Brian Kabbes which are both sterile and perennial. The flowers are broad flat discs sunny yellow at the tips surrounding a perfect circle of rich mahogany red. 55cm. July to September
BLOODY DOCK. Deep blood red veins make for an unusual foliage effect which contrasts well with other spring greenery. Flower spikes should be removed to maintain good foliage. 30cm
Excellent foliage with a felted grey rosette of large deeply toothed leaves which produce a very dense & very symetrical pyramidal head of woolly stems and white flowers. Biennial
Wonderful foliage plant with 45cm leaves entirely covered with dense soft white hairs. Produces a large head of small white flowers. Cut back after flowering to keep it perennial
A charming curiosity amongst Salvias. Flowers are bright yellow with a deep maroon lip mimicking a bumble bee. Best in well drained soil in full sun
Large border salvia producing a hearty clump of pale green leaves and much branched stems carrying hundreds of lilac flowers. A good splash of colour for a sunny spot. 3ft

Rich deep royal blue in abundance. Completely herbaceous with a clumping underground rootstock which throws up 6 ft. high stems of shiny dark green leaves which produce long terminal racemes of vivid blue flowers in late summer.
Sweetly fragrant leaves in a large tidy rosette; giving way in summer to tall spikes of crowded mauve flowers. In effect like a tall Salvia nemorosa. 100cm

Extremely deep maroon-purple salvia flowers are produced all season on a twiggy small leaved shrub. The name translates as 'Moth'. It is hardy inn full sun given good drainage and shelter from freezing East winds.
One of a series introduced to celebrate the Solar eclipse of 11th August 1999
Lovely salvia with an upright bushy habit. The flowers are a rich violet blue carried on narrow spikes and enhanced by the purple black stems and blue green foliage. Best grown in full sun. 90cm.
Excellent garden value on account of its dwarf habit (75cm) and long lasting intensely coloured spikes of violet flowers and bracts. Best grown in full sun.
Excellent garden value on account of its dwarf habit (75cm) and long lasting intensely coloured spikes of violet flowers and bracts. Best grown in full sun.

A super garden plant. Clumps of foliage  produce lots of spires of pink flowers which emerge from darker buds and are set off by purple bracts. A undemanding plant for a sunny site growing to 60cm (2'). good cut flower and for drying for everlasting flowe
An improved purple leaved form of culinary sage. Selected from Salvia o. 'Purpurascens' for its improved hardiness; better winter retention of leaves and darker leaf colour in season
Flowering stems stand 2ft tall; much branched bearing a mass of sugar pink blooms in whorls up the stems. Will repeat flower if cut back.  Best paced in full sun. Lovely with deep coloured roses

Flowering stems stand 3ft tall; much branched bearing a mass of blooms in a most enchanting shade of powder blue. Will repeat flower if cut back.  Best paced in full sun. Lovely with deep coloured roses

Good reliable perennial sage for the front section of any border. Upright spikes carrying relatively dense heads of rose-pink flowers. 50cm. Summer flowering. reblooms if cut back after first flowering.
A sky blue version of these lovely large flowered perennial salvias. First flowering starts in june and July but if dead-headed flowers for a second time in September. 50 cm. Border Ballet series.

Good reliable perennial sage for the front section of any border. Upright spikes carrying relatively dense heads of pure white flowers. 50cm. Summer flowering. reblooms if cut back after first flowering.

Good reliable perennial sage for the front section of any border. Upright spikes carrying relatively dense heads of rich magenta-pink flowers. 50cm. Summer flowering. reblooms if cut back after first flowering.

Good reliable perennial sage for the front section of any border. Upright spikes carrying relatively dense heads of blue-violet flowers. 50cm. Summer flowering. reblooms if cut back after first flowering.

A short compact Salvia at 30cm producing lots of well branched densely packed spikes of small brilliant scarlet 2-lipped trumpets over a long season from early May to October. Rounded hairy aromatic foliage which is grass-green and smells of Cedars when crushed. well drained soil

Compact mound of thick textured leaves with a crinkly edge. Abundant flowering spikes are produced from May until the first frosts. Whorls of up of 6 long tubed pretty flowers of pale pink.  For a sunny site in well drained soils. 40cm
1 Clary. A magnificent show-stopping biennial to add impact to the garden. Large atractive rosettes & a branching head of white; blue & pink flowers the second year. 6ft.
Excellent garden value on account of its dwarf habit (40cm) and long lasting rose pink flowers enhanced by dark purple bracts. Best grown in full sun.
Excellent garden value on account of its dwarf habit (40cm) and long lasting rich blue flowers enhanced by dark purple bracts. Best grown in full sun.
Excellent garden hybrid producing a  long display in May and June of richest deep violet flowers on short flowering spikes. Height 60cm Best grown in full sun.

Dwarf version of the extremely tall S. uliginosa. Clusters of clearest azure blue flowers like a bedding Lobelia on a tall stem. Well worth growing for its remarkable colour. The flowers last and last but needs careful siting in a warm sheltered site with reasonably moist soil.
A very tall salvia for the back of the border (1.2-1.5m). In mid summer it produces spikes of sky blue flowers amidst plenty of upright foliage. Sunny well drained spot
A handsome species with long arching spikes of white flowers with cclustered green bracts that outlast the flowers . Prefers a well drained site in full sun. 60-90cm

Crowded spikes of purple calyces produce a long succession of bright blue nepeta like flowers sticking out all up and down the spikes. Attractive heart shaped leaves are deeply textured not unlike Apple Mint in appearance and make a nice mound to set off the flowers.60cm June to August
A handsome species with long arching spikes of purple flowers with conspicuous mauve bracts that outlast the flowers and produce a pretty purple haze. Prefers a well drained site in full sun. 60-90cm

Flowers are a rich glowing royal purple shown to great effect as the stems and calyces are both near black. A well grown plant can be 3 or more feet high and wide with numerous flowering stalks arching out all over.

Pillar box red flowers typical of Salvia microphylla emerging from dark calyces on thin dark stems. Compact shrubby bush 60cm high in flower all through Summer up until the first frosts. Reasonably hardy given good drainage and a warm sunny site with the shelter of a wall.

Lovely mounds of dissected and smartly toothed grey-green leaves act as a valuable foil for Spring bulbs. In June it sends up lots of wiry self-supporting stems each crowded with neat almost cone-like flowerswhich erupt shaggy pink
Attractive clumps of pinnate leaves giving rise to 3ft stems hung with pendant fluffy pink foxtails. Excellent for the flower arranger

Sure to evoke the curiosity of your neighbours when in Summer  the sumptuous green pinnate and neatly saw-toothed foliage sends up its stems to 5 or 6 feet each topped with a loose head of compact deep blood red cone flowers that dance and sway in the b

Like a half sized shorter version of Sanguisorba 'Arnhem' this lovely sanguisorba sports waving heads of raspberry red cone-like flowers on stiff stems above pinnatifid foliage. For full sun but not too dry borders. Flowering in mid Summer. Korea. 4 feet high

Delicately crimped edges picked out in a bright cream just enough to pick out the leaf shape and lighten the foliage effect. The cone-like flower heads are carried on stiff widely branched stems standing up to 6ft tall Each one is 3cm long consisting of dozens of tiny burgundy flowers.
Dark maroon-red cone flowers  on branched relatively short stems over divided foliage. Lovely to add an extra texture in amongst the hot daisies of summer. 30cm

Sits about mid height amongst the Sanguisorbas half way between 'Arnhem' and 'Chocolate Tip' and about in the middle for colour as well. It is a deep burgundy less red than 'Arnhem' and less sombre than 'Chocolate Tip' and flowers in late summer on stiff swaying stems up to 1.5m tall
Dark maroon-red cone flowers sway on branched stems over divided foliage. Lovely to add an extra texture in amongst the hot daisies of summer. 60cm

Fascinating strawberry pink almost cone like flowers which erupt plumes of white anthers giving an airy and elegant effect arranged as they are on wiry much branched stems. The handsome foliage is pinnate heavily toothed and pleated. A magnet to insect

Fascinating strawberry pink almost cone like flowers which erupt plumes of white anthers giving an airy and elegant effect arranged as they are on wiry much branched stems. The handsome foliage is pinnate heavily toothed and pleated. A magnet to insect

A great British native for a planting somewhere rough. The flowers are larger than the type with very many extra petals really quite dishevelled in form with a split calyx like an old pinks but they have a old world charm. The colour is cream deepening to a sugar pink. 3-4 ft.

A great British native for a planting somewhere rough where it will produce a good show of raggedy double pale sugar-pink campion-like flowers in late Summer. This is one of those perennials that we call 'undemanding' or put another way a blessed nuisance.

A great British native for a planting somewhere rough where it will produce a good show of raggedy double pink campion-like flowers in late Summer. This variety comes out a mid pink darkening with age to a pretty strong cerise.
Good all round value with dark green leaves overlaid white above and red below; airy heads of bright white flowers on red stems and creeping red stems that root to form new plants. Sun and drainage

A real gem to be treasured in a moist cool shady spot. Glistening rounded leaves; mottled with shades of  maroon and purple; the perfect setting for the dainty sprays of pale lemony-green flowers produced late in the autumn.

One of the last herbaceous plants to flower producing airy sprays bedecked with pure white flowers from October. The leaves are glistening green with beautiful mahogany stems and reverses.For a sheltered spot.

The flowers start like padded burgundy buttons. Then a frill of burgundy white edged petals erupts deckeld with whiote exerted anthers. Eventually the centre of the flower becomes a tight pyramid of claret coloured blossoms all sprinkled with white anth
An excellent modern hybrid scabious bred to be good in the border and as a cut flower. Large blooms of a good mid blue with typical central 'pincushion'. loves a little added lime
This strain was selected from plants produced by the premier breeder of border scabious; Isaac House Excellent in the garden or as a cut flower
An excellent modern hybrid scabious bred to be good in the border and as a cut flower. Large blooms in soft creamy white with typical central 'pincushion'. loves a little added lime
An excellent modern hybrid scabious bred to be good in the border and as a cut flower. Large blooms of a good mid blue with typical central 'pincushion'. loves a little added lime
A selected form of our native small scabious producing a mass of lavender pincushion flowers throughout summer. Good on chalk. Needs good drainage

Rosettes of finely cut foliage push up tall wiry richly-branched stems topped with a multitude of small 15-25mm light yellow pin-cushion like flowers with short pale yellow ray florets. The flowers mature into very attractive seed heads that dry very wel

(‘Pixie Yellow’). An outstanding selection by the University of Georgia. A compact dwarf habit and an abundant and free flowering tendency producing a cloud of pale creamy yellow pincushion flowers throughout the season. 40cm

Tall and branched from a nest of pinnatifid foliage to dance off with numerous deep mauve scabious flowers. The ray florets are quite large and their dissected nature and way in which they are held gives off a cottagey and charmingly disheveled air.
Really free flowring with masses of vivid violet pincushions right up until the frosts. Compact and relatively mildew resistant.
Blue green leaves have wavy edges and are intensely silver variegated. Pinky white flowers are born in late summer and are much loved by butterflies and bees. Sun
The beautiful golden variegated leaves make a striking clump and a perfect foil for the pink-eyed starry white flowers. Excellent for butterflies. 60cm. Full sun
A Small creeping species with dove grey leaves which in autumn are completely obscured by the mass of pale pink starry flowers. A real winner for the rock garden. Non invasive
Strong growing sedum with dense heads of bright  sugar pink flowers set off by round glaucous foliage. A magnet to butterflies in early Autumn. 60 cm tall. Sunny position in any soil
Strong growing sedum with dense heads of white flowers set off by round glaucous foliage. A magnet to butterflies in early Autumn. 60 cm tall. Sunny position in any soil
Strong growing sedum with extra large dark red flower heads - larger than 'Autumn Joy' A magnet to butterflies in early Autumn. 60 cm tall. Sunny position in any soil
Strong growing sedum with dense heads of white flowers set off by round glaucous foliage. A magnet to butterflies in early Autumn. 60 cm tall. Sunny position in any soil
Strong growing sedum with dense heads of white flowers set off by round glaucous foliage. A magnet to butterflies in early Autumn. 60 cm tall. Sunny position in any soil
Strong growing sedum with dense heads of bright  sugar pink flowers set off by round glaucous foliage. A magnet to butterflies in early Autumn. 60 cm tall. Sunny position in any soil
ORPINE. Large fleshy leaves of a bloomy deep purple and late flowering make this sedum an interesting addition to any scheme; looking especially nice in gravel gardens. ;30cm
Probably the best dark foliage sedum. Bushy habit almost black upright foliage giving rise to red flowers from July to September. Height 40cm (18'')
ORPINE. Large fleshy leaves of a bloomy deep purple and late flowering make this sedum an interesting addition to any scheme; looking especially nice in gravel gardens. ;30cm
An unusual but very attractive combination or deep glaucous foliage with dense heads of creamy lime green flowers. 30cm tall  Best grown in a sunny position

A new cultivar with all of the good characteristics of 'Autumn Joy' without its tendancy to split open. Toothed grey green foliage and vivid pink flowers which are a magnet to butterflies in early Autumn. 60 cm tall. Sunny position in any soil
Beloved by butterflies with rich ruby red heads of flowers in early Autumn. Stems of deep purple leaves trail 1ft from a spreading crown. Will stand dry conditions. Cut back hard
Strong growing sedum with extra large dark red flower heads - larger than 'Autumn Joy' A magnet to butterflies in early Autumn. 60 cm tall. Sunny position in any soil
Strong upright growth combine with glaucous foliage and large heads of pale pink flowers to  make a very desirable pretty sedum. 60cm A magnet to butterflies in early Autumn.

Ideal for attracting bees and butterflies in late summer but has the added attraction of super foliage. Smokey blue green leaves heavily overlaid with purple and purple stems. Broad clusters of flowers are cream in bud opening rusty pink. 50cm high. Easy
Beautiful compact growing sedum with a dense head of deep red-maroon flowers and purple tinged foliage. height 45cm Excellent nectar source for butterflies
Beloved by butterflies with rich ruby red heads of flowers in early Autumn. Stems of glaucous leaves trail 1ft from a central crown. Will stand dry conditions. Cut back hard
Beloved by butterflies with rich ruby red heads of flowers in early Autumn. Stems of glaucous leaves trail 1ft from a central crown. Will stand dry conditions. Cut back hard

A Stately plant for the back of any border. The foliage is a joyful mass of finest cut leaves providing a lovely foil for the teirs of flat heads of white flowers all enhanced by the rich red stems. An upright plant for any moderately drained soil in su
In habit quite like a columbine; but with quite different flowers - fully double in a rich ruby red Height 45-60cm. Moist soil   HARMFUL IF EATEN
Like a delicate dwarf Aquilega; but with spurless maroon-pink nodding flowers daintily held above finely cut leaves. Height 30-45cm. Moist soil  HARMFUL IF EATEN

Cheerful easily grown perennial for wide ranging soils; preferably in full sun. Stout clumps of foliage and delicate spikes of hollyhock-like flowers in palest satin rose pink. 80cm. Flowers July- august
Cheerful easily grown perennial for wide ranging soils; preferably in full sun. Stout clumps of foliage and delicate spikes of reddish-pink mallow flowers. 1m
Cheerful easily grown perennial for wide ranging soils; preferably in full sun. Stout clumps of foliage and delicate spikes of hollyhock-like flowers in rose pink. 1m

Cheerful easily grown perennial for wide ranging soils; preferably in full sun. Stout clumps of foliage and delicate spikes of hollyhock-like flowers in palest satin rose pink. 80cm. Flowers July- august
Cheerful easily grown perennial for wide ranging soils; preferably in full sun. Stout clumps of foliage and delicate spikes of hollyhock-like flowers in carmine-rose. 100cm. Flowers July-August

Cheerful easily grown perennial for wide ranging soils; preferably in full sun. Stout clumps of foliage and delicate spikes of hollyhock-like flowers in palest satin rose pink. 120cm. Flowers July-August
Cheerful easily grown perennial for wide ranging soils; preferably in full sun. Stout clumps of foliage and delicate spikes of hollyhock-like flowers of a rosey red. 100cm. Flowers July-August
Double flowers in the most shocking pink imaginable makes this a plant that is sure to be noticed. A sterile variety that just goes on and on flowering all summer. 60 cm
Evergreen rosettes produce a number of arching wiry stems at the end of which are suspended the white bladdered flowers. Will repeat flower if dead-headed. Height 15cm
60cm
Beautifully variegated iris-like leaves forming a dense clump to 45cm. Upright stems carry many upward facing creamy yellow flowers. Evergreen

Grey green iris like clumps which sprout spikes or creamy yellow flowers in May. Easy to grow in any sunny spot ideal at the edge of a path or bed where it gets plenty of air and can lounge forward and look at its best. Evergreen

Cheery small perennial for growing at the front of a sunny bed or in the rock garden. Spreading clumps of short grassy foliage topped all summer with a succession of yellow-eyed rich purple flowers. 15cm

A pretty hybrid between a michaelmas daisy and a golden rod. The open sprays of delicate lemon yellow flowers have a good deal of grace and cut excellently for the flower arranger. 60cm. Summer flowering
A compact dwarf selection of golden rod. Forms a dense clump of dark green foliage with a thickly branched head of many hundreds of tiny rich yellow flowers in late summer. 50cm

75cn Stems are clustered with 5 petalled hollyhock-like flowers the exact colour of ripe apricots with a deep red stain at the base of each petal from June to September. Requires full sun good drainage and a spot sheltered from the East wind.
Pale green sagey leaves and hairy stems  bearing whorls of orangey red flowers throughout the summer. Does well for regular trimming and deadheading. Dry sunny site
Lamb's Ears. Excellent ground-cover is formed by the dense mats of soft woolly grey leaves. Flower spikes also are thickly woolly and cut and dry well. Easy cultivation. 30cm

Lamb's Ears. Excellent ground-cover is formed by the dense mats of soft woolly grey leaves. Flower spikes which are rarely produced are also thickly woolly and cut and dry well. Easy cultivation. 30cm
Lamb's Ears. Excellent ground-cover is formed by the dense mats of soft woolly grey leaves. Flower spikes also are thickly woolly and cut and dry well. Easy cultivation. 30cm
The heart shaped leaves make good ground cover; giving rise to dense heads of palest blush pink flowers on short stalks. A first rate spreading plant for the front of the border.
The heart shaped leaves make good ground cover; giving rise to dense heads of rosey-pink flowers on short stalks. A first rate plant for the front of the border
The many 2ft stems are held stiffly erect crowned with a dense head of tubular lipped flowers in pale pink. Good value in the border and an excellent cut flower for arrangements

Foliage is broad divided and silver-grey white on the reverse - worth a place in the border for this alone. The flowers start as a 5cm ball of silvery papery scales from which emerge a tuft of pale pink thread petals making a classic thistle shape. 60cm
Airy; oat-like flowers sway gracefully on tall stems above a dense hummock of foliage. Flowers 2.5m; foliage 1m. Prefers a well drained warm spot

column7: (Stipa tenuifolia. Nassella tenuissima) Mexican Feather Grass. Texan Needle Grass
column9: Needle thin foliage forms an arching fountain which only get more diaphanous when the feathery inflorescences appear throughout Summer. Being short it is really easy to slip in all through the garden and looks at its best if you can get it back lit by the westering sun.
Large cornflower-like flowers in white with a pink tinge and evergreen leaves make this an attractive and unusual perennial for a warm well drained spot. good cut flower. 1m
Large cornflower-like flowers of clear blue with a pink tinge and evergreen leaves make this an attractive and unusual perennial for a warm well drained spot. good cut flower. 60cm
Large deep violet purple cornflowers from August to September and evergreen leaves make this an attractive and unusual perennial for a warm well drained spot. Good cut flower. 1m
An unusual form of our native Devil's Bit Scabious with buttermilk yellow buttton-like pin-cushion flowers. For a moist soil in sun or partial shade. July to October. 80cm

Good for any damp planting and useful in meadow schemes where a Spring meadow management regime can be applied. The flowers are dusky blue buttons held on stifly branching stems. Particularly effective en masse. Grows on slightly acid to calcareous soils

Good for any damp planting and useful in meadow schemes where a Spring meadow management regime can be applied. The flowers are dusky blue buttons held on stifly branching stems. Particularly effective en masse. Grows on slightly acid to calcareous soils

A relative of our native Devil's Bit Scabious an inhabitant of wet meadows. It flowers earlier than Succisa by early August. Denser and less airy than its British counterpart. 60cm. Pearly white with just a hint of pinkish lavender and are a great necta
Growing just 30cm tall with a very dense head of hanging creamy white bells; produced in a continual succession. Excellent edging plant. Campanula family
Tall comfrey with flowers in a rich lavender
Ground covering comfrey with beautiful variegated leaves and attractive pendant red and lilac flowers. Good for brightening up a shady spot. Will suceed even in dry shade
Excellent weed obliterating ground cover for most situations. Covered in spring in a long succession of hanging bells; each cream and pale blue; opening from deep red buds.
In addition to the flat heads of golden yellow flowers this tansy delights with lemony yellow fern like foliage throughout the growing season. Spreading habit. 120cm

Lovely little carpeting woodlander; easy to grow with pretty little leaves that add to the garden all year around. Leaves are well rounded and lobed with veins and edges that colour red as the temperature drops. The flowers are small held sparsely on tall waving stems.
A very floriferous perennial which will produce a short bushy mound of sage like foliage covered from June to September in tall thin spikes shaded from a rich purple base to a pale green tip. 40cm

Sturdy thalictrum with delicate double pinnate blue-green foliage and dusky pink-purple fluffy flowers crowded into a flattened pom-pom and carried on dark stained stems. The darkest form of this species. Altogether a plant that tends towards the twilight
Short sturdy thalictrum with delicate double pinnate blue-green foliage and pink fluffy flowers crowded into a flattened pom-pom. 30-45cm. Best in moist shade
A delicate and charming addition to any planting scheme with very deeply divided foliage and an airy head of pink flowers with contrasting yellow stamens. 120cm. Cool position
A delicate and charming addition to any planting scheme with very deeply divided foliage and an airy head of pure white flowers . 120cm. Cool position
A delicate and charming addition to any planting scheme with dainty foliage and sprays of gypsophila like double mauve pom-poms in July & Aug 120cm. Sun/part shade

A handsome background plant to 5' (1.5m) The foliage is divided into broad leaflets which make a good foil for other plants long after the fluffy lemon yellow flowers have passed. This variety has golden yellow leaves in spring.
6ft stems carry delicate; blue ferny foliage; topped with a fluffy mass of yellow. Good structure plant and excellent for natural plantings. Sun or Shade.

A Charming Japanese mounding meadow rue. The hummock of crowded foliage is nearly obscured in June by the gypsophila-like cloud of tiny pale pink pom-pom flowers. A plant of delicate charms for a cool position in acid soil. 30x30cm
Beautiful divided foliage varying in tint from sea green to reddy brown; the perfect setting for the cloud of small pendulous pink flowers. 1-2m. Cool position

This is a seedling from the supposedly sterile thalictrum ‘Elin’ and is said to be an improvement on it. An imposing specimen plant reaching between 200 and 300cm in height often without the need for staking. The foliage emerges well coloured turning a

This variety has its roots firmly in Thalictrum aquilegifolium and so has broad heads like lavender-pink fluffy clouds which are quite strong in colour and set strikingly on black stems. Plant it in a sunny spot but make sure it doesn't want for water in the growing season. 1.5m plus

A fine cross between T.rochebrunianum and T.flavum glaucum .. A sterile hybrid it produces stiff tall 3.6m dark stems which carry steely blue foliage below and a branched cloud of yellow and lavender flowers above. Despite its size it rarely needs staki
Stiffly ascending stems terminate with upright spikes of bright yellow; nectar-rich pea flowers. A very attractive; if little known species. Non invasive. to 80cm. sun
Tall stems of silvery green leaves ending in stiff upright spikes of bright yellow pea flowers. Good where it has chance to spread. full sun. to 1m
Charming groundcover for moist shade. Forms a spreading pale green carpet brightened in late spring by fuzzy white flowers emerging from pinky red buds. 15-30cm

Charming ground cover for moist shade. At its loveliest in Spring when the pale new growth emerges over the dark over wintered foliage with a generous topping of pink budded foamy flowers . Leaves deeply palmate with a central dark blotch15-30cm

Deeply incised palmate leaves with the ‘fingers’ cut 3/4 of the way to the palm strongly marked giving the whole leaf the suggestion of a purple black star with green margins. Flowers typical little white stars

Charming ground cover for moist shade. At its loveliest in Spring when the pale new growth emerges over the dark over wintered foliage accompanied by a generous topping of flesh-pink budded foamy flowers . Deeply palmate leaves with central dark star. 15-

Charming ground cover for moist shade. At its loveliest in Spring when the pale new growth emerges over the dark over wintered foliage with a generous topping of pink budded foamy flowers . Leaves deeply palmate with a central dark blotch15-30cm

A new variety with really interesting marbled foliage. Over a base coat of apple green the leaves are heavily speckled white with the veins picked ouit in red. In winter the leaves take on another overlay of autumn shades. Charming pink and white bottle b

Charming ground cover for moist shade. At its loveliest in Spring when the pale new growth emerges over the dark over wintered foliage with a generous topping of pink budded foamy flowers . Leaves deeply palmate with a central dark blotch15-30cm

Charming ground cover for moist shade. At its loveliest in Spring when the fesh new pale-green leaves with cenhtral maroon star are topped with numerous rose-pink budded foamy flowers . Leaves deeply palmate with a central dark blotch 15-30cm

A useful plant that can be great in the right place excellent for the wild garden just don’t plant it in the rockery. The leaves are reminiscent of comfrey and the flowers which appear before the leaves in early Spring are like compressed spikes of bo
Spreading mounds of neat grassy foliage amongst which nestle the cheery lilac and white flowers. A reliable and colourful addition to the front of the border. Best in full sun. 20cm
Spreading mounds of neat grassy foliage amongst which nestle the cheery triangular blue flowers. A reliable and colourful addition to the front of the border. Best in full sun. 30cm
Sreading mounds of neat grassy foliage amongst which nestle the cheery triangular pink flowers. A reliable and colourful addition to the front of the border. Best in full sun. 30cm
Spreading mounds of neat grassy foliage amongst which nestle clean white triangular flowers . A cheerful addition to the front of the border. Best in full sun. 30cm
Nestling amongst mounds of short neat grassy foliage are abundant sprays of three petaled pale blue flowers. A cheerful addition to the front of the border. Best in full sun. 30cm
Spreading mounds of neat grassy foliage amongst which nestle clean white flowers with curious furry blue stamens. A cheerful addition to the front of the border. Best in full sun. 30cm
Spreading mounds of neat grassy foliage amongst which nestle the cheery triangular bright cerise flowers. A reliable and colourful addition to the front of the border. Best in full sun. 45cm

Particularly dark flowered form of the Formosan (Taiwan) Toad Lily. Flowers are upwards facing arranged in cymes at the end of each stem rather than in each leaf axil as in some species. 75cm September to October. A stoloniferous species which will gradu
Delightful late flowering perennials with groups of small white lily like flowers heavily spotted with purple or mauve. Height 60cm. For humus rich soil in sun or shade.
The flowers on this variety are particularly heavily coloured. The spidery petals are heavily spotted in rich maroon with the spots coalescing at the tips to form a dark blotch. 1m tall
Delightful late flowering perennials with white flowers which are heavily spotted with mauve and purple borne  in the leaf axils. Height 90cm. For humus rich soil in sun or shade.
A quite distinctive species which carries the largest flowers of all the Tricyrtis. The stems are long and arching and carry pendant yellow flowers from the axils each one spotted maroon inside.

Delightful late flowering perennials with white flowers which are heavily spotted with mauve and purple borne  in the leaf axils. one of the shorter varieties at 50cm tall. For humus rich soil in sun or shade.

Attractive both for the curious flowers and the soft yellow green striped leaves .White flowers heavily spotted with mauve and purple are borne  in the leaf axils in late summer. Height 50cm. For humus rich soil in sun or shade.

This is a variety which leans towards Tricyrtis formosana. It is earlier flowering than most with compact habit. The flowers are relatively broad in the petals with a bas colour of pink stained white moderately spotted with burgundy. Height 60cm
Sophisticated clover with flowers in a lovely green shaded cream. Best with moisture and a little shade.

Flower heads start like a fuzzy fir cone green with overtones of mauve  opening up from the bottom with a ruff of peachy-pink flowers with darker red lips. Excellent nectar source. Tolerates poor soils including calcareous. From dry grassland in Europe to the Mediterranean. 60cm

Showy and upright with long terminal heads of flowers downy and silvery in bud opening from the base with ruby-red peas. Likes sunlight but not extremes of temperature.Moisture in a slightly alkaline soil. Late summer.Nectar rich and therefore a magnet for the bees.

Flowers are brilliant white contrasting well with the rich dark green of the foliage. Ideal for poor soils tolerating calcareous  very well. Reblooms if cut back. Excellent nectar source for bees. 60cm. Native to Europe  down to the Mediterranean in dry grassland and woodland edges
The neat little mound of tightly crowded bright green leaves compliment perfectly the mass of upward facing wide open 5 that stud it in early spring. 15cm moist soil
Strikingly beautiful spring flowering perennial  for any moist soil. Glowing deep golden yellow incurved buttercup flowers with a splash of protruding inner petals. 90cm. Attractive cut foliage

Hybrid globe flower beautiful rounded flowers in a rich glowing sunny yellow; produced in early summer  With attractive foliage also this perennial is perfect for any moist soil or waterside planting. 3ft
Hybrid globe flower with perfectly formed cupped flowers in translucent glowing orange. With attractive foliage also this perennial is perfect for any moist soil or waterside planting. 3ft

Hybrid globe flower with perfectly formed cupped flowers in translucent glowing orange. With attractive foliage also this perennial is perfect for any moist soil or waterside planting. 3ft. Colour really glows if grown by Geranium sylvaticum 'Mayflower'

A strong robust hybrid globe flower with perfectly formed cupped flowers in a translucent glowing orange. With attractive foliage also this perennial is perfect for any moist soil or waterside planting. 3ft
Hybrid globe flower with perfectly formed cupped flowers in translucent lemon yellow. With attractive foliage also this perennial is perfect for any moist soil or waterside planting. 3ft

A hybrid globe flower which in spring is lit up with perfectly formed cupped shaped double petalled flowers in palest moonlight cream. Requires a moisture retentive soil or is happy in wet soil as a waterside plant. vigorous habit . 60cm

A hybrid globe flower which in spring is lit up with perfectly formed cupped shaped double petalled flowers in translucent glowing orange. Requires a moisture retentive soil or is happy in wet soil as a waterside plant. Attractive divided foliage . 3' (9

A strong robust hybrid globe flower with perfectly formed cupped flowers in a translucent glowing orange. With attractive foliage also this perennial is perfect for any moist soil or waterside planting. 3ft
Hybrid globe flowers with perfectly formed cupped flowers in translucent glowing orange. With attractive foliage also this perennial is perfect for any moist soil or waterside planting. 3ft
A tall form of our native Globe Flower; Beautiful in spring with its perfectly formed lemon yellow incurved buttercups held well  above attractive foliage mounds. 90cm. moist soil
A rarely seen trollius with large golden yellow incurved flowers with a boss of protruding orange petals. Best in a heavy moist soil where the beauty of flowers and foliage will best be seen. 90cm

5cm long flared lemony-yellow deeply cut bells with a lovely twist in each petal. They are clump formers with upright stems clasped in alternate oval leaves which in this form  ages into golden yellow as the season progresses. Moist humus rich soil. 50cm high.

Principally grown for its starling foliage which is especially good in spring this easy going perennial has racemes of dainty white flowers in July and August and is sure to cheer the winter garden from January onwards. 2' 60cm

Magnificent stately perennial whose large rounded leaves are pleated like a fan and make an impressive largely slug resistent mound. The flower spike is tall stiffly branched and densely covered in deep maroon stars. A rare and impressive plant best gr

Tall airy wands of well spaced pure white flowers make a graceful and delicate plant which grows happily in most soils and will seed about liberally. Each white flower has a distinctive purple centre. 150cm

Slender vertical accents with tightly packed small soft white flowers with fluffy mauve eyes. This is a good plant to give a gentle off-white touch to a pastel scheme and especially good with Campanulas. A sound perennial reaching 1m high
From a dark shining rosette of leaves arise several stems bearing relatively long-stalked white flowers with a soft fluttery edge. A relatively short lived variety. 60cm. May to August.
Mixed colours of this charming dainty perennial verbascum. The airy 45cm spikes carry flowers which vary from white; through shades of pink to dark purple. Best in sun
Mixed colours of this charming dainty perennial verbascum. The airy 45cm spikes carry flowers which vary from white; through shades of pink to dark purple. Best in sun
Large felty rosettes of grey green leaves give rise to tightly crowded felty flower stems that are crammed with flowers in a deep cherry red. Summer flowering. Full sun. 100cm
Large felty rosettes of grey green leaves give rise to tightly crowded felty flower stems that are crammed with flowers that age from brick red to flesh pink. Summer flowering. Full sun. 100cm
Pristine white flowers on branching spikes each flower with a felty orange eye. Will repeat flower on side shoots if old faded spikes are removed. 100cm. dry sunny position

Ruffled orange-peach flowers crowd along a 80cm tall and elegant flower spike over grey felty leaves. Will flower twice if cut back. A beautiful way to add a vertical accent to any planting scheme. Summer flowering. Full sun.  well drained
Unusual colour combination of flesh-pink flowers with fuzzy purple stamens; all on tightly packed tall stems. Beautiful leaves In Autumn. Summer flowering. Full sun. 100cm

Unusual colour combination of flesh-pink flowers with fuzzy purple stamens; all on tightly packed tall stems. Attractive felty grey green rosettes of leaves. Summer flowering. Full sun. 100cm
Pale primrose yellow flowers adorn branching spikes over a lovely grey felted rosette. Will repeat flower on side shoots if old faded spikes are removed. 100cm. dry sunny position
Striking and beautiful with tall woolly spikes crowded with purple eyed; biscuity-amber coloured flowers. Repeat flowers if cut back Summer flowering. Full sun. 150cm. well drained
Unusual colour combination of flesh-pink flowers with fuzzy purple stamens; all on tightly packed short stems over woolly grey-green foliage.  Summer flowering. Full sun. 30cm
Golden ochre flowers with a broad pink stripe down each petal centre and a shaded ochre and pink reverse.
White flowers with dark maroon eyes adorn branching spikes over a lovely grey felted rosette. Will repeat flower on side shoots if old faded spikes are removed. 100cm. dry sunny position100cm.
Rich pink; purple eyed flowers crowded along a  tall and elegant flower spike. A beautiful way to add a vertical accent to any planting scheme. Summer flowering. Full sun. 100cm. well drained
Pale primrose yellow flowers adorn short branching spikes over a lovely grey felted rosette. Very much like a dwarf form of V. Gainsborough. 30cm. dry sunny position
Peachy-orange flowers with fuzzy purple stamens; all on a relatively short branching stem to 80cm. Basal leaves are  woolly  pale green forming a dense clump.  Summer flowering. Full sun.
Pristine white flowers on branching spikes each flower with a felty orange eye. Will repeat flower on side shoots if old faded spikes are removed. 100cm. dry sunny position
Stiff tall stems up to 6ft; crowned with ever expanding heads of pinky mauve flowers. Flowers from late summer onwards. Sunny position. Will replace itself from seed

The ever branching heads of small white flowers get better and better from June to September as they grow in size . A tall and robust addition to the border but of nonetheless delicate appearance. 150cm. Best in a moist soil in full sun.

The ever branching heads of small pink flowers get better and better from June to September as they grow in size . A tall and robust addition to the border but of nonetheless delicate appearance. 150cm. Best in a moist soil in full sun.

The ever branching heads of small violet flowers get better and better from June to September as they grow in size . A tall and robust addition to the border but of nonetheless delicate appearance. 150cm. Best in a moist soil in full sun.

An unusual verbena ideal for adding height and colour to the garden in mid to late summer. Stiff erect stems to 90cm are clothed with serrated leaves and are topped with spikes of purple flowers over a long season. Sun and decent soil.
Lovely metallic purple leaves in spring

Vernonia is a large clump forming perennial with tall 5-7 foot willowy stems which terminate in late August through Autumn in 4 inch wide cymose heads of white fluffy flowers which sway in the breeze and are a magnet to butterflies.Native to damp situations butdrought tolerant
Rooting creeping stems form a lush mat of evergreen foliage which produce spikes of the most vivid cobalt blue flowers in late Spring. A real show stopper for the front of a border. 45cm tall
