column9: Delicate spikes of pale china blue; prettily veined flowers are borne above clumps of glossy evergreen leaves that provide good ground cover.  Early summer. 45cm. Any good soil

Purest white densely packed spikes of flowers each with an exerted style and two yellow tipped anthers. Green in bud. The foliage is greyish green with good creamy yellow margins. All in all a rather elegant and classy plant. June to August. 65cm.

The long slender spikes of buds are green at the top turn white and then through shades of icing pink until they open 1 sugary pink with lovely exerted dark styles which persist after the petals have fallen. The impression is of an elegant pink mascar

The flower spikes of this plant consist of uncountable tightly packed deep purple-blue flowers with exerted stamens giving them a velvety plush quality. Absolute magnet for bees. Very long season June to November if deadheaded. 65cm
Rooting creeping stems form a lush mat of evergreen foliage which in mild weather produces many short spikes of vivid cobalt blue flowers. Excellent ground cover. 10cm tall
A neat bushy dwarf Veronica with deepest sapphire blue flowers from wonderful limey-green tips. Branching flower spikes to 30cm. Very long season. June to October
Rooting creeping stems form a lush mat of evergreen foliage which in mild weather produces many short spikes of vivid cobalt blue flowers. Excellent ground cover. 10cm tall

Easily grown in any fertile soil Veronicastrum is hard to beat for creating an upright accent in any planting. The stems are stiff and erect bearing terminal spikes of clean white flowers in late summer. 120cm

Easily grown in any fertile soil Veronicastrum is hard to beat for creating an upright accent in any planting. The stems are stiff and erect with the terminal spikes of small starry flowers in strong lavender blue.. 120cm

Easily grown in any fertile soil Veronicastrum is hard to beat for creating an upright accent in any planting. The stems are stiff and erect bearing terminal spikes of clean white flowers in late summer. 120cm

Easily grown in any fertile soil Veronicastrum is hard to beat for creating an upright accent in any planting. The stems are stiff and erect with the terminal spikes of small starry flowers being shaded pale pink at the base to old rose at the tip.. 120

Easily grown in any fertile soil Veronicastrum is hard to beat for creating an upright accent in any planting. The stems are stiff and erect with the terminal spikes of small starry flowers being shaded pale pink at the base to lavender pink at the tip.

Veronicastrum is hard to beat for creating an upright accent in any planting. The stems are stiff and erect with the terminal spikes of small starry flowers being shaded pale pink at the base to old rose at the tip.. This is the shorter form of 'Erica'

Easily grown in any fertile soil Veronicastrum is hard to beat for creating an upright accent in any planting. The stems are stiff and erect with the terminal spikes of small starry flowers in pale lavender blue.. 120cm

The graduation of colour and the inflexion of the verticals creates a very nice effect and the foliage too with its reddish stems and slight purplish flush is strong and handsome. In flower from July to September. 120cm tall.

Grows two sorts of shoots One long and barren the other much shorter to 30cm tall and bears the white flowers. Not as hardy as the more common species but reliable in the SW and good elsewhere with the shelter of a wall.

Grows two sorts of shoots One shoot is long and barren the other much shorter upright up to 30cm tall and bears the pink flowers. Not as hardy as the more common species but is reliable in the South West and good elsewhere with the shelter of a wall.

At first impressions it looks a lot like Vinca major with its large fresh green foliage; that is until mid October when it is studded with large palest pearly blue periwinkle flowers which appear throughout Winter into early Spring. The flower age to pure white 30 x 60cm spreading.

This is a sweet little Vinca with much to recommend it. The flowers are white with a rosy glow about the throat and the foliage has a pretty variegation. It is fresh green with a yellow edge when young the edge fading to white as it ages.

If you are looking for something a little darker in a Vinca then this is where to come. It tends to be quite rangey in growth with plain green foliage tinted ochre at times. The flowers are a ruby-violet with a pale ring about the eye.

Excellent ground cover in almost any soil short of a bog growing in sun or shade. The small leaves are a deep rich green and a lovely setting for the pale sky blue flowers which are produced in the Spring.

An excellent variety with abundant blue flowers a good as 'La Grave' and variegated foliage into the bargain. Possibly a little more compact or tight in growth than some of the other varieties but despite this a great coverer of the ground.

The lovely white form of this classic ground covering perennial. Vinca minor is the lesser Periwinkle the smaller of the two species most commonly found. Its makes excellent ground cover in almost any soil short of a bog growing in sun or shade
Horned Violet. The pure white flowers are produced in a very long succession from spring onwards. Trim to improve shape Spreads underground to form dense hummocks

column9: A very large flowered dark purple hybrid with a flower that is heading towards a pansy in size.
The same charming little flowers as Viola cornuta but in a lovely shade of pink with darket bee lines.
Horned Violet. The powder blue violet flowers are produced in a very long succession from spring onwards. Trim to improve shape Spreads underground to form dense hummocks
The pure white form of our native sweet violet. Dense clumps of fresh green leaves to 20cm; and many sweetly scented flowers from Nov to Apr. Grows in shade or sun. Prefers a moist soil

Reminiscent of a Viola riviniana with its flattish spreading growth habit. The flowers are borne on quite lax low stems but they are produced in profusion. They are mid-blue with a white eye and strong bee guides leading up to a orange beak. Scented but not strongly.
Floriferous variety with flowers that have a white ground flecked with violet. Medium scent. Good to grow in shade and in dry spots under trees.
A pale pink form of our native sweet violet. Dense clumps of fresh green leaves to 20cm; and many very highly scented flowers from Nov to Apr. Grows in shade or sun. Prefers a moist soil

column9: A Rosy pink form of our native sweet violet. Dense clumps of fresh green leaves to 20cm; and many very highly scented flowers from Nov to Apr. Grows in shade or sun. Prefers a moist soil
Our native sweet violet. Dense clumps of fresh green leaves to 20cm; and many sweetly scented flowers from Nov to Apr. Grows in shade or sun. Prefers a moist soil

A little gem for the woodland garden or under the edge of spring flowering shrubs. Makes a ground hugging mat of green leaves topped off with really bright yellow violets throughout spring. Tiny but very cheerful!

White form of our native dog violet. Happy to naturalise. The flowers are the purest of whites and standing up from the foliage will shine out wherever they are encountered. Neat low mounds of heart shaped leaves. Valuable as a food plant for several of the fritillary butterflies.
Excellent edging plant; its dark purple leaves forming an excellent foil for its own violet flowers as well as those of many other perennials. Spreads well to cover the ground
Clump forming violet with heart shaped leaves and large pure white flowers lilac flushed in bud. Excellent ground cover and scented. Any decent soil
A most appealing perennial violet bearing a profusion of white flowers heavily spotted in blue through late spring and early summer. Spreads to form a mat 30 cm high
A most appealing perennial violet bearing a profusion of blue or blue-striped white flowers through late spring and early summer. Spreads to form a mat 30 cm high
A highly scented variety in a rich purple magenta
Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil Cream base; streaked with bright mauve Orange Eye. Scented
An improved version of our native sweet violet. Dense clumps of fresh green leaves to 20cm; and many sweetly scented flowers from Nov to Apr. Grows in shade or sun. Prefers a moist soil
A beuatiful pure blue viola with large  flowers of the V.cornuta type. Produces low creeping mats of foliage and a profusion of scented blooms in early summer. 30cm

Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil Base colour blue; streaked with purple/blue and marbled white. Heavily scented
A pale pink form of our native sweet violet. Dense clumps of fresh green leaves to 20cm; and many very highly scented flowers from Nov to Apr. Grows in shade or sun. Prefers a moist soil
Compact hybrid viola sending up many moonlight yellow flowers over a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil

Strong growing variety with nicely scented flowers held well up on strong rose coloured stems. The flowers are near white with a variable flush of apricot-pink which intensifies to rose madder on the spur. Overall heart shaped outline.

A scentless variety produced by Margaret Howard from NSW Australia. The flowers are held on fairly lax stems. They have wide spaced long wavy petals that are a pale pinkish lavender. The centre of the flower is white with strong lines leading to orange anthers.

Similar in colour to Sultan but tending more towards magenta with less violet flushing just violet veining. The flowers are more rounded as well with a strong scent. A strong vigorous variety named after a former seedsman from CW Groves and Son.

Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Very distinctive and unusual flower colouring the yellow overlaid with  purple giving a metalic burnished bronze tint. Any good soil. Scented
Two-toned dark maroon and yellow flowers like cheery little sunshine yellow faces stare out above dense foliage.Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer.
Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil Pale cream; shaded to pale lemon Bright yellow eye. Scented

A compact variety with quite squat flowers as wide as they are tall. The flowers are pink to pale pastel lavender with a very neat well defined set of bee guide lines in the throat making a dark eye. Good scent.
Wide open-faced large flowers of rich sugar pink with little flecks of even richer pink which are only obvious when observed closely which is a treat in itself as it is very richly scented.
Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil Large flowers of a soft lilac blue Highly fragrant old variety - pre 1910
Forget papal purple this Viola is the richest Catholic Bishop Pink you'll come across. Deep and extravagent with a delightful silver edge
Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil flowers a highly unusual matt black with a  purple eye. Beautiful strong perfume

Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil Flowers lavender pink; rayed
Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil Base colour cream; shaded to pale lilac Edges flecked mauve. Heavily scented

('Queen of Snow') This variety is for the most part pure white on neat compact plants though early on flowers can have a distinctive blue rinse. This is one of the longest flowering violets and has a good scent.
A unusual cream form of our native sweet violet. Dense clumps of fresh green leaves to 20cm; and many very sweet scented flowers from Nov to Apr. Grows in shade or sun. Prefers a moist soil

column14: U to Z\Viola odorata Irish Elegance.JPG

column9: A well scented variety whose flowers are a rich glowing Bengal-rose with a velvety sheen. They are narrow in outline taller than they are wide held on long strong stems.
Compact hybrid viola with a long flowering season from spring through summer. Any good soil Yellow centred flowers in old rose; streaked with darker areas.

A potentially very large and handsome fern for a sheltered moist site in a neutral to acid site. Fronds are leathery in texture and can reach 50 x 300cm in ideal conditions. Protect from the worst of the winter cold.

Shade loving little plant that grows a rosette of leathery fresh green leaves from which rise dense curved spikes of small tubular blue flowers. It is very hardy if given adequate drainage in the Winter. Little known cousin to Penstemons Foxgloves and Toadflaxes.

Lily of the Nile. An interesting variation on the usual white flower with large green edged spathes. An excellent cut flower and handsome foliage plant. Mulch young plants well in  first few years. Avoid dry soils. 120cm
column13: U to Z\Zantedeschia aethiopica Green Goddess #2.JPG

column9: Lily of the Nile. Beautiful gleaming white arum lily. An excellent cut flower and handsome foliage plant. Mulch young plants well in  first few years. Avoid dry soils. 120cm

Flowers are more upward facing than the standard Zantedeschia slightly shorter and posses a lovely carmine glow to the base. Reports are that it is as hardy as Green Goddess which we have had outside for many years and that it will take a little more dryness than usual. 60cm

30-60cm tall. The flowers which are widely spaced on each stem are slightly cupped 6 pointed stars creamy white. Best grown in a moisture retentive soil with plenty of water in the Spring and Summer in partial to full shade. HIGHLY TOXIC
